componenttext: Yes, so generally, Europe, I talked about automotive being down as being a customer timing issue. Automotive was certainly a driver. That's one of our -- where some of our largest automotive customers are. But I think, in general, we've been looking -- looking at wireless, it was down there in Europe as well as industrial as part of that industrial conversation I had previously. So I think we do expect Europe to bounce back some next quarter, particularly with a much stronger automotive revenue expected.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, thanks for that. And then the team has done, obviously, a solid job on driving 28-nanometer and 20-nanometer new products. On the competitive front, since your competitor has been in the midst of being acquired, we've not really heard much in the w
componenttext: Great, thanks for that. And then the team has done, obviously, a solid job on driving 28-nanometer and 20-nanometer new products. On the competitive front, since your competitor has been in the midst of being acquired, we've not really heard much in the way of their 14-nanometer program or product family. You guys are obviously out there with your 16-nanometer products and getting some good early traction. Is the Xilinx team seeing the 14-nanometer products yet from your competitor? And any competitive engagements?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Harlan, we haven't seen them, and we haven't seen any announcement from them. This sort of goes and contradicts the commitments that have being made to ship a long time ago. I think that this indicates that the fact that we taped out in June of last year,
componenttext: Harlan, we haven't seen them, and we haven't seen any announcement from them. This sort of goes and contradicts the commitments that have being made to ship a long time ago. I think that this indicates that the fact that we taped out in June of last year, got silicon back in September, because silicon is very, very functional that we have a tremendous lead, and we already have. Now the Virtex side, which we expect to tape-out -- sorry, we expect to sample customers. We've seen the silicon, and again, it is in great shape. And what we're going to do is we're starting to turn the crank, and there will be a large marker of tape-out to 16-nanometer devices because we do believe we have at least a significant time-to-market leadership at this node.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean typically what would happen, Moshe talked about tens of -- customers shipping the 16-nanometer product to UltraScale+. Typically, what would is, happen is, there might be a bake-off between us and our competitor, et cetera. And at this point, we do
componenttext: I mean typically what would happen, Moshe talked about tens of -- customers shipping the 16-nanometer product to UltraScale+. Typically, what would is, happen is, there might be a bake-off between us and our competitor, et cetera. And at this point, we don't have any consumer telling us there was a bake-off going on. So that leads us to believe there are no product -- there are no parts out there, but of course, we're not the center of all knowledge there. But once -- we haven't seen any, as Moshe said.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Chris Rolland with FBR.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Chris Rolland with FBR.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: You guys mentioned a potential downtick in wired comps next quarter. Perhaps you can elaborate on what you guys are seeing there, and how you kind of view this market longer term?
componenttext: You guys mentioned a potential downtick in wired comps next quarter. Perhaps you can elaborate on what you guys are seeing there, and how you kind of view this market longer term?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We had quite a bit of growth this quarter in the wired communications area. It was both, I would say, core wired communications as well as data center, in particular, both data acceleration. But in a big way, also some of the storage -- solid-stage storag
componenttext: We had quite a bit of growth this quarter in the wired communications area. It was both, I would say, core wired communications as well as data center, in particular, both data acceleration. But in a big way, also some of the storage -- solid-stage storage. And so that -- sometimes those customers buy a lot and then absorb, and buy a lot and absorb. And really, the down is more related to the customer absorption in some of those cases than it is to any other trend. What we are seeing a very strong uptake of new products in wired communications. If you stripped out older products and just looked at the ramp of new products, new 28-nanometers and newer, you would see a very nice ramp in wired communications and growth next quarter in new products as well. So this is kind of a timing issue more than it is a trend.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Thank you. And then not too much discussion on auto in the quarter. Maybe that paused, I don't know. And then as we look at the ADAS market more specifically, did you guys pick up any new guys there, Tier 1s, OEMs? I would love some color the
componenttext: Okay, great. Thank you. And then not too much discussion on auto in the quarter. Maybe that paused, I don't know. And then as we look at the ADAS market more specifically, did you guys pick up any new guys there, Tier 1s, OEMs? I would love some color there. And just for your ARM products more generally, auto and everything, what percentage of revenue would you say are actually associated with -- or have a ARM core in them?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So they're was a lot of -- that's quite a few questions. So our -- overall, automotive business continues to be very strong. Europe, year-to-year, full year growth, definitely '16 over '15 at 30%. That growth is coming primarily from ADAS applications. Ou
componenttext: So they're was a lot of -- that's quite a few questions. So our -- overall, automotive business continues to be very strong. Europe, year-to-year, full year growth, definitely '16 over '15 at 30%. That growth is coming primarily from ADAS applications. Our traditional businesses around entertainment, it's stable, still is doing well. Relative to the growth of new applications, I don't know that we have any new public -- something I can say publicly relative to new platforms that have joined. But we had -- there are ordinary design wins in the quarter in automotive, but I'm just not at liberty to provide the name of the ultimate manufacturer at this point in time. We are seeing the designs. We have 1 ramped very strongly, and those -- again, the ADAS application being the biggest driver of growth. There is a growing percentage of that ADAS that has an our ARM core in it. In some cases, we end up having more simple applications, just straight FPGAs in there. But the ARM core is growing very dramatically. So if you say that we talked last quarter about a 50 -- about 50% of our revenue from automotive was ADAS-related, I would say at least 1/2 of that is associated with some level of ARM core, and that will be growing over time.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And your next question comes from the line of David Long with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And your next question comes from the line of David Long with Wells Fargo.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: In which applications are you seeing the most initial interest currently for 16-nanometer product?
componenttext: In which applications are you seeing the most initial interest currently for 16-nanometer product?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, well, there is quite a lot of them because it's a broad product offering. So there's the MPSoC, which is basically our base product. And then there's the Kintex and the Virtex derivatives. So if you look at the ones which I think are the most signi
componenttext: David, well, there is quite a lot of them because it's a broad product offering. So there's the MPSoC, which is basically our base product. And then there's the Kintex and the Virtex derivatives. So if you look at the ones which I think are the most significant ones at this point, it's the next-generation ADAS that goes beyond the 28-nanometer zinc. [ph] It's the industrial control, and we do expect this to be used very broadly for the 5G wireless, at least, for the prototyping versions. Whereas in the 2020 timeframe, it's more likely to go into full-fledged production with the 7-nanometer. So those are 3 target markets which are driving the design wins in the 16-nanometer. But reality is, it's a very broad node, so I'm probably doing a disservice to the others and just sort of mentioning [indiscernible].

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Romit Shah from Nomura.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Romit Shah from Nomura.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Moshe, you mentioned earlier partnerships with IBM on open-power servers using their CPUs and as well with Qualcomm using their server CPUs. And I'm curious, how much interest are you guys seeing from web and cloud providers to deploy these chips?
componenttext: Moshe, you mentioned earlier partnerships with IBM on open-power servers using their CPUs and as well with Qualcomm using their server CPUs. And I'm curious, how much interest are you guys seeing from web and cloud providers to deploy these chips?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The same tremendous interest, because as I said, this is an emerging market. This is a market where performance per watt is one of the -- is the most important parameter, and our All Programmable solutions can actually put a huge dent in improving that fo
componenttext: The same tremendous interest, because as I said, this is an emerging market. This is a market where performance per watt is one of the -- is the most important parameter, and our All Programmable solutions can actually put a huge dent in improving that for a broad range of applications. Now these tend to be, at this point, very large players who are very autonomous and control their software environment, so it's not a PC-type environment where control is in the hands of a Microsoft, right? It's actually, if you look at the big players, the Amazons, Googles, the Chinese equivalents, they absolutely control their environment, and they are driven by the efficacy of their -- the power footprint of their data center. That's why this is viewed as such an interesting and compelling opportunity going forward. Now there's a lot of excitement about this now. This is a market which is starting to evolve, and it has several years to grow. So we've expected to be significant 5 years from now, and I just want to make sure that everyone understands that. At least from our perspective, that's where it will start having the biggest impact. That doesn't mean there won't be deployments before that, but in terms of being a significant portion of our revenue, then it's 5 years away.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And is the partnership with Qualcomm exclusive? Or do you have the ability to partner with other ARM server suppliers?
componenttext: And is the partnership with Qualcomm exclusive? Or do you have the ability to partner with other ARM server suppliers?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have a very close relationship with Qualcomm, but it's not an exclusive one on our behalf. And fundamentally, we can connect with whoever is developing a solution, whether it's x86, whether it's power based, or whether it's ARM based. And we can
componenttext: Well, we have a very close relationship with Qualcomm, but it's not an exclusive one on our behalf. And fundamentally, we can connect with whoever is developing a solution, whether it's x86, whether it's power based, or whether it's ARM based. And we can help accelerate all of those, and you can rest assured that we're in the midst of working with all of them. But the ones we have announced, we have now a very deep relationship with, and we're working towards enabling their products when they have the equivalent CPUs and board systems for those environments. But it's more than just the 2 that we have announced.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then, Jon, can I just ask quickly? My impression is that revenue growth in June and September have traditionally been weaker than December and March, and is that your impression as well? And is there a seasonal component there?
componenttext: Okay, and then, Jon, can I just ask quickly? My impression is that revenue growth in June and September have traditionally been weaker than December and March, and is that your impression as well? And is there a seasonal component there?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, if you look back at our pattern, it has changed from time to time. And last year, I think that was -- I mean, we had down every quarter, so it's hard to pick that pattern of -- out of that, but -- and we're not prepared to talk about the June -- the
componenttext: Yes, if you look back at our pattern, it has changed from time to time. And last year, I think that was -- I mean, we had down every quarter, so it's hard to pick that pattern of -- out of that, but -- and we're not prepared to talk about the June -- the June quarter right now, Romit. We'll have to wait until the next earnings release.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ian Ing with MKM Partners.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ian Ing with MKM Partners.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you talk about scenarios to get gross margins back to the high end of the range? You know, 70%, is it the production ramp costs of going away after March? Or does mix really need to turn more favorable here?
componenttext: Could you talk about scenarios to get gross margins back to the high end of the range? You know, 70%, is it the production ramp costs of going away after March? Or does mix really need to turn more favorable here?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, our goal is to operate in the 68 to 70, and we're comfortable with that. So we're not actually going to have programs that are specific to have that target because we're obviously focused on adding the most value to the company in total on the oper
componenttext: Again, our goal is to operate in the 68 to 70, and we're comfortable with that. So we're not actually going to have programs that are specific to have that target because we're obviously focused on adding the most value to the company in total on the operating margin dollar line. But from a mix perspective, I mean, one of the bigger impacts that we had forecasted for this quarter was the fact that we knew we were going to be returning to a richer, large customer mix that tends to buy in volume and, therefore, has better pricing as a result of that. There was also some end-market characteristics, where we were at a low point for aerospace and defense, and that builds -- that will counteract some of the large customer impact. So I guess, if you're looking for a scenario that drives margin up is, large customers, except aerospace and defense customers. But again, we're not -- we're trying to add total dollars to the bottom line. That's the goal.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Hans Mosesmann with Raymond James.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Hans Mosesmann with Raymond James.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Moshe, just to go back on the aggressive ramp of new products this year, is that a result of just faster-than-expected yield improvements at your foundry? Or are you being opportunistic to kind of take advantage of an opportunity versus the competition? W
componenttext: Moshe, just to go back on the aggressive ramp of new products this year, is that a result of just faster-than-expected yield improvements at your foundry? Or are you being opportunistic to kind of take advantage of an opportunity versus the competition? What exactly is driving that? Or is it just customer demand?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's basically driven by new technology and the maturity of the new technology. And typically what happens when we start with the new process node, then we tape out one version, and then we go through an extensive debug cycle. And once we have the d
componenttext: Well, it's basically driven by new technology and the maturity of the new technology. And typically what happens when we start with the new process node, then we tape out one version, and then we go through an extensive debug cycle. And once we have the debug done, then we can start turning the crank. What has happened is the level of functionality was so high on the initial silicon that we actually could sample it to customers, and we could almost immediately start taping out the other versions. And so the answer to your question is, we're basically exploiting the high quality of the engineering execution and it behooves us to capitalize on that because now as we take -- tape-out all of the other versions, we expect to extend our market leadership in terms of breadth of product and in terms of being -- having first-mover advantage. So it's that element which we're capitalizing on, and it will manifest itself with tape-out -- more tape-out happening faster than we had expected, which is good news because there's more products out.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Does that change -- as a follow up, does that change the timing of the tape-out of 7-nanometer?
componenttext: Great. Does that change -- as a follow up, does that change the timing of the tape-out of 7-nanometer?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. No, it doesn't. Because it means -- it probably means that we will tape-out more versions on 16 to exploit the maturity of it, but it doesn't mean that we'll do 7-nanometer earlier, because in our industry, the customers can only absorb the technology
componenttext: No. No, it doesn't. Because it means -- it probably means that we will tape-out more versions on 16 to exploit the maturity of it, but it doesn't mean that we'll do 7-nanometer earlier, because in our industry, the customers can only absorb the technology at a certain rate. And we believe that on average, every 2.5 years to have a new node is the optimal time for their capacity to use a new technology, and it also helps us contain our costs. Otherwise, we'll just be burning money on tape-outs ahead of when the customers can use them. So we're still planning on 7-nanometer tape-out in the 2017 -- calendar 2017 timeframe, generally speaking.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tristan Gerra with Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tristan Gerra with Baird.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: You had said in the past that 28-nanometer will be larger node from a revenue standpoint than 20. Do you still expect that based on the response that you're seeing from customers? And most -- so assuming that based on your 5G commentary, 16-nanometer's re
componenttext: You had said in the past that 28-nanometer will be larger node from a revenue standpoint than 20. Do you still expect that based on the response that you're seeing from customers? And most -- so assuming that based on your 5G commentary, 16-nanometer's revenue is expected to be larger than the peak you expect at 28?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So we absolutely expect 28-nanometer due to the richness of the product offering and the cross point that it's at and the customer needs to be a long-lasting node, and likely to be the largest node, at least up to this point, in the industry. And we
componenttext: Okay. So we absolutely expect 28-nanometer due to the richness of the product offering and the cross point that it's at and the customer needs to be a long-lasting node, and likely to be the largest node, at least up to this point, in the industry. And we don't expect 16 or 20 to approach that. We do expect the 16 and 20 together to be generally in that sort of size. But the 2 together, not any 1 of them separately. And the 28-nanometer, as I said, had a record revenue this quarter. We expect it to have a record revenue -- that was December. We expect it to have another record revenue in the March quarter. And we -- actually, I wouldn't be surprised if it becomes our all-time highest-record product in terms of quarterly revenue shipments sometime for the next 12 months, and overtakes everything else in terms of that. And what we're seeing is that we expect it to continue to grow, albeit at a slower rate, over the next few years. And it has several years until it actually hits its peak. So that's the story on 28-nanometer for us. 16, we expect to be a very strong node too, but not as a strong as 28.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And not to confuse anything -- or anything that Moshe just said, but we are kind of living on a multi-technology product family situation now. We've just -- in the last couple of quarters, we've announced the smart and 7 product line, which is the 28-nano
componenttext: And not to confuse anything -- or anything that Moshe just said, but we are kind of living on a multi-technology product family situation now. We've just -- in the last couple of quarters, we've announced the smart and 7 product line, which is the 28-nanometer technology. And so we're extending -- using all their technologies to extend low end and improve upon the low end of the FPGA market, where our 20 and 16-nanometer aren't as economical for us to go. So when you start looking at the growth of the company and then the long-term situation, it is going to be a multi-node kind of product family rollouts as we keep going in order cover all the different price points in the spaces we're going to be in.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Vivek Arya with Bank of America.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Vivek Arya with Bank of America.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question, Moshe, is on the long-term growth for the PLD industry. If I look over the last 3, 5, or even 10 years, the top-line growth for the industry has sort of being flattish despite a lot of penetration in new markets. I understand the volatility i
componenttext: My question, Moshe, is on the long-term growth for the PLD industry. If I look over the last 3, 5, or even 10 years, the top-line growth for the industry has sort of being flattish despite a lot of penetration in new markets. I understand the volatility in the communications and the aerospace market, but that's not going away anytime soon, and that's over half of the sales in this industry. So just the very basic fundamental question is, what's going to be different over the next 3, 4 years to create growth in this industry?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, I mean, that's a profound question. And I agree with your comments on it -- we have been disappointed vis-Ã -vis growth of a few years. I think, as a result, there's a point in time where the general expectation was that you could deliver and
componenttext: Okay. Well, I mean, that's a profound question. And I agree with your comments on it -- we have been disappointed vis-Ã -vis growth of a few years. I think, as a result, there's a point in time where the general expectation was that you could deliver and sustain double-digit growth, and we're -- we believe that, that is unlikely. That no, it could happen, but it's unlikely to be the compound annual growth rate. So we're talking about single-digit growth. Even that, we obviously still need to deliver. And as John indicated, we do expect fiscal year '17 to be a growth year. On the general question, which we'll try to answer probably a little better at our Analyst Day, the point that I would like to make is that, except with high volume -- very high-volume markets, ASICs and ASSPs, and this is no longer a wet dream, right, this is documented, known and happening, and has happened over the past few years of becoming less and less viable. And that opens a serviceable market, and it requires the right silicone, and it requires the right software. And if we move forward and we continue to move forward with -- and being at the leading edge, there's less and less to compete with. And if we have the right silicone, we have the right level of integration, and we can enable a broader set of customers to use our technology, we should be able to benefit from that. That's sort of the very high-level answer. I'd love to give you a more profound answer, but that isn't something we can do now. We will try to address it a little better during our Analyst Day and explain what we're doing in order to exploit the opportunities. And amongst other things, just a snippet is, if you look at the ARM product line, that enables us to service a market, which up to when it was available, we couldn't even touch, right? And that's the ASSP market. And we've gone from -- to it already being approaching 20% of our revenue in U.S. node, right, and that just sort of shows you that it's an expansion play. We'll try and give more examples when explaining that in the future.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very quickly, could you help -- Moshe, help us quantify your -- how large is your data center and your automotive business today?
componenttext: Very quickly, could you help -- Moshe, help us quantify your -- how large is your data center and your automotive business today?

componenttext: I'll let Jon give you the official answer there -- or not give you the answer.

componenttextpreview: I actually don't have the data center information, so I don't -- we don't spend a -- we don't track that as a separate sub on a routine basis. And our automotive business has been running in the 7% range, I would say on a -- if you look at it over a broad
componenttext: I actually don't have the data center information, so I don't -- we don't spend a -- we don't track that as a separate sub on a routine basis. And our automotive business has been running in the 7% range, I would say on a -- if you look at it over a broad spectrum of quarters.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And that's double where it was a few years ago, so it has grown.
componenttext: Yes. And that's double where it was a few years ago, so it has grown.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Blayne Curtis with Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Blayne Curtis with Barclays.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're talking about turning the crank on 16, and are you adding any more products? Or is it just a pull-in in terms of the timing? And I know you're giving, fiscal year '17 guidance, but how does that impact the shape OpEx?
componenttext: You're talking about turning the crank on 16, and are you adding any more products? Or is it just a pull-in in terms of the timing? And I know you're giving, fiscal year '17 guidance, but how does that impact the shape OpEx?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't have the numbers, but obviously, it's the right thing to do, right? Because we have leadership, and there is market demand. It would be foolhardy not to exploit that. And we'll give you those numbers when we get to giving the fiscal year '17 numb
componenttext: We don't have the numbers, but obviously, it's the right thing to do, right? Because we have leadership, and there is market demand. It would be foolhardy not to exploit that. And we'll give you those numbers when we get to giving the fiscal year '17 numbers. At this point, what we want to make sure is that we exploit the breadth of the opportunity there, and we're just accelerating the existing roadmap to provide it at an earlier point than we had expected before. There might be an opportunity to actually also provide better coverage, but at this point, it's the former as opposed to the latter.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, but I just wanted to go back out to a prior question on the wireless segment. Is there a way to distinguish whether it's a recovery in inventory? Or are you actually seeing the end market pick up? And then you talked about an average of 20% of rev
componenttext: Thanks, but I just wanted to go back out to a prior question on the wireless segment. Is there a way to distinguish whether it's a recovery in inventory? Or are you actually seeing the end market pick up? And then you talked about an average of 20% of revenue, and not being able to get back to a prior peak, but average of 20%. Is that a good goal that this business could get back to a 20% revenue?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, I think that's a pretty reasonable play -- number, I mean, just a plus or minus a reasonable arrow bar there. I think what Moshe was trying to communicate was that the very large buildup in the overall 4G global network, we have passed that
componenttext: Well, I mean, I think that's a pretty reasonable play -- number, I mean, just a plus or minus a reasonable arrow bar there. I think what Moshe was trying to communicate was that the very large buildup in the overall 4G global network, we have passed that stage of the life-cycle of 4G, even though we continue to get a lot of long-tail business, even from geographies that are more fully deployed like North America, for example, because of capacity, they show the network adding on, et cetera. And the situation and the best that we can see in China is they're building FD base stations. We've been told they're deployed, but as you know, the last time we learned -- we were told those kinds of things it turned out they weren't all fully deployed and there are a lot of buildup in the warehouses. As best as we can tell, it is moving through the manufacturing line, and out of the warehouses and being deployed. And it is going to be a couple of quarters of good business. And yes, there was some replenishment of inventory going on this quarter, but we also see some growth next quarter in the wireless business. And some of that is related to the China market as well.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your last question comes from the line of John Pitzer with CrÃ©dit Suisse.
componenttext: Your last question comes from the line of John Pitzer with CrÃ©dit Suisse.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick ones. First one's housekeeping. Jon, now that the quarter's over, can you just level set us on what you think the extra week added to both revenue and OpEx in the December quarter? And then, Moshe, I think this question might have been partia
componenttext: Just 2 quick ones. First one's housekeeping. Jon, now that the quarter's over, can you just level set us on what you think the extra week added to both revenue and OpEx in the December quarter? And then, Moshe, I think this question might have been partially answered with Blayne's question, but when you think about getting wireless back to prior peak, it sounds like that's more commentary on the overall CapEx cycle and inventory cycle and not the PLD the opportunity set within base stations. And I wonder if you can just comment a little bit on kind of what you think the content on PLD was supposed to be and how that's sort of playing out through the 4G cycle?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So relative to your first question on the impact, we had estimated a couple of a percent, 2% or 3% kind of -- in the last call, and that's exactly where it turned out. The last 2 weeks of the quarter were, for us, the -- were 13 -- week 14 were quite mute
componenttext: So relative to your first question on the impact, we had estimated a couple of a percent, 2% or 3% kind of -- in the last call, and that's exactly where it turned out. The last 2 weeks of the quarter were, for us, the -- were 13 -- week 14 were quite muted on an individual basis. And when you add those 2 together, it ends up being around a 2% or 3% kind of a positive impact as a result of having that extra week. Of course, we get to spend -- that would give all the extra spending in as well in that quarter. And then your second version was around the peak. Moshe, you want to answer?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So what we see is the continuing opportunity and actually a growing opportunity for FPGA content in wireless. We're seeing the number of players who can effectively design ASICs, which is the other option, because there really isn't a viable ASSP sol
componenttext: Yes. So what we see is the continuing opportunity and actually a growing opportunity for FPGA content in wireless. We're seeing the number of players who can effectively design ASICs, which is the other option, because there really isn't a viable ASSP solution at this point in time. We don't see that happening anytime soon. So it's ASIC versus FPGAs. We're seeing less and less players with the capacity to do that. And so the role of FPGAs' growth and with each generation, generally speaking, the average ASP per system is a little higher. It doesn't reflect the much-larger role the FPGA has in the system, so it's an integration play. We replaced a lot of other components. We have more major part, but the ASP does not go out at the same level to reflect the value the FPGA provides. But generally speaking, it's one of those markets, where the role of the FPGA continues to grow. And the major competition is the very, very, very few, and actually diminished number of players who can design ASIC alternatives. And that number continues, with each generation of production, to go lower and lower.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016

componenttext:
Good afternoon. My name is Victoria, and I will be your conference operator. I would like to welcome everyone to the Xilinx's Second Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] 
I would now like to turn the call over to Rick Muscha. Thank you. Mr. Muscha, you may begin your conference.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Jon Olson, CFO. We will provide a financial and business review of the December quarter, and then we'll open the call for questions. Let me remind everyone that during our conference c
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Jon Olson, CFO. We will provide a financial and business review of the December quarter, and then we'll open the call for questions. 
Let me remind everyone that during our conference call today, we may make projections or other forward-looking statements regarding future events or the future financial performance of the company. We wish to caution you that such statements are predictions based on information that is currently available, and actual results may differ materially. We refer you to the documents the company files with the SEC, including our 10-Ks, 10-Qs and 8-Ks. These documents contain and identify important risk factors that could cause the actual results to differ materially from those contained in our projections or forward-looking statements. 
This conference call is open to all, and is being webcast live. We wish to caution you can be accessed from our Xilinx Investor Relations website.
Let me now turn the call over to Jon.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rick. Xilinx sales were $566 million, up 7% sequentially and at the high end of our guidance. We experienced exceptional new product growth during the quarter, driven by our 28-nanometer 7 Series products and 20-nanometer UltraScale products. E
componenttext:
Thank you, Rick. Xilinx sales were $566 million, up 7% sequentially and at the high end of our guidance. We experienced exceptional new product growth during the quarter, driven by our 28-nanometer 7 Series products and 20-nanometer UltraScale products. End market strength was broad based, with communications and Industrial, Aerospace & Defense recovering as anticipated. The Broadcast, Consumer & Automotive category was down slightly driven primarily by automotive, which was impacted by the timing of customer purchases. We expect automotive to post strong growth in the March quarter and to increase by 30% in the full fiscal year '16.
Gross margin was 68.5% for the quarter. In addition to the expected impact of customer mix shift to our larger customers, gross margin was impacted by higher-than-anticipated production ramp costs associated with the aggressive introduction of our new products. Our March quarter guidance incorporates a small impact from these costs.
Operating expenses, including $2 million of amortization expense, were $228 million, slightly lower-than-expected as a result of disciplined spending. Other income was a net expense of $5 million, better than anticipated due primarily to higher investment income. The tax rate for the quarter was 15.6%. There were 2 discrete tax items impacting the rate. There was a $0.03 per share benefit from the retroactive reinstatement of the R&D tax credit and a 5 -- excuse me, $0.05 per share negative impact due to a change in the amount of foreign earnings for which U.S. tax is provided.
Net income for the quarter was $131 million or $0.49 per diluted share. Operating cash flow for the December quarter was $290 million before $6 million in CapEx. Strong cash flow for the quarter was positively impacted by net improvement in working capital driven by a reduction in receivables and inventories. Diluted shares for the quarter were 270 million. There was a 10.6 million share diluted -- dilutive effect from our convertible notes. For questions related to dilution associated with our convertible debt, please visit our Investor Relations website at www.investor.xilinx.com.
We repurchased 2.1 million shares for $100 million during the quarter and paid $80 million in dividends. Let me now comment on the balance sheet.
Cash and investments were $3.6 billion. We have $600 million in convertible debt and $1 billion in fixed-rate debt, resulting in a net cash position of approximately $2 billion. Inventory dollars at Xilinx decreased by $17 million sequentially. We expect inventories to be down again in the March quarter. Let me now turn to discussion of guidance for the March quarter of fiscal year '16. Our backlog heading into the March quarter is up slightly. We are forecasting continued growth in 28-nanometer and 20-nanometer products. We expect communications to be flat with increases in wireless offsetting decreases in wired. Industrial, Aerospace & Defense is forecasted to be down slightly with decreases in IAs offsetting increases in defense.
Lastly, we are expecting consumer, auto and broadcast to be up, driven by automotive, which is forecasted to have a record quarter. As a result, we are expecting total sales to be approximately flat sequentially. The midpoint of this guidance is predicated on turns rate of approximately 48%. Gross margin is expected to be between 68% and 69%. Operating expenses for the March quarter are expected to be approximately $220 million, including $1 million of amortization of acquisition-related intangibles. Other income and expense for the March quarter will be a net expense of $6 million. The share count is expected to be approximately 267 million shares. The tax rate for the March quarter is expected to be between 13% and 14%. The increase in the tax rate forecast is a result of the previously stated changes.
Let me now turn the call over to Moshe.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jon, and good afternoon to you all. I'm very pleased that we delivered a significant growth quarter with revenue hitting the high end of our guidance. Overall, 6 of our 8 end markets grew demonstrating the strength of our highly diversified ant
componenttext:
Thank you, Jon, and good afternoon to you all. I'm very pleased that we delivered a significant growth quarter with revenue hitting the high end of our guidance. Overall, 6 of our 8 end markets grew demonstrating the strength of our highly diversified anti-market portfolio. Particularly, I'm gratified that this growth was driven by an exceptionally strong surge from our new products category, primarily our latest 20-nanometer and 28-nanometer production node, which delivered an 18% sequential quarterly increase. The December quarter 28-nanometer sales grew significantly, obtaining a new record revenue level. 28-nanometer revenue growth benefited from broad-based sales contributions from industrial, broadcast, defense, test and measurements and consumer markets in conjunction with a significant forecasted recovery in the communications markets. The current March quarter, driven again by a majority of our end markets, we expect to repeat this trend and set a new quarterly 28-nanometer revenue record.
Similarly, 20-nanometer revenue in December quarter significantly exceeded the $20 million target we had set last quarter. With no 20-nanometer competition, the Virtex UltraScale high-end family continues to represent the largest percentage of our 20-nanometer sales. Additionally, our Kintex UltraScale family demonstrated significant sales momentum with revenue doubling in the quarter.
Looking forward to the March quarter, driven by many of our end markets and led by test and measurement, defense and consumer, we expect 20-nanometer sales to exceed our new $25 million quarterly target. These business successes, both the 20 and 28 nodes, are being bolstered by the significant milestones we have achieved with our 16-nanometer UltraScale+ family, extending our clear industry and technology leadership.
Since the September quarter, we've already shipped the industry's first 16-nanometer All Programmable MPSoC to tens of customers. This broad customer shipment milestone was achieved a quarter ahead of schedule, enabled by the excellent functionality of our first 16-nanometer silicon. More recently, we received silicon of our 16-nanometer Virtex silicon, which is exhibiting similarly pristine functionality. Consequently, we plan to ship it to customers by the end of January, significantly ahead of our original schedule.
In addition, we taped out 2 additional 16-nanometer devices last quarter, and we fully expect to continue this accelerated ramp of new product taped out throughout fiscal year '17 to build up upon and extend our time-to-market advantage. The silicon leadership position is being complemented on the software front by our enabling broad public access to design tool support the 16-nanometer UltraScale+ family. 
The breakthrough capabilities of the 16-nanometer UltraScale+ product family, coupled with our very significant first-mover advantage, make it uniquely suited for high-growth applications, ranging from next-generation trans-drive resistance, industrial Internet of Things to 5G wireless.
Lastly, following the October announcement of our strategic partnership with Qualcomm for compute acceleration in our base servers, Xilinx and IBM announced a similar collaboration to enable compute acceleration in servers based on the POWER architecture. This collaboration is expected to enable high-performance and energy-efficient FPGA-enabled workload acceleration of rapidly growing applications. Notwithstanding the recent turbulence in the global market, we continue to focus and deliver upon the elements we can control, namely, our total technology execution, our ability to expand the serviceable market, utilizing our leadership portfolio and our emphasis on maximizing shareholder value. 
Now I'll turn the call back to the operator for Q&A.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from William Stein with SunTrust.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from William Stein with SunTrust.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Moshe, I want to address a comment as -- I believe you made on the last quarter call about Xilinx having passed through the bottom and that the company sees growth in the coming quarters. And I think, one of the specific comments was more upside risk than
componenttext: Moshe, I want to address a comment as -- I believe you made on the last quarter call about Xilinx having passed through the bottom and that the company sees growth in the coming quarters. And I think, one of the specific comments was more upside risk than downside risk. Guidance for the next quarter is, I think, seasonal or maybe slightly below that. And I'm wondering if you can give us an update on sort of where you anticipate we are in the cycle, ignoring perhaps what you read in the papers and see in the markets but based more on backlog and customer discussion.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, as you look over the past couple of years, clearly, we had a challenge in terms of our revenue, and what we identified was there were 2 elements -- significant elements which were challenges for us. We're a multi-market company, so we're very
componenttext: Okay. Well, as you look over the past couple of years, clearly, we had a challenge in terms of our revenue, and what we identified was there were 2 elements -- significant elements which were challenges for us. We're a multi-market company, so we're very diversified, and I think that's generally good. But the 2 challenges we had were on the A&D front and on the wireless front. And wireless, depending on the point in time, is typically north of 20% and A&D can be in the mid-teens depending on the cycle. And those 2 markets hit low points. The low point for wireless, we believe, was in the June quarter, and the low point for A&D was in the September quarter. And so those 2 markets, which were a bit of a drag now, we believe, are in recovery mode. And what we're seeing is, generally speaking, on most or all of our markets we're seeing growth isn't linear. So it sort of goes up, goes down a little. But generally speaking, we think the worst is behind us, and we expect to see over the next 2 quarters better results than we have seen in the past. And it's driven by a very strong technology cycle, so it's driven by the 28-nanometer and the 20-nanometer now hitting record revenue. They hit records in the December quarter. We expect them to the prior records in the March quarter. There's sort of impacts of the 14 weeks versus 13 weeks, you could sort of -- we've generally modeled that as between 2% to 3% in terms of benefiting from that this past -- during that obviously won't -- we won't have that in the current March quarter. So we think that what you're seeing is -- regardless of that, you're actually seeing some growth on an apples-to-apples comparison. Beyond March, we're loathe to give predictions, and we're probably going to give predictions on a quarter-by-quarter basis going forward because of the choppiness in the market. So that's sort of the Reader's Digest version. I could spend the whole hour. Hopefully that helped.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's helpful. If I can have one follow-up, please.
componenttext: It's helpful. If I can have one follow-up, please.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure.
componenttext: Sure.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know it's very early days, but with your primary competitor being acquired by Intel, I imagine that over time, there may be differences in competitive dynamics on the one hand, in the data center opportunity and on the other hand, in sort of the long-ta
componenttext: I know it's very early days, but with your primary competitor being acquired by Intel, I imagine that over time, there may be differences in competitive dynamics on the one hand, in the data center opportunity and on the other hand, in sort of the long-tail applications. And I'm wondering if you're seeing any early signs of that or maybe you can perhaps preview what you anticipate from a competitive dynamic perspective in the next few quarters.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, with regards to data center, in particular, it's an emerging market. It's emerging market for everyone. It would be very correct to say that Intel is, by far, the market leader due to their very strong position on high-performance servers, and that
componenttext: Well, with regards to data center, in particular, it's an emerging market. It's emerging market for everyone. It would be very correct to say that Intel is, by far, the market leader due to their very strong position on high-performance servers, and that helps them. And undoubtedly, they will leverage that to help them keep as much as they can of that market. Our expectation is that, notwithstanding that element, there is an expectation of competing solutions coming to market, be they competing architectures. The 2 that are obvious are the ARM and the power ones. But even on the x86 front, we believe that we can provide a lot of the big players in the market a differentiated solution. So no, I believe that, that market, there's growth opportunity for us. I would say that definitely it's a market where Intel has the pole position. It will be foolhardy to state anything other than that with regards to that market in the x86 world. In the non-x86 world, it's sort of ours, by and large. With regard to the other markets I think it's fundamentally driven by the customers looking for who has the best technology solution, which, at this point, as you look at the 28-nanometer and 20 and our position on 16, we clearly have tremendous leadership, and our market share has grown there. We have leadership on the software front, and we clearly have the service demeanor, which is important to this customer -- to customers in these markets. So I think that it's a growth opportunity for us. We don't take anything for granted. We need to continue to deliver leadership and the best support, and our intention is to continue doing that. So that's another rather long answer.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to follow up on the industrial and aerospace segment. Jon, just a clarification of the moving parts within that. I think you talked about that being down as an entire segment, but the A&D side of it being up. Can you talk a little bit about wh
componenttext: Just wanted to follow up on the industrial and aerospace segment. Jon, just a clarification of the moving parts within that. I think you talked about that being down as an entire segment, but the A&D side of it being up. Can you talk a little bit about what you're seeing on the industrial side, OEM versus disti demand and especially given all the uncertainty, macro-wise, industrial data points are very helpful to us.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. In this past quarter, both the Industrial, Aerospace & Defense and test and measurement were all up sequentially. And in the forecast, the guide was to have industrial down, test and measurement down and aerospace and defense, up. So I was just wasn
componenttext: Sure. In this past quarter, both the Industrial, Aerospace & Defense and test and measurement were all up sequentially. And in the forecast, the guide was to have industrial down, test and measurement down and aerospace and defense, up. So I was just wasn't 100% sure of which quarter you were referring to when you made those comments, so I just want to be clear on that. So aerospace and defense, as Moshe pointed out earlier, has -- did bottom out in the September quarter. And we're starting to see strength in that business, particularly in many of the defense areas. The movement and the change and some of the things going on in the budget -- budgetary process is starting to -- we're starting to see some general goodness in terms of programs and emerging things going on there. But most of our business comes from existing programs -- current business comes from existing programs, and we're just seeing a very good -- continued very good penetration of products there. As our -- quite frankly, our 65-nanometer products are growing in that category. As you know, there's a big latency issue relative to the revenue ramp. But we're also seeing really good 28-nanometer growth over and above what we've seen maybe historically for a new product category growing. So I think our strength there is continuing to build and grow for Aerospace & Defense. From a -- and that's a U.S. and European statement more than it is as any other geography from the military perspective. Then in industrial, it's pretty choppy. We're seeing overall growth in industrial from a full-year-to-full-year basis, but by geography, it is kind of up and down. In this particular quarter, this past quarter, we had stronger numbers out of Japan than anywhere else, and everything else was kind of flattish to -- flat to down kind of situation. So it continues to be challenging in China and Asia-Pacific, as well as Europe, where we have a significant string -- set of consumers. So it's not like it's cratering and going down, it's just kind of a very choppy environment for us in industrial.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, that's helpful. If I can sneak in one other -- more housekeeping, there was a -- in the 8-K you put out, along with your results tonight that had a change in control provision, to the extent it's possible, and I know it might be a little bit diffic
componenttext: Great, that's helpful. componenttext: So let me take that, and I actually lost a big bet, but I had expected that to be the first question, to be honest. But thank you of asking it.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, you're fine. So there's very clearly matters of consolidation which is happening in the semiconductor world, and the general expectation is that, that will continue. Having said that, we really don't comment on market speculation or rumors, and there
componenttext: No, you're fine. So there's very clearly matters of consolidation which is happening in the semiconductor world, and the general expectation is that, that will continue. Having said that, we really don't comment on market speculation or rumors, and there have been numerous ones. What we are doing is basically aligning the change in control arrangements for the company's executives management to be in line with those which are common for public companies, both in our industry and actually across industries. And it's just -- it just happened now. It was a result of some feedback we got or the board got from an external consultant that they had engaged to look at these issues. And that was put in place as a result of the recommendations from the external consultants. So that's sort of the entirety of it.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, just a longer-term question. I know you don't or you haven't commented on sort of the long-term growth rate. Now that we're getting towards the end of the year here, can you just talk about your kind of relative expectations for the growth in you
componenttext: I guess, just a longer-term question. I know you don't or you haven't commented on sort of the long-term growth rate. Now that we're getting towards the end of the year here, can you just talk about your kind of relative expectations for the growth in your end markets? And then any sort of operating margin or OpEx goals, and then end of the plan to get to those?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so correct, Chris. So we aren't really giving -- prepared to give any real long-term guidance or longer-term guidance, as Moshe mentioned a little earlier today. But we clearly expect growth next year for us as the strength of our new products overal
componenttext: Yes, so correct, Chris. So we aren't really giving -- prepared to give any real long-term guidance or longer-term guidance, as Moshe mentioned a little earlier today. But we clearly expect growth next year for us as the strength of our new products overall are going to drive us there. We seem to be in such a really strong position, even at the latest generation of product, the 16-nanometer products, vis-Ã -vis competition. We're getting very strong interest and demand, interest from our customers for 20 and 16-nanometer products. And then as we mentioned in Moshe's remarks, the uptake in terms of shipments of samples and early products has been extremely brisk for our customers, which demonstrates a lot of interest. And of course, we're hopeful that those turn into real significant revenue dollars downstream. From a margin perspective, we've been running, kind of bouncing around a little between 68 to 70 bps. Still confident we're in the 68 to 70 range in any sort of near term, plus or minus a few of the things that bumped us up to 70, and now down to 68.5. But I we're solidly in the 68 to 70 range, and we're going to provide more spending guidance at a later point. We really haven't gone through our plan fully and gone through all that entire exercise. So to summarize, I do believe in top-line growth year-on-year for next year and stable margin.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Moshe, you talked about wireless coming back a bit. I'm just curious how much visibility do you guys have into inventories to your customers. And then what you saw last quarter and this quarter seems like more of an inventory normalization. And if so, how
componenttext: Moshe, you talked about wireless coming back a bit. I'm just curious how much visibility do you guys have into inventories to your customers. And then what you saw last quarter and this quarter seems like more of an inventory normalization. And if so, how should we think about where we are in the inventory cycle? And then, can you also talk about what you're seeing geographically in terms of any new rollouts or new developments in wireless?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the biggest rollouts we are currently seeing is the FD rollout in China. We expect that to be significantly smaller than the TV rollout in terms of the length and the number of units. But nonetheless, we see that happening now, and we believe that the
componenttext: So the biggest rollouts we are currently seeing is the FD rollout in China. We expect that to be significantly smaller than the TV rollout in terms of the length and the number of units. But nonetheless, we see that happening now, and we believe that the improvement we're seeing in our wireless business is driven by that. We are waiting for continuing rollouts in India. We do believe that we -- level we had reached at the very bottom of wireless cycle which happened in the June calendar 2014 is behind us, and we're seeing growth beyond that. But we don't see anything short term which will enable us to reach the peak, which I believe was probably in the March 2013 timeframe. I might have the year -- it was a long -- sorry.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: 2014, the March 2014 timeframe. So we don't see anything which will bring us back to that anytime soon. We think that the 5G is a the next big wave. We expect -- we are being designed into all of the prototyping for demonstration of technology of 5G, but
componenttext: 2014, the March 2014 timeframe. So we don't see anything which will bring us back to that anytime soon. We think that the 5G is a the next big wave. We expect -- we are being designed into all of the prototyping for demonstration of technology of 5G, but that is not identical to being in the production vehicles, which are likely to be very significant truthfully in the 2020 timeframe. So everything until 2020 is likely to be of a smaller scale, and the next big surge will be driven by 5G. There will continue to be rolled out of 4G on a worldwide basis, but it's not going to be anything like the previous levels. So wireless is not going to reach that peak of March 2014 anytime soon.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's great. Thanks for that. And then, Jon, again, on the inventory front, I just asked about customer inventories, but also if you can comment on your balance sheet inventories. I think they came down, and you also said that they're going to come
componenttext: Okay, that's great. Thanks for that. And then, Jon, again, on the inventory front, I just asked about customer inventories, but also if you can comment on your balance sheet inventories. I think they came down, and you also said that they're going to come down again in March. And given your optimism about growth for next year, I'm somewhat surprised that inventories are coming down. If you could shed some light on that, that would be helpful.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Quite a few quarters ago, we had built up our inventory intentionally for 2 reasons. One is, we thought we saw some stronger demand in -- particularly in FD coming at us, and we thought the foundry was pretty tight in terms of their ability to supply
componenttext: Yes. Quite a few quarters ago, we had built up our inventory intentionally for 2 reasons. One is, we thought we saw some stronger demand in -- particularly in FD coming at us, and we thought the foundry was pretty tight in terms of their ability to supply us. And then we had 6 quarters of down revenue. And so essentially what I'm saying is we built up too much inventory, and we've been bleeding it off. So yes, we did go down quite a bit this quarter, and we expect to go down again the next quarter. We'll be a much closer to our desired model by the time we get to next quarter. So this is really getting us back to model, which is more of the 90 to 100 day kind of range. That's the general target. Of course, that fluctuates depending on where we in new product ramp capability. But this shouldn't be viewed as some sort of a cautionary signal. This is really about getting inventory back into historic model after we had built it up in -- about 1.5 years ago.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
