componenttext: Yes, so generally, Europe, I talked about automotive being down as being a customer timing issue. Automotive was certainly a driver. That's one of our -- where some of our largest automotive customers are. But I think, in general, we've been looking -- looking at wireless, it was down there in Europe as well as industrial as part of that industrial conversation I had previously. So I think we do expect Europe to bounce back some next quarter, particularly with a much stronger automotive revenue expected.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, thanks for that. And then the team has done, obviously, a solid job on driving 28-nanometer and 20-nanometer new products. On the competitive front, since your competitor has been in the midst of being acquired, we've not really heard much in the w
componenttext: Great, thanks for that. And then the team has done, obviously, a solid job on driving 28-nanometer and 20-nanometer new products. On the competitive front, since your competitor has been in the midst of being acquired, we've not really heard much in the way of their 14-nanometer program or product family. You guys are obviously out there with your 16-nanometer products and getting some good early traction. Is the Xilinx team seeing the 14-nanometer products yet from your competitor in any competitive engagements?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Harlan, we haven't seen them, and we haven't seen any announcement from them. This sort of goes and contradicts the commitments that have being made to ship a long time ago. I think that this indicates that the fact that we taped out in June of last year,
componenttext: Harlan, we haven't seen them, and we haven't seen any announcement from them. This sort of goes and contradicts the commitments that have being made to ship a long time ago. I think that this indicates that the fact that we taped out in June of last year, got silicon back in September, because silicon is very, very functional that we have a tremendous lead, and we already have. Now the Virtex side, which we expect to tape-out -- sorry, we expect to sample customers. We've seen the silicon, and again, it is in great shape. And what we're going to do is we're starting to turn the crank, and there will be a large marker of tape-out to 16-nanometer devices because we do believe we have at least a significant time-to-market leadership at this node.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean typically what would happen, Moshe talked about tens of -- customers shipping the 16-nanometer product to UltraScale+. Typically, what would is, happen is, there might be a bake-off between us and our competitor, et cetera. And at this point, we do
componenttext: I mean typically what would happen, Moshe talked about tens of -- customers shipping the 16-nanometer product to UltraScale+. Typically, what would is, happen is, there might be a bake-off between us and our competitor, et cetera. And at this point, we don't have any consumer telling us there's a bake-off going on. So that leads us to believe there are no product -- there are no parts out there, but of course, we're not the center of all knowledge there. But once -- we haven't seen any, as Moshe said.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Chris Rolland with FBR.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Chris Rolland with FBR.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: You guys mentioned a potential downtick in wired comms next quarter. Perhaps you can elaborate on what you guys are seeing there, and how you kind of view this market longer term?
componenttext: You guys mentioned a potential downtick in wired comms next quarter. Perhaps you can elaborate on what you guys are seeing there, and how you kind of view this market longer term?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We had quite a bit of growth this quarter in the wired communications area. It was both, I would say, core wired communications as well as data center, in particular, both data acceleration. But in a big way, also some of the storage -- solid-state storag
componenttext: We had quite a bit of growth this quarter in the wired communications area. It was both, I would say, core wired communications as well as data center, in particular, both data acceleration. But in a big way, also some of the storage -- solid-state storage. And so that -- sometimes those customers buy a lot and then absorb, and buy a lot and absorb. And really, the down is more related to the customer absorption in some of those cases than it is to any other trend. What we are seeing a very strong uptake of new products in wired communications. If you stripped out older products and just looked at the ramp of new products, new 28-nanometers and newer, you would see a very nice ramp in wired communications and growth next quarter in new products as well. So this is kind of a timing issue more than it is a trend.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Thank you. And then not too much discussion on auto in the quarter. Maybe that paused, I don't know. And then as we look at the ADAS market more specifically, did you guys pick up any new guys there, Tier 1s, OEMs? I would love some color the
componenttext: Okay, great. Thank you. And then not too much discussion on auto in the quarter. Maybe that paused, I don't know. And then as we look at the ADAS market more specifically, did you guys pick up any new guys there, Tier 1s, OEMs? I would love some color there. And just for your ARM products more generally, auto and everything, what percentage of revenue would you say are actually associated with -- or have a ARM core in them?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So they're was a lot of -- that's quite a few questions. So our -- overall, automotive business continues to be very strong. Europe, year-to-year, full year growth, definitely '16 over '15 at 30%. That growth is coming primarily from ADAS applications. Ou
componenttext: So they're was a lot of -- that's quite a few questions. So our -- overall, automotive business continues to be very strong. Europe, year-to-year, full year growth, definitely '16 over '15 at 30%. That growth is coming primarily from ADAS applications. Our traditional businesses around entertainment, it's stable, still is doing well. Relative to the growth of new applications, I don't know that we have any new public -- something I can say publicly relative to new platforms that have joined. But we had -- there were ordinary design wins in the quarter in automotive, but I'm just not at liberty to provide the name of the ultimate manufacturer at this point in time. We are seeing the designs we have won ramp very strongly, and those -- again, the ADAS application being the biggest driver of growth. There is a growing percentage of that ADAS that has an our ARM core in it. In some cases, we end up having more simple applications, just straight FPGAs in there. But the ARM core is growing very dramatically. So if you say that we talked last quarter about a 50 -- about 50% of our revenue from automotive was ADAS-related, I would say at least 1/2 of that is associated with some level of ARM core, and that will be growing over time.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And your next question comes from the line of David Long with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And your next question comes from the line of David Long with Wells Fargo.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: In which applications are you seeing the most initial interest currently for 16-nanometer product?
componenttext: In which applications are you seeing the most initial interest currently for 16-nanometer product?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, well, there is quite a lot of them because it's a broad product offering. So there's the MPSoC, which is basically our base product. And then there's the Kintex and the Virtex derivatives. So if you look at the ones which I think are the most signi
componenttext: David, well, there is quite a lot of them because it's a broad product offering. So there's the MPSoC, which is basically our base product. And then there's the Kintex and the Virtex derivatives. So if you look at the ones which I think are the most significant ones at this point, it's the next-generation ADAS that goes beyond the 28-nanometer zinc. [ph] It's the industrial control, and we do expect this to be used very broadly for the 5G wireless, at least, for the prototyping versions. Whereas in the 2020 timeframe, it's more likely to go into full-fledged production with the 7-nanometer. So those are 3 target markets which are driving the design wins in the 16-nanometer. But reality is, it's a very broad node, so I'm probably doing a disservice to the others and just sort of mentioning [indiscernible].

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Romit Shah from Nomura.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Romit Shah from Nomura.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Moshe, you mentioned earlier partnerships with IBM on open-power servers using their CPUs and as well with Qualcomm using their server CPUs. And I'm curious, how much interest are you guys seeing from web and cloud providers to deploy these chips?
componenttext: Moshe, you mentioned earlier partnerships with IBM on open-power servers using their CPUs and as well with Qualcomm using their server CPUs. And I'm curious, how much interest are you guys seeing from web and cloud providers to deploy these chips?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The same tremendous interest, because as I said, this is an emerging market. This is a market where performance per watt is one of the -- is the most important parameter, and our All Programmable solutions can actually put a huge dent in improving that fo
componenttext: The same tremendous interest, because as I said, this is an emerging market. This is a market where performance per watt is one of the -- is the most important parameter, and our All Programmable solutions can actually put a huge dent in improving that for a broad range of applications. Now these tend to be, at this point, very large players who are very autonomous and control their software environment, so it's not a PC-type environment where control is in the hands of a Microsoft, right? It's actually, if you look at the big players, the Amazons, Googles, the Chinese equivalents, they absolutely control their environment, and they are driven by the efficacy of their -- the power footprint of their data center. That's why this is viewed as such an interesting and compelling opportunity going forward. Now there's a lot of excitement about this now. This is a market which is starting to evolve, and it has several years to grow. So we've expected to be significant 5 years from now, and I just want to make sure that everyone understands that. At least from our perspective, that's where it will start having the biggest impact. That doesn't mean there won't be deployments before that, but in terms of being a significant portion of our revenue, then it's 5 years away.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And is the partnership with Qualcomm exclusive? Or do you have the ability to partner with other ARM server suppliers?
componenttext: And is the partnership with Qualcomm exclusive? Or do you have the ability to partner with other ARM server suppliers?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have a very close relationship with Qualcomm, but it's not an exclusive one on our behalf. And fundamentally, we can connect with whoever is developing a solution, whether it's x86, whether it's power based, or whether it's ARM based. And we can
componenttext: Well, we have a very close relationship with Qualcomm, but it's not an exclusive one on our behalf. And fundamentally, we can connect with whoever is developing a solution, whether it's x86, whether it's power based, or whether it's ARM based. And we can help accelerate all of those, and you can rest assured that we're in the midst of working with all of them. But the ones we have announced, we have now a very deep relationship with, and we're working towards enabling their products when they have the equivalent CPUs and board systems for those environments. But it's more than just the 2 that we have announced.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then, Jon, can I just ask quickly? My impression is that revenue growth in June and September have traditionally been weaker than December and March, and is that your impression as well? And is there a seasonal component there?
componenttext: Okay, and then, Jon, can I just ask quickly? My impression is that revenue growth in June and September have traditionally been weaker than December and March, and is that your impression as well? And is there a seasonal component there?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, if you look back at our pattern, it has changed from time to time. And last year, I think that was -- I mean, we had down every quarter, so it's hard to pick that pattern of -- out of that, but -- and we're not prepared to talk about the June -- the
componenttext: Yes, if you look back at our pattern, it has changed from time to time. And last year, I think that was -- I mean, we had down every quarter, so it's hard to pick that pattern of -- out of that, but -- and we're not prepared to talk about the June -- the June quarter right now, Romit. We'll have to wait until the next earnings release.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ian Ing with MKM Partners.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ian Ing with MKM Partners.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you talk about scenarios to get gross margins back to the high end of the range? You know, 70%, is it the production ramp costs of going away after March? Or does mix really need to turn more favorable here?
componenttext: Could you talk about scenarios to get gross margins back to the high end of the range? You know, 70%, is it the production ramp costs of going away after March? Or does mix really need to turn more favorable here?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, our goal is to operate in the 68% to 70%, and we're comfortable with that. So we're not actually going to have programs that are specific to have that target because we're obviously focused on adding the most value to the company in total on the op
componenttext: Again, our goal is to operate in the 68% to 70%, and we're comfortable with that. So we're not actually going to have programs that are specific to have that target because we're obviously focused on adding the most value to the company in total on the operating margin dollar line. But from a mix perspective, I mean, one of the bigger impacts that we had forecasted for this quarter was the fact that we knew we were going to be returning to a richer, large customer mix that tends to buy in volume and, therefore, has better pricing as a result of that. There was also some end-market characteristics, where we were at a low point for aerospace and defense, and that builds -- that will counteract some of the large customer impact. So I guess, if you're looking for a scenario that drives margin up is, large customers, except aerospace and defense customers. But again, we're not -- we're trying to add total dollars to the bottom line. That's the goal.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Hans Mosesmann with Raymond James.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Hans Mosesmann with Raymond James.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Moshe, just to go back on the aggressive ramp of new products this year, is that a result of just faster-than-expected yield improvements at your foundry? Or are you being opportunistic to kind of take advantage of an opportunity versus the competition? W
componenttext: Moshe, just to go back on the aggressive ramp of new products this year, is that a result of just faster-than-expected yield improvements at your foundry? Or are you being opportunistic to kind of take advantage of an opportunity versus the competition? What exactly is driving that? Or is it just customer demand?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's basically driven by new technology and the maturity of the new technology. And typically what happens when we start with the new process node, then we tape out one version, and then we go through an extensive debug cycle. And once we have the d
componenttext: Well, it's basically driven by new technology and the maturity of the new technology. And typically what happens when we start with the new process node, then we tape out one version, and then we go through an extensive debug cycle. And once we have the debug done, then we can start turning the crank. What has happened is the level of functionality was so high on the initial silicon that we actually could sample it to customers, and we could almost immediately start taping out the other versions. And so the answer to your question is, we're basically exploiting the high quality of the engineering execution and it behooves us to capitalize on that because now as we take -- tape-out all of the other versions, we expect to extend our market leadership in terms of breadth of products and in terms of being -- having first-mover advantage. So it's that element which we're capitalizing on, and it will manifest itself with tape-out -- more tape-outs happening faster than we had expected, which is good news because there's more products out.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Does that change -- as a follow up, does that change the timing of the tape-out of 7-nanometer?
componenttext: Great. Does that change -- as a follow up, does that change the timing of the tape-out of 7-nanometer?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. No, it doesn't. Because it means -- it probably means that we will tape-out more versions on 16 to exploit the maturity of it, but it doesn't mean that we'll do 7-nanometer earlier, because in our industry, the customers can only absorb the technology
componenttext: No. No, it doesn't. Because it means -- it probably means that we will tape-out more versions on 16 to exploit the maturity of it, but it doesn't mean that we'll do 7-nanometer earlier, because in our industry, the customers can only absorb the technology at a certain rate. And we believe that on average, every 2.5 years to have a new node is the optimal time for their capacity to use a new technology, and it also helps us contain our costs. Otherwise, we'll just be burning money on tape-outs ahead of when the customers can use them. So we're still planning on 7-nanometer tape-out in the 2017 -- calendar 2017 timeframe, generally speaking.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tristan Gerra with Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tristan Gerra with Baird.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: You had said in the past that 28-nanometer will be larger node from a revenue standpoint than 20. Do you still expect that based on the response that you're seeing from customers? And most -- so assuming that based on your 5G commentary, 16-nanometer's re
componenttext: You had said in the past that 28-nanometer will be larger node from a revenue standpoint than 20. Do you still expect that based on the response that you're seeing from customers? And most -- so assuming that based on your 5G commentary, 16-nanometer's revenue is expected to be larger than the peak you expect at 28?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So we absolutely expect 28-nanometer due to the richness of the product offering and the cost point that it's at and the customer needs to be a long-lasting node, and likely to be the largest node, at least up to this point, in the industry. And we
componenttext: Okay. So we absolutely expect 28-nanometer due to the richness of the product offering and the cost point that it's at and the customer needs to be a long-lasting node, and likely to be the largest node, at least up to this point, in the industry. And we don't expect 16 or 20 to approach that. We do expect the 16 and 20 together to be generally in that sort of size. But the 2 together, not any 1 of them separately. And the 28-nanometer, as I said, had a record revenue this quarter. We expect it to have a record revenue -- that was December. We expect it to have another record revenue in the March quarter. And we -- actually, I wouldn't be surprised if it becomes our all-time highest-record product in terms of quarterly revenue shipments sometime for the next 12 months, and overtakes everything else in terms of that. And what we're seeing is that we expect it to continue to grow, albeit at a slower rate, over the next few years. And it has several years until it actually hits its peak. So that's the story on 28-nanometer for us. 16, we expect to be a very strong node too, but not as a strong as 28.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And not to confuse anything -- or anything that Moshe just said, but we are kind of living on a multi-technology product family situation now. We've just -- in the last couple of quarters, we've announced the Spartan-7 product line, which is the 28-nanome
componenttext: And not to confuse anything -- or anything that Moshe just said, but we are kind of living on a multi-technology product family situation now. We've just -- in the last couple of quarters, we've announced the Spartan-7 product line, which is the 28-nanometer technology. And so we're extending -- using all their technologies to extend low end and improve upon the low end of the FPGA market, where our 20 and 16-nanometer aren't as economical for us to go. So when you start looking at the growth of the company and then the long-term situation, it is going to be a multi-node kind of product family rollouts as we keep going in order cover all the different price points in the spaces we're going to be in.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Vivek Arya with Bank of America.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Vivek Arya with Bank of America.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question, Moshe, is on the long-term growth for the PLD industry. If I look over the last 3, 5, or even 10 years, the top-line growth for the industry has sort of being flattish despite a lot of penetration in new markets. I understand the volatility i
componenttext: My question, Moshe, is on the long-term growth for the PLD industry. If I look over the last 3, 5, or even 10 years, the top-line growth for the industry has sort of being flattish despite a lot of penetration in new markets. I understand the volatility in the communications and the aerospace market, but that's not going away anytime soon, and that's over half of the sales in this industry. So just the very basic fundamental question is, what's going to be different over the next 3, 4 years to create growth in this industry?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, I mean, that's a profound question. And I agree with your comments on it -- we have been disappointed vis-Ã -vis growth over the past few years. I think, as a result, there's a point in time where the general expectation was that you could del
componenttext: Okay. Well, I mean, that's a profound question. And I agree with your comments on it -- we have been disappointed vis-Ã -vis growth over the past few years. I think, as a result, there's a point in time where the general expectation was that you could deliver and sustain double-digit growth, and we're -- we believe that, that is unlikely. That you know it could happen, but it's unlikely to be the compound annual growth rate. So we're talking about single-digit growth. Even that, we obviously still need to deliver. And as John indicated, we do expect fiscal year '17 to be a growth year. On the general question, which we'll try to answer probably a little better at our Analyst Day, the point that I would like to make is that, except with high volume -- very high-volume markets, ASICs and ASSPs, and this is no longer a wet dream, right, this is documented, known and happening, and has happened over the past few years of becoming less and less viable. And that opens a serviceable market, and it requires the right silicone, and it requires the right software. And if we move forward and we continue to move forward with -- and being at the leading edge, there's less and less to compete with. And if we have the right silicone, we have the right level of integration, and we can enable a broader set of customers to use our technology, we should be able to benefit from that. That's sort of the very high-level answer. I'd love to give you a more profound answer, but that isn't something we can do now. We will try to address it a little better during our Analyst Day and explain what we're doing in order to exploit the opportunities. And amongst other things, just a snippet is, if you look at the ARM product line, that enables us to service a market, which up to when it was available, we couldn't even touch, right? And that's the ASSP market. And we've gone from -- to it already being approaching 20% of our revenue in the U.S. node, right, and that just sort of shows you that it's an expansion play. We'll try and give more examples when explaining that in the future.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very quickly, could you help -- Moshe, help us quantify your -- how large is your data center and your automotive business today?
componenttext: Very quickly, could you help -- Moshe, help us quantify your -- how large is your data center and your automotive business today?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll let Jon give you the official answer there -- or not give you the answer.
componenttext: I'll let Jon give you the official answer there -- or not give you the answer.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I actually don't have the data center information, so I don't -- we don't spend a -- we don't track that as a separate sub on a routine basis. And our automotive business has been running in the 7% range, I would say on a -- if you look at it over a broad
componenttext: I actually don't have the data center information, so I don't -- we don't spend a -- we don't track that as a separate sub on a routine basis. And our automotive business has been running in the 7% range, I would say on a -- if you look at it over a broad spectrum of quarters.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And that's double where it was a few years ago, so it has grown.
componenttext: Yes. And that's double where it was a few years ago, so it has grown.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Blayne Curtis with Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Blayne Curtis with Barclays.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're talking about turning the crank on 16, and are you adding any more products? Or is it just a pull-in in terms of the timing? And I know you're not giving fiscal year '17 guidance, but how does that impact the shape OpEx?
componenttext: You're talking about turning the crank on 16, and are you adding any more products? Or is it just a pull-in in terms of the timing? And I know you're not giving fiscal year '17 guidance, but how does that impact the shape OpEx?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't have the numbers, but obviously, it's the right thing to do, right? Because we have leadership, and there is market demand. It would be foolhardy not to exploit that. And we'll give you those numbers when we get to giving the fiscal year '17 numb
componenttext: We don't have the numbers, but obviously, it's the right thing to do, right? Because we have leadership, and there is market demand. It would be foolhardy not to exploit that. And we'll give you those numbers when we get to giving the fiscal year '17 numbers. At this point, what we want to make sure is that we exploit the breadth of the opportunity there, and we're just accelerating the existing roadmap to provide it at an earlier point than we had expected before. There might be an option to actually also provide better coverage, but at this point, it's the former as opposed to the latter.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, but I just wanted to go back out to a prior question on the wireless segment. Is there a way to distinguish whether it's a recovery in inventory? Or are you actually seeing the end market pick up? And then you talked about an average of 20% of rev
componenttext: Thanks, but I just wanted to go back out to a prior question on the wireless segment. Is there a way to distinguish whether it's a recovery in inventory? Or are you actually seeing the end market pick up? And then you talked about an average of 20% of revenue, and not being able to get back to a prior peak, but average of 20%. Is that a good goal that this business could get back to a 20% revenue?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, I think that's a pretty reasonable play -- number, I mean, just a plus or minus a reasonable arrow bar there. I think what Moshe was trying to communicate was that the very large buildup in the overall 4G global network, we have passed that
componenttext: Well, I mean, I think that's a pretty reasonable play -- number, I mean, just a plus or minus a reasonable arrow bar there. I think what Moshe was trying to communicate was that the very large buildup in the overall 4G global network, we have passed that stage of the life-cycle of 4G, even though we continue to get a lot of long-tail business, even from geographies that are more fully deployed like North America, for example, because of capacitization [ph] of the network adding on, et cetera. And the situation and the best that we can see in China is they're building FD base stations. We've been told they're deployed, but as you know, the last time we learned -- we were told those kinds of things it turned out they weren't all fully deployed and there were a lot of buildup in the warehouses. As best as we can tell, it is moving through the manufacturing line, and out of the warehouses and being deployed. And it is going to be a couple of quarters of good business. And yes, there was some replenishment of inventory going on this quarter, but we also see some growth next quarter in the wireless business. And some of that is related to the China market as well.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your last question comes from the line of John Pitzer with CrÃ©dit Suisse.
componenttext: Your last question comes from the line of John Pitzer with CrÃ©dit Suisse.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick ones. First one's housekeeping. Jon, now that the quarter's over, can you just level set us on what you think the extra week added to both revenue and OpEx in the December quarter? And then, Moshe, I think this question might have been partia
componenttext: Just 2 quick ones. First one's housekeeping. Jon, now that the quarter's over, can you just level set us on what you think the extra week added to both revenue and OpEx in the December quarter? And then, Moshe, I think this question might have been partially answered with Blayne's question, but when you think about getting wireless back to prior peak, it sounds like that's more commentary on the overall CapEx cycle and inventory cycle and not the PLD opportunity set within base stations. And I wonder if you can just comment a little bit on kind of what you think the content on PLD was supposed to be and how that's sort of playing out through the 4G cycle?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So relative to your first question on the impact, we had estimated a couple of a percent, 2% or 3% kind of -- in the last call, and that's exactly where it turned out. The last 2 weeks of the quarter were, for us, the -- week 13 and week 14 were quite mut
componenttext: So relative to your first question on the impact, we had estimated a couple of a percent, 2% or 3% kind of -- in the last call, and that's exactly where it turned out. The last 2 weeks of the quarter were, for us, the -- week 13 and week 14 were quite muted on an individual basis. And when you add those 2 together, it ends up being around a 2% or 3% kind of a positive impact as a result of having that extra week. Of course, we get to spend -- that would give all the extra spending in as well in that quarter. And then your second version was around the peak. Moshe, you want to answer?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So what we see is the continuing opportunity and actually a growing opportunity for FPGA content in wireless. We're seeing the number of players who can effectively design ASICs, which is the other option, because there really isn't a viable ASSP sol
componenttext: Yes. So what we see is the continuing opportunity and actually a growing opportunity for FPGA content in wireless. We're seeing the number of players who can effectively design ASICs, which is the other option, because there really isn't a viable ASSP solution at this point in time. We don't see that happening anytime soon. So it's ASIC versus FPGAs. We're seeing less and less players with the capacity to do that. And so the role of FPGAs' growth and with each generation, generally speaking, the average ASP per system is a little higher. It doesn't reflect the much-larger role the FPGA has in the system, so it's an integration play. We replaced a lot of other components. We have more major part, but the ASP does not go up at the same level to reflect the value the FPGA provides. But generally speaking, it's one of those markets, where the role of the FPGA continues to grow. And the major competition is the very, very, very few, and actually diminished number of players who can design ASIC alternatives. And that number continues, with each generation of product, to go lower and lower.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016

componenttext:
Thanks for joining us today. We have a playback of this call beginning at 5:00 p.m. Pacific Time, 8:00 p.m Eastern Time today. For a copy of our earnings release, please visit our IR website. 
This quarter, we will be presenting at the Goldman Sachs Technology and Internet Conference in San Francisco on February 9. 
This completes our call. Thank you very much for your participation.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and my name is Skinner, and I'll be your conference operator. I would like to welcome everyone to the Xilinx's Fourth Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]I would now like to turn the call over to R
componenttext:
Good day, and my name is Skinner, and I'll be your conference operator. I would like to welcome everyone to the Xilinx's Fourth Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]
I would now like to turn the call over to Rick Muscha. Thank you. Mr. Muscha, you may begin your conference.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; Jon Olson, CFO; and Lourenco Floris VP of Finance and Corporate Controller. As we announced in February, Jon will be retiring in May, with Lourenco succeeding him as CFO. Jon will continue t
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; Jon Olson, CFO; and Lourenco Floris VP of Finance and Corporate Controller. As we announced in February, Jon will be retiring in May, with Lourenco succeeding him as CFO. Jon will continue to support the transition through July. Jon and Moshe will provide a financial and business review of the March quarter, and fiscal 2016. Moshe will add a high level the perspective on fiscal 2017 and Lourenco will follow at June quarter in FY '17 guidance. We look forward to providing you more details at our upcoming analyst day on May 23rd.
Let me remind everyone that during our conference call today, we may make projections or other forward-looking statements regarding future events or the future financial performance of the company.  We wish to caution you that such statements are predictions based on information that is currently available, and that actual results may differ materially. We refer you to the documents the company files with the SEC, including our 10-Ks, 10-Qs and 8-Ks. These documents contain and identify important risk factors that could cause the actual results to differ materially from those contained in our projections or forward-looking statements. This conference call is open to all, and is being webcast live. It can be accessed from our Xilinx Investor Relations website.
Let me now turn the call over to Jon.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rick. Fiscal year '16 is another profitable year for Xilinx, although revenue did not meet our expectations going into the year. Revenue was $2.2 billion for the year, down 7% from last year but strengthening throughout FY '16. Gross margin rem
componenttext:
Thank you, Rick. Fiscal year '16 is another profitable year for Xilinx, although revenue did not meet our expectations going into the year. Revenue was $2.2 billion for the year, down 7% from last year but strengthening throughout FY '16. Gross margin remains strong through the year, averaging 69.7% as our pricing and cost management efforts continue to have a positive impact.
Operating margin exceeded 30% based on these margin management efforts and prudent spending. Professional margin was 33%, the same as last year. Though our lower revenues contributed to lower operating cash flow of $730 million. We repurchased 9.7 million shares for $423 million and paid $390 million in dividends, a total return of $761 million. This is the second straight year we have returned over 100% of cash flow and another straight year of dividend increase.
Turning now to a discussion of the fourth quarter. Xilinx sales were 571 [indiscernible] up 1% as new products continue to grow and we saw stabilizing trends across our end markets segments.
Communications was flat with the small growth in wireless offsetting a small decline in wired. Industrial and MD was down slightly with strengthened Aerospace & Defense, offsetting declines in [indiscernible] measurement. Broadcast consumer automotive grew 6% powered by another record quarter in automotive, demonstrating our strength in ASSPs.
Gross margin in Q4 was 69.2%, higher than last quarter and higher than expected due to the mix of customers and products in addition to lower products and expenses. We continued to aggressively manage both the pricing and cost sides of gross margin.
Operating expense at $270 million were slightly lower than our guidance. A reminder here that a significant part of the decline from Q3 was due to the 14th week in our Q3. The increase in revenue gross margin and lower operating expense drove an increase of more than 10% in operating income for the quarter up to $178 million.
Other income and expense was an expense of $8 million, higher than forecasted, due to and equity investment write off. The tax rate was 14.6% for the quarter.
Our net income for Q4 was $126 million or $0.54 per share. Operating cash flow was $127 million, down from last quarter, primarily due to an increase in accounts receivables. Diluted shares were $268 million or 1 million shares, including 10.5 million shares from the convertible. During the quarter, we repurchased 3 million shares for $143 million that we paid $80 million in dividends.
Now turning to the balance sheet. We ended the year with $3.6 billion in gross cash and $2 billion a net cash after our debt. As mentioned above, we saw an increase in accounts receivable to $307 million, this is entirely due to the timing of customer shipments in the quarter and we see no credit or accountability issues.
Inventory was $179 million, down from $17 million from the prior quarter and down $52 million from the beginning of the year as we continue to manage inventory down.
Let me now turn the call over to Moshe.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jon. I'm very pleased with both the financial and operating results for the fourth quarter. Our revenue has rebounded to its highest level in over a year by expanding the growth momentum which started in the fiscal third quarter. As Jon discuss
componenttext:
Thank you, Jon. I'm very pleased with both the financial and operating results for the fourth quarter. Our revenue has rebounded to its highest level in over a year by expanding the growth momentum which started in the fiscal third quarter. As Jon discussed, both profitability and cash flow remains robust throughout the entire year, reflecting our strong business model.
Our execution on the 28-, 20- and 16-nanometer nodes has been exceptional. The realignment driven in our sales organization is leading stronger customer relationships and expanding our reach. We are confident this will translate into revenue growth for both market share gain and market expansion, following some achievement which illustrate the strength of our position.
Our product leadership has translated to 4 points of PLD market share gains over the past 5 years. In the fourth quarter of fiscal year '16, we delivered record sales on the 28-nanometer node and expect to set a significant new record in the June quarter.
Our 20-nanometer family approached $100 million in revenue in fiscal year '16, both significantly exceeding our target in all 4 quarters of fiscal year '16. We expect to ship well over $30 million of 20-nanometer product in the June quarter.
In a successful demonstration of our market expansion effort, revenue from our Zynq product line more than doubled in fiscal year '16. Zynq is particularly strong in the automotive, wireless and industrial market. For example, our automotive business has grown over 60% over the past 2 years, driven by employment of advanced driver systems applications and over 60 automobile models.
At the 16-nanometer node, we have delivered all 3 UltraScale + product family ahead of schedule and already shipped 6 unique products to several types of customers. Our 1 year-plus leadership in 16-nanometer product has generated multi-$100 million design wins on customer platforms, which in the past have traditionally been speed base. We have established data-centric partnership and data-centric acceleration initiatives with both IBM and Qualcomm, and now deeply engaged with multiple hyper-scale data center customers.
Lastly, we completed the rollout of the SDx family of software defined development environment. This is a key capability to significantly expanding our user base beyond traditional PLD designers to a much larger community systems and software engineers.
We finished fiscal year '16 with undisputed product leadership in the silicon, software and IP fronts. Very welcomed session in multiple markets coupled with much deeper engagement with key customers and partners. Our excellent execution could not have come to a more opportune time. The consolidation and semiconductor industry is leading to rationalization and elimination of competing product lines at both traditional ASIC and ASSPs companies. This phenomenon has opened up new growth opportunities for Xilinx is vendor of choice for new customers. This is a carpe diem opportunity. The time is right for us to capitalize on the 3 successive generation of leadership to expand our market position. We intend to do this by simultaneously pursuing on the following forefront. On the 16-nanometer UltraScale+ front due to its excellent software and pristine silicon functionality, we have elected to both accelerate our current lead plan 16-nanometer and expand original product portfolio. These multi-market 16-nanometer products complements our successful 20-nanometer family with its estimated 80% market share. The address each revenue growth opportunities in the data center market are tailored for the first wave of 5G deployments in the 2018 timeframe while positioning us for longer-term massive 5G deployments. After that, serve the automotive market and form a basis for expanding our platform wins in industrial Internet of Things.
Similarly, we are executing on our plans to deliver our 7-nanometer product offering. This capitalizes on our extremely tight relationship with our absolutely outstanding foundry partner, TSMC, to satisfy the advanced technology needs of our leading edge customers. This is another pillar of our sound expansion strategy. And parallel, we are committed to providing our customers with an attractive high volume [indiscernible] 7 family. This family would be implemented in 20-nanometer and will expand on our market position in the price-sensitive parts of the market. On the software front, we have enabled market expansion by breakout and integration and programming models targeted to high-growth segment driven by cloud computing, vision processing, including but not limited to industrial Internet of Things and 5G. Our plans for fiscal year '17 while aggressive, are based on the financial principles we have consistently demonstrated. We are committed to continue to investment prudently to preserve and extend our market position while delivering longer-term a 30%-plus operating margin and preserving our commitment to return cash to our shareholders.
Before I turn the call over to Lourenco who will discuss the financial guidance for Q1 for the rest of fiscal year '17. I would like to give this opportunity to personally thank Jon for his 11 years of extremely significant contribution and exemplary partnering for Xilinx. [indiscernible]

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Moshe. And I also would like to thank Jon, specifically for the leadership function over the past 11 years. Moshe has established the opportunity for Xilinx and now, I want to provide you all with the financial guidance aligned to our taking ad
componenttext:
Thank you, Moshe. And I also would like to thank Jon, specifically for the leadership function over the past 11 years. Moshe has established the opportunity for Xilinx and now, I want to provide you all with the financial guidance aligned to our taking advantage of that opportunity.
Starting with Q1. Revenue will be approximately flat. We entered the quarter with backlog down slightly and are expecting turns to be about 49%. We expect new products to continue to grow with 28-nanometer growing to a new record and 20-nanometer exceeding $30 million.
With respect to end markets, communications and data center growth were offset a decline in industrial and AMD. Communications and data center growth reflects a continued ramp of our customers wire designs and a near-term firming in wireless. The decline in industrial and AMD is primarily due to program timing in AMD. Broadcast automotive and consumer will be down slightly, reflecting a small inventory cycle in automotive and a small decline in broadcast. Our gross margin will be between 69% and 70%, and our operating expense will be approximately $220 million, including $1 million of amortization. Other income and expense will be an expense of $5 million, and our tax rate is expected to be 14%. Share count is expected to be $266 million.
As we move into the discussion of our full year guidance, I want to remind the audience that we have our Analyst Day on the 23rd of May in Boston. While I expect there will be questions on the full year guidance, we will give further details at our Analyst Day.
First, on revenue. We see actual revenue growth to be in the range of 48%. This will be driven by growth and communications and data center and Broadcast, Consumer & Automotive and to a lesser degree, by industrial in AMD. Within communications and data center, all end markets will show growth including wireless as it is recovered from the low points in FY '16. In Broadcast, Consumer & Automotive we expect automotive to continue to grow strongly, although at a reduced rate, with the other end markets showing some growth. In industrial and AMD, the overall growth of the segment will be mitigated by program timing factors in AMD, although the underlying business in AMD remains healthy. We see the growth of our overall business weighted into the second half of the fiscal year.
For gross margin we expect to remain in the range of 68% to 70%. Our price and cost management efforts will continue to support our gross margin, though we expect some pressure from product ramp expenses in cost per mix through the year.
For the past few years, we have been deliberately increasing our relative emphasis on R&D while extracting efficiency from SG&A. This has provided the resourcing for the execution we have seen on 28-, 20- and now 16-nanometer, and has put us in the advantageous position OSHA has described. We are continuing that approach with an investment level and focus consistent with addressing the opportunity we see in front of us. In order to capitalize on and extend our market position, operating expenses expected to grow 7% to 9% with almost all of the growth being in research and development. This growth provides the expansion of our leadership position with a 28-nanometer Spartan 7, significant increases in other expenses to accelerate our lead in 16-nanometer and our leading 7-nanometer product developer. Other income and expense will decline slightly through the year from the $5 million quarterly level in the first quarter. This will mean that we will see approximately half the expense we saw in fiscal year '16, a significant improvement driven by last year's interest rate increases and a small anticipated increase in interest rate in FY '17.
Our tax rate is expected to be approximately 14%.
With the growth in revenue and the operating assumptions I've described, we anticipate low-single digit growth in earnings per share in fiscal year '17.
Let me now open up the call for questions.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Maybe I just misunderstood, Jon. The other question I have was on 7-nanometer, can you give us a sense of when you think you'll be ramping 7-nanometer and in particular, when does that sort of mean for your opportunity and data centers?
componenttext: Okay. Maybe I just misunderstood, Jon. The other question I have was on 7-nanometer, can you give us a sense of when you think you'll be ramping 7-nanometer and in particular, when does that sort of mean for your opportunity and data centers?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me take a cut at that. So the data center is first, emerging market, and it still the recent periods. So it's a market which we expect over the next 5 years to grow great for us. It could be significant and in that sort of timeframe, as we execute, we
componenttext: Let me take a cut at that. So the data center is first, emerging market, and it still the recent periods. So it's a market which we expect over the next 5 years to grow great for us. It could be significant and in that sort of timeframe, as we execute, we believe that it could be a multi-hundred million dollar market, which for us is a big number. We can service it and we are servicing it already with our existing product portfolio. So we actually have design wins and 20-nanometer, 16-nanometer and [indiscernible] we would expect to have significant disclaimer in 7-nanometer too. With 7-nanometer is typically high level of integration, higher performance, lower power, all of these things are important to this market where every 2 to 3 years, there's a total refresh of the data centers due to the rapid rate of evolvement. So data center is a big driver of a 7-nanometer business but, actually part of expansion, our 16-nanometer we expect to have significant benefit starting with our data center too. So you don't need to wait until 7-nanometer in order to see our revenue growth and it should come ahead of that. Given the nature of our business, after we take out the device, it usually takes a year to move into production and the deployment is very market specific. So there are markets that deploy very quickly. Emulation is an example of the one which deployed fastest. But data centers also first time-to-market for us. So it's probably 7-nanometer, our data center product should be generating revenue 2019, 2020, that sort of timeframe. Hopefully, that answers your question.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jon, let me take that one. So I think while you've been and you're familiar with the fact that we characterize, we had a roll ooff of a very large program and we bottomed out I think in our June quarter of this past year for aerospace and defense and we h
componenttext: Jon, let me take that one. So I think while you've been and you're familiar with the fact that we characterize, we had a roll ooff of a very large program and we bottomed out I think in our June quarter of this past year for aerospace and defense and we have had incremental improvement in each quarter from that point actually about September, excuse me, in September quarter, not the June quarter. With that incremental improvement in every quarter to continuate in Aerospace & Defense, it ships out when you look at the full year was still shipped quite of few products in our first quarter last year that is dragging the year-on-year comparison down. So it's a modest growth in Aerospace & Defense. It is actually a very stable strong comeback for us, and when the redesign of the F-35 capabilities starts kicking in more towards the end of the next fiscal year, I think you're going to see some acceleration there. Industrial has been more about timing issue for us for certain customers A. And then some recent softness particularly in APAC that we're seeing softness in industrial and a couple of our regions, and that's going to grow a little more slowly than we thought, but we still are expecting pretty significant growth on a year-on-year basis.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, there's kind of 2 parts to that the way I think about it. One as the cameras and other part is distribution aspect of things. And the distribution aspect is moving more towards server and common platform. And in some cases were actually seeing some
componenttext: Well, there's kind of 2 parts to that the way I think about it. One as the cameras and other part is distribution aspect of things. And the distribution aspect is moving more towards server and common platform. And in some cases were actually seeing some of that start to bleed into what we would call our classic imitation business as IP protocols are used more. In the camera business is tended to be more around trends of technology. So thinking of the move to 4K and then 8K, beyond that. So we are seeing relative strength in the whole camera side of it because of this trends more towards 4K, in terms of recording content and things like that. And the other side of the distributional, we're seeing relative softness.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the product and our 3 generations of leadership, we -- allow me to feel vindicated on that topic. And so when we delivered on that, you see the massive changes which are happening in a market. And no way I am minimizing the challenges of competing with
componenttext: On the product and our 3 generations of leadership, we -- allow me to feel vindicated on that topic. And so when we delivered on that, you see the massive changes which are happening in a market. And no way I am minimizing the challenges of competing with very large corporations like Intel and new [indiscernible] et cetera. The only thing what's happening is that semiconductor market has matured, it's changing radically and it's changing in a way where a lot of applications, which in the past, could justify namesake or the small and medium-sized ASP company that would provide a complete solution. The basics are particularly viable and most of those little companies and medium-size companies have gone, they've disappeared, and some emerge, some just no longer viable. Both in reality, a lot of those product line do not have a path going forward. So we sort of looked at -- and this is a multi-market trend, right, so I wouldn't say it's in every single market, but is doing a lot of the market we service that we actually now finding that we have the much larger firm we can address through our product offering because our product offerings have evolved in the same product line in the like and the integrated capabilities we can provide an alternative to ASSPs. And so both through our technology, through our market leadership and through the fact of consolidation, largely is eliminating solutions for a lot of these markets which might not be multibillion-dollar markets, but they're nice markets for us we are the best game in town, and the customers are telling that. So I'm sitting in front of this great opportunity saying: "okay, we have that technology leadership and these opportunities are coming up. Do I take my foot off the gas? Do I keep my foot on the gas, but where it was? Do I push the pedal, all the way down to the metal? And this was a strategic discussion we had. And we figured out that we can still remain at 30-plus percent operating margin frowth grow that point in and around and over time grow beyond it. And we'll talk a little more about that in May but we are still at the high and of profitability. So we might as well exploit this and in a nutshell this is an opportunity we think it would be [indiscernible] not to pursue it. As I said, we can do this while retaining a fabulous return of cash to investors with almost best-in-class operating margin. We can still do all of that. So yes, that's sort of -- that's the message we try to deliver and we will provide a little more clarity on that, and that's why you're seeing the investment grow, and it's almost all in R&D because we have to do more takeouts and we have to develop 2 or more things in parallel. One more thing of encapsulating this and this could be viewed as being arrogant, we do it because we can. The other way of looking at it is we're doing it because we can't afford not to exploit this great opportunity, right? That's the thinking behind this. So hopefully, again, that clarifies the strategic question. On the issue and data centers. So again, this is an evolving market which is [indiscernible] at this point in time and it's a market which traditionally has been serviced by CPUs and also the past several years NVidia in particular, has identified that there are segments that was serviced by GPUs and may actually have established a strong foothold in the market. What has become very clear and there's a lot of papers from third-parties, there's 1 from Microsoft which analyze what happened with these massively parallel applications and how they -- how well they do instead of just using a CPU or a GPU, you actually use an SPGA or program of logic. And what we found is for a lot of very critical applications is anywhere between potentially a 10x to a 35x improvement in performance per watt if you use programmable logic. And that's the essence that market is evolving. It's a market which is unique because most of it at this point in time is controlled by very large independent companies that actually control the ecosystem for this. So it doesn't require a Microsoft with all of the applications, it's actually a very -- it could be thought of as an embedded application, which is controlled by these very large companies and these very large companies are looking for alternatives to Intel and alternatives to GPUs. And this was cited by Intel, justifiably as one of the reasons that they acquired Altera and paid what they did for Altera, it was worth that much for them. Going forward, we expect the market to bifurcate into a an Intel x86 [indiscernible] and everyone else. With everyone else regardless of their x86 or powerbase or on-base and for most of these other players, this is significant growth market, then we are realistically the only game in town. Hence, we believe that's very possible for us. On the Intel x86 side, we do believe that Intel will do all sorts of integration things. Regardless of that, as we talk to these hyper scale customers, they're indicating to us that for a lot of their requirements, actually, a nonintegrated solution which they totally control is more attractive than one which is dictated to them from above. And so we are investing heavily. We think we have a big lead on the technology side and we do expect this to be a multi-hundred million dollar opportunity but again, this is in a 5-year time frame. This is -- we have design wins, we have several options, we are going to go into production soon and this is both likely in North America and outside America. But it's still early days and again, being a multi-market company, we believe that this will be a significant growth opportunity for us. So I apologize for both answer, but there's a lot to cover on both.

Do we have to wait until 16-nanometer materializes to get the benefits? Or should 20-nanometer help [indiscernible] trended at some point? I mean, is 30% up much in the line in the same year?

componenttext: Okay. That's a great question. We will answer it in more detail in May, but just to sort of give you a preview, we're going to be approaching that either way and we intend to grow the company over time to beat that number and to grow beyond it. So we'll give a little more clarity as to when you can expect that in May. But this is not -- you're not going to need to wait several years for that. This year is particularly significant in terms of growth because to be totally open, we have so overachieved on the functionality of the 16-nanometer that we are just accelerating the takeouts when each of these takeouts is a multimillion dollar cost to us. So realistically, we're sort of pulling several of the names which is a good news because that means that over time, it will translate revenue quickly. But what you're seeing now, this rate of growth in R&D, which potentially could be larger than the top line, we do not expect that to continue in the future. And again, in May, we'll give you more.

componenttext: It's Lourenco here. I think we are really, really conscious of the strength of our operating model, and I think I want to point out again what was said earlier, we've been very disciplined in how we spend and invest our money in the past. I think this is a strategic investment area, and I do -- as Moshe said, our objective is to get back to our target operating margin levels as quickly as possible.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: This is Jane for Ross Seymore. So Moshe, what gives the company confidence in spending so much more on OpEx that the OpEx yield revenues given the past few years or revenue growth has been difficult to generate.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's a great question. It sort of what sort of happen in the past few years is we're in a business where most of the markets we serve takes a long time to come to fruition. And so if you look at 28-nanometer, which we take out 6 years ago, it is n
componenttext: Okay. That's a great question. It sort of what sort of happen in the past few years is we're in a business where most of the markets we serve takes a long time to come to fruition. And so if you look at 28-nanometer, which we take out 6 years ago, it is now approaching $200 million a quarter, it hasn't quite reached that level. At $200 million a quarter, is give or take, only 1/3, in or around, it's about 30% of revenue. So what you are seeing is the time it takes for the new nodes starting from 28 and now, 20 which as we said, we shipped close to 100 million relatively quickly for us during the past fiscal year. They're in their continued growth phase and also to the product line is now in its more accelerated growth phase, for example, automotive is driven by Zynq product lines, which is an expansion phase. So we're in a point in time where all of the headwinds we had which are all technology some execution challenges we have had in the past which we are paying the price for, et cetera. They're tailing off and the new technologies where we have much higher market share and where expansion plays are starting to pick up. And so, I think, your question is very fair and a very good one, but the reason is that we now see that the headwinds are tailing off and hence, the growth from the new products will happen and we're also seeing the changes in the industry. For example, I'll just throw one thing at you. 5 years ago, we predicted that the Japanese ASIC vendors would depart the stage, right? And at the time, that was considered an heresy, right, because it also market for the longest period of time. And to a large extent, they're gone, right? So that's an opportunity for us. So a lot of the other ASIC vendors is gone. I mean, it's not that there are no ASIC companies but there are fewer and fewer of them. The same thing is true on the ASSPs side. So the serviceable market is now growing and in order to exploit that, we are making this larger investments.

componenttext: Okay. Clearly, we believe we have the yearly potentially a more significant lead in that and the who is to exploit it because the silicon is a such good shape and we can do multiple takeouts and we already are shipping 6 products which for us, would be unheard of. This is a product we taped out at the very end of June. So it's only 9 months since we taped it out and we are already are shipping 6. Derivative unique products, so that means that we've done 6 tapeouts, which really are in very good shape. And you're right that -- if we sort of sit back and we have already worthy competitor and we just let them -- don't exploit that, we are likely to compromise the potential here. So yes, there is an element of that. That's on core programmable logic business, but this goes beyond programmable logic because with 16-nanometer and with 7, and with Zynq, we can provide an alternative to ASIC and ASSPs, and those are nontraditional competitors. And obviously, we need to keep running as quickly as we can to maintain the lead we have in terms of technology. So it's both.

componenttext: This is Jon. Let me take that one. So we talk a lot about ASSPs and I think with a lot of comparisons to what we're doing in the forward-looking cameras, which is where we have a lot of strengths particularly, the stereo versions of those. But our ASSPs business is very, very broad. So Zynq is the driver of it and it's a driver of us not just in the forward-looking cameras but also in some of the other safety and lane departure and those kinds of things as well. We have developed a really broad business in the automotive world and it isn't just 1 competitor. There's a variety of competitors now that we're meeting. When we talk about -- when you see the presentations in May, I think you're goingo to see a lot more conversation around the breadth of what we have the why we're still so confident about success of years of growth in this market. So in other words, just technology, it's not just the programmable processing unit. It's really broader than that for us and we're doing really quite well.

componenttextpreview: You've talked about 5G starting to ramp in 2018, how should we look at the wireless in [indiscernible] market between now and then? Is there -- what's the status of the 4G ramping in Europe? And how should we look at wireless in [indiscernible] trend over
componenttext: You've talked about 5G starting to ramp in 2018, how should we look at the wireless in [indiscernible] market between now and then? Is there -- what's the status of the 4G ramping in Europe? And how should we look at wireless in [indiscernible] trend over the next couple of quarters given the kind of that we saw in China last year?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll give you my cut and then I'm sure there's additional information, Jon is willing, he's going to that. We hit the low point in the June quarter for calendar 2015, and that was a really low, low point. So sort of 2 peak to [indiscernible], it was al
componenttext: So I'll give you my cut and then I'm sure there's additional information, Jon is willing, he's going to that. We hit the low point in the June quarter for calendar 2015, and that was a really low, low point. So sort of 2 peak to [indiscernible], it was almost 1/2 of the peak or maybe even less than 1/2 of the peak. And what we've seen is it's recovering. We think that there's a lot of things that happened because wireless is a multi-geography, multi-generation phenomenon on the infrastructure side. What we saw was there's the combination of all the bad news on all of the fronts happening at the same time for us. Since then, it has improved. We're seeing renewed deployment in China. We're seeing deployment in India, and this is all triggered around, this is not 5G, this is largely LTE. We think that LTE still has a lot of deployment left, and that will probably for the next few years, continue to carry things. What we're seeing which is very encouraging to us, is you go back 1 year or 1.5 years ago, the general feeling was that there would be rush towards 5G, and that is sort of totally changed. Now we've been in the past year. And then now seems to be a race towards 5G with an amazing amount of prototyping and proof of concept being done now and we actually have a great footprint there. We expect a quasi 5G or an early 5G to be deployed in 2018 at a minimum in Korea. But actually, there's no surprise that some early signs in North America. And then 2020 onwards, we expect it to grow, its expected to be a very large market and there's a lot of applications which are driving it. Smartphones even though they're not growing, their footprint in terms of bandwidth is increasing, all right? So maybe there's not that many new smartphones, but the refresh cycle is one which have [indiscernible] bandwidth, which actually require more bandwidth and significantly bigger load on the infrastructure and the applications of driving that. The other one is the Internet of Things both on the consumer and the industrial side, and that's expected to generate totally a new set of needs for infrastructure. So we think it's a big market. Again, we'll shed some more light on that in people with more expert in the field.

We are not planning, Lorenzo's guidance for the year is 4% to 8%, and we're not sort of planning on some huge surge to justify this. We're planning on a gradual growth during the year. We think that's very reasonable, given our strong design win situation and the fact that we do see them moving into production and that creates on the new nodes. So I'm not discounting that, things happen and if they do, we will act accordingly.

I'm just kind of curious, can you give us some broad strokes as to what end markets or what product portfolios you think are going to good to start driving sort of better than seasonal growth as you go throughout the year.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me take that, I actually look at the issue of seasonality. I think the complexity of our business and the multi-market nature of our business makes seasonality a tough model to apply because it's more -- we're more prone to be following a longer-te
componenttext: So let me take that, I actually look at the issue of seasonality. I think the complexity of our business and the multi-market nature of our business makes seasonality a tough model to apply because it's more -- we're more prone to be following a longer-term growth or decline trends than we are necessarily seasonal behaviors like say, retail. And I know you acknowledge that up front, Jon, but I think what you're were really saying in this market environment, it is the continued growth of our new products which you can view as not being terribly impacted by seasonality and the expansion into new markets which also not impacted by seasonality, they are driving our overall growth for the year. And those would be the continued ramp of new products in our wired business, like I made in my commentary, there's relative firmness in wireless, expansion in the data center, continued growth in the expansion opportunity we've developed in automotive. Those are the things that are going to drive us. And like I said, I don't see that, kind of, expansion impacted significantly by seasonality.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we'll give some more bits here but again, this is an emerging set of application and there's various ways of skimming the cat. We think it won't end up with one centralized monster processer, regardless. Now there may be more centrally or maybe less th
componenttext: So we'll give some more bits here but again, this is an emerging set of application and there's various ways of skimming the cat. We think it won't end up with one centralized monster processer, regardless. Now there may be more centrally or maybe less than centrally, but it won't all be done centrally for a whole host of reason. In order to enable this distribution, one of the biggest issue is of course, issue security, that's where a product because the security can be built in our products and embedded in hardware as opposed to software which the more you're going to be we believe that we have a strong potential advantage as that turns out to be the case, right? But I think this is going to evolve over 10, 15 years, right? And this is a long-term transition. And regardless, I don't think that even at the very end, it will all be in 1 place. I think there will be lots of reasons for it to redistribute it over. But for sure, for the next 2 generations of products, we don't see anything other than the distributive solution.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the whole issue with latency and you can wait for a decision to be made by a process unit to get information to the driver at essentially real-time speeds, and that's where we excel. And there'll be many of those applications that are so crit
componenttext: Yes, I think the whole issue with latency and you can wait for a decision to be made by a process unit to get information to the driver at essentially real-time speeds, and that's where we excel. And there'll be many of those applications that are so critical to getting that information there. You cannot stand any sort of latency kind of an issue, and that's what we're finding usually interest in even more advanced products from customers.
