componenttext: Not for me at least, Moshe.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It has been in the past and I think our 3 generations of leadership, we -- allow me to sort of feel vindicated on that topic. And so when you've delivered on that, and you see the massive changes which are happening in the market, and no way am I minimizi
componenttext: It has been in the past and I think our 3 generations of leadership, we -- allow me to sort of feel vindicated on that topic. And so when you've delivered on that, and you see the massive changes which are happening in the market, and no way am I minimizing the challenges of competing with very large corporations, like Intel, like the new Broadcomm et cetera, but relative what is happening is the semiconductor market has matured, is changing radically. And it's changing in a way where a lot of applications which, in the past, could justify an ASIC or there would be a small and medium-sized ASSP company that would provide a complete solution, neither the ASICs are particularly viable and most of those little companies and medium-size companies have gone, they've disappeared and some have merged, some just are no longer viable. But in reality, a lot of those product lines do not have a path going forward. So we sort of look at what -- and this is a multi-market trend, right, so I wouldn't say that it's true in every single market, but it's true in a lot of the markets that we service that we actually now are finding that we have the -- it's a much larger fam we can address through our product offering because our product offerings have evolved and with the same product line and the like and the integrated capabilities we can provide an alternative to ASSPs. And so both through our technology, through our market leadership and through the fact that the consolidation largely is eliminating solutions for a lot of these markets, which might not be multibillion-dollar markets, but they're nice markets for us, we are the best game in town. And the customers are telling us that. So I'm sitting in front of this great opportunity saying, "Okay, we have the technology leadership and these opportunities are coming up. Do I take my foot off the gas? Do I keep my foot on the gas but -- where it was? Or I -- do I push the pedal all the way down to the metal?" And this was a strategic decision discussion we had. And we figured out that we can still remain at 30-plus percent operating margin and grow to that point and in and around and over time grow beyond it. And we'll talk a little more about that in May. But we're sort of at the high end of profitability, so we might as well exploit this. And in a nutshell, this is an opportunity and we think it would be foolhardy not to pursue it. And as I said, we can do this while retaining a fabulous return of cash to investors with almost best-in-class operating margin. We can still do all of that. So yes, that's sort of -- that's the message we try to deliver and we will provide a little more clarity on that. And that's why you're seeing the investment grow, and it's almost all in R&D because we have to do more tapeouts, and we have to develop a few more things in parallel. So one way of doing it, of encapsulating this, and this could be viewed as being arrogant, we're doing it because we can. The other way of looking at it is we're doing it because we can't afford not to exploit this great opportunity, right. And that's the thinking behind this. So hopefully, again, that clarifies the strategic question. On the architectural issue and data centers. So again, this is an evolving market which is nascent at this point in time, and it's a market which traditionally has been serviced by CPUs. And over the past several years, NVIDIA, in particular, has identified that there are segments that are well serviced by GPUs and may actually have established a strong foothold in the market. What has become very clear, and there's a lot of papers from third-parties, there's one from Microsoft, which analyzed what happens with these massively parallel applications and how they -- how well they do if instead of just using a CPU or a GPU, you actually use an FPGA or programmable logic. And what they found is that for a lot of very critical applications, there's anywhere between potentially a 10x to a 35x improvement in performance per watt if you use programmable logic. And that's the essence that market is evolving. It's a market which is unique because most of it at this point in time is controlled by very large independent companies that actually control the ecosystem for this. So it doesn't require a Microsoft with all of the x86 applications. It's actually a very -- it can be thought of as an embedded application, which is controlled by these very large companies. And these very large companies are looking for alternatives to Intel and alternatives to GPUs. And this was cited by Intel justifiably as one of the reasons that they acquired Altera and paid what they did for Altera. It was worth that much for them. Going forward, we expect the market to bifurcate into an Intel x86 camp and everyone else, where the everyone else, regardless of their x86 or power-based or ARM-based and for most of these other players, this is a significant growth market, and we are realistically the only game in town. Hence, we believe that that's very profitable for us. On the Intel x86 side, we do believe that Intel will do all sorts of integration things. Regardless of that, as we talk to these hyper-scale customers, they're indicating to us that, for a lot of their requirements, actually a nonintegrated solution which they totally control is more attractive than one which is dictated to them from above. And so we are investing heavily. We think we have a big lead on the technology side, and we do expect this to be a multi-hundred million dollar opportunity. But again, this is -- in a 5-year time frame, this is -- we have design wins. We have several of them. They are going to go into production soon. And this is both likely in North America and outside America. But it's still early days. And again, being a multi-market company, we believe that this will be a significant growth opportunity for us. So I apologize for the verbose answer, but there's a lot to cover on both.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Ian Ing from MKM Partners.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: More questions on these investment levels for the fiscal year. I know you talked about it being a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity, and customers are saying you're the best game in town. But how many years are you willing to grow investments faster than rev
componenttext: More questions on these investment levels for the fiscal year. I know you talked about it being a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity, and customers are saying you're the best game in town. But how many years are you willing to grow investments faster than revenue? Do we have to wait until 16-nanometer materializes to get the benefits? Or should 20-nanometer help to reverse the trend at some point? I mean is 30% up margin the line in the sand here?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's a great question. And I think we will answer it in more detail in May. But just to sort of give you a preview, we're going to be approaching that either way, and we intend to grow the company over time to beat that number and to grow beyond i
componenttext: Okay. That's a great question. And I think we will answer it in more detail in May. But just to sort of give you a preview, we're going to be approaching that either way, and we intend to grow the company over time to beat that number and to grow beyond it. So we'll give a little more clarity as to when you can expect that in May. But this is not -- you're not going to need to wait several years for that. This year is particularly significant in terms of growth because, to be totally open, we have so overachieved on the functionality of the 16-nanometer that we are just accelerating the tapeouts, and each of these tapeouts is a multimillion dollar cost to us. So realistically, we're sort of pulling several of the main [ph] which is good news because that means that, over time, it should translate to revenue quickly. But what you're seeing now, this rate of growth in R&D, which potentially could be larger than the top line, we do not expect that to continue in the future. And again, in May, we'll give you more.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ian, it's Lorenzo here. I think we are really, really conscious of the strength of our operating model. And I think we've -- I wanted to point out again what was said earlier, we've been very disciplined at how we spent and invested our money in the
componenttext: Yes, Ian, it's Lorenzo here. I think we are really, really conscious of the strength of our operating model. And I think we've -- I wanted to point out again what was said earlier, we've been very disciplined at how we spent and invested our money in the past. I think this is a strategic investment area. And I do -- as Moshe said, our objective is to get back to our target operating margin levels as quickly as possible.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ross Seymore from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ross Seymore from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Ji for Ross Seymore. So Moshe, what gives the company confidence in spending so much more on OpEx that the OpEx then will yield revenues given the past few years where revenue growth has been difficult to generate?
componenttext: This is Ji for Ross Seymore. So Moshe, what gives the company confidence in spending so much more on OpEx that the OpEx then will yield revenues given the past few years where revenue growth has been difficult to generate?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's a great question. What sort of happened over the past few years is we're in a business where most of the markets we serve take a long time to come to fruition. So if you look at 28-nanometer, which we taped out 6 years ago, it is now approach
componenttext: Okay. That's a great question. What sort of happened over the past few years is we're in a business where most of the markets we serve take a long time to come to fruition. So if you look at 28-nanometer, which we taped out 6 years ago, it is now approaching $200 million a quarter. It hasn't quite reached that level. And $200 million a quarter is, give or take, only 1/3. In or around, it's about 30% of our overall revenue. So what you're seeing is the time it takes for the new nodes, starting from 28 and now at 20 which, as we said, we shipped close to 100 million relatively quickly for us during the past fiscal year. They're in their continued growth phase and also the Zynq product line is now in its more accelerated growth phase. For example, automotive is driven by the Zynq product line, which is an expansion play. And so we're at a point in time where all of the headwinds we had, which are old technologies, some execution challenges we have had in the past which we are paying the price for, et cetera, they're tailing off and the new technologies where we have much higher market share and where the expansion plays are starting to pick up. And so, I think your question is very fair and a very good one, but the reason is that we now see that the headwinds are tailing off and, hence, the growth from the new products will happen. And we're also seeing the changes in the industry. For example, I'll just throw one thing at you. 5 years ago, we predicted that the Japanese ASIC vendors would depart the stage, right. And at the time, that was considered heresy, right, because they had owned the market for the longest period of time. And to a large extent, they're gone, right, so that's an opportunity for us. So a lot of the other ASIC vendors have gone. I mean, it's not that there are no ASIC companies, but there are fewer and fewer of them. The same thing is true on the ASSP side. So the serviceable market is now growing. And in order to exploit that, we are making these larger investments.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as a follow-up, is the OpEx expected to be back-half-weighted in the fiscal year, similar to revenues, so it can be moderated if revenues don't follow?
componenttext: And as a follow-up, is the OpEx expected to be back-half-weighted in the fiscal year, similar to revenues, so it can be moderated if revenues don't follow?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the second half operating expense will be significantly higher than the first half. But you'll start seeing the increase in the second quarter.
componenttext: Yes, the second half operating expense will be significantly higher than the first half. But you'll start seeing the increase in the second quarter.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Hans Mosesmann from Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Hans Mosesmann from Raymond James.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Moshe, on the -- going back to the 16-nanometer and the decision to accelerate and expand on the tapeouts and such, how much of it is a result of a competitive dynamic? I understand that customers are eager, but perhaps there's another element here. Your
componenttext: Moshe, on the -- going back to the 16-nanometer and the decision to accelerate and expand on the tapeouts and such, how much of it is a result of a competitive dynamic? I understand that customers are eager, but perhaps there's another element here. Your competitor might be delayed or delayed significantly. How much of it is that potentially that you're taking advantage of an opening, if you will?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Clearly, we believe we have the year lead potentially a more significant lead than that and if behooves us exploit it. And because our silicon is in such good shape and we can do multiple tapeouts and we already are shipping 6 products which, for us
componenttext: Okay. Clearly, we believe we have the year lead potentially a more significant lead than that and if behooves us exploit it. And because our silicon is in such good shape and we can do multiple tapeouts and we already are shipping 6 products which, for us, would be unheard of. This is a product we taped out at the very end of June. So it's only 9 months since we taped it out, and we already are shipping 6 derivative unique products, so that means that we've done 6 tapeouts which we said it's really in very good shape. And you're right that if we sort of sit back and we have a very worthy competitor and we just let them -- don't exploit that, we're likely to compromise the potential here. So yes, there is an element of that. That's on a core programmable logic business, but this goes beyond programmable logic because with 16-nanometer and with 7, and with Zynq, we can provide an alternative to ASICs and ASSPs, and those are nontraditional competitors. And obviously, we just need to keep running as quickly as we can to maintain the lead we have in terms of technology. So it's both.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. And then a quick follow-up, please. On the Zynq side, on the automotive business, what's the competitive dynamic there? Are you gaining share? What's the size of the market? If you can just give us a little framework there as you look into fi
componenttext: Fair enough. And then a quick follow-up, please. On the Zynq side, on the automotive business, what's the competitive dynamic there? Are you gaining share? What's the size of the market? If you can just give us a little framework there as you look into fiscal '17.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Jon. Let me take that one. So we talk a lot about ADAS, and I think we get a lot of comparisons to how well we're doing in the forward-looking cameras which is where we have a lot of strength, particularly in the stereo versions of those. But
componenttext: Yes, this is Jon. Let me take that one. So we talk a lot about ADAS, and I think we get a lot of comparisons to how well we're doing in the forward-looking cameras which is where we have a lot of strength, particularly in the stereo versions of those. But our ADAS business is really very broad. So Zynq is the driver of it, and it's a driver of us not just in the forward-looking cameras, but also in some of the other safety and lane departure and those kinds of things as well. We have developed a really broad business in the automotive world. And it isn't just 1 competitor, there's a variety of competitors now that we're meeting. And when we talk about -- when you see the presentations in May, I think you're going to see a lot more conversation around the breadth of what we have and why we're so confident about successive years of growth in this market. So in other words, FPGA technology is not just the programmable processing unit. It's really broader than that for us, and we're doing really quite well.

componenttext: Our next question comes from Tristan Gerra from Baird.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You've talked about 5G starting to ramp in 2018, how should we look at the wireless infrastructure market between now and then? Is there -- what's the status of the 4G ramping in Europe? And how should we look at wireless infrastructure trends over the ne
componenttext: You've talked about 5G starting to ramp in 2018, how should we look at the wireless infrastructure market between now and then? Is there -- what's the status of the 4G ramping in Europe? And how should we look at wireless infrastructure trends over the next couple of quarters given the kind of the turmoil that we saw in China last year?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll give you my cut, and then I'm sure there's a lot of additional information Jon and Lorenzo can add. But we hit the low point in the June quarter of calendar 2015, and that was a really low, low point. So if you sort of do peak to trough, it was al
componenttext: So I'll give you my cut, and then I'm sure there's a lot of additional information Jon and Lorenzo can add. But we hit the low point in the June quarter of calendar 2015, and that was a really low, low point. So if you sort of do peak to trough, it was almost 1/2 of the peak or maybe even less than 1/2 of the peak. And what we've seen is it's recovering. We think there was a -- there's a lot of things that happened because wireless is a multi-geography, multi-generation phenomenon on the infrastructure side. What we saw was there's the combination of all of the bad news on all of the fronts happened at the same time for us. Since then, it has improved. We're seeing renewed deployment in China. We're seeing deployment in India. And this is all triggered around -- this is not 5G, this is largely LTE. We think that LTE still has a lot of deployment left. And that will probably, for the next few years, continue to carry things. What we're seeing, which is very encouraging to us, is if you go back 1 year or 1.5 years ago, the general feeling was that there would be no rush towards 5G. And that has sort of totally changed. Now we've been in the past year, and there now seems to be a race towards 5G with an amazing amount of prototyping and proof of concept being done now and we actually have a great footprint there. We expect a quasi 5G or an early 5G to be deployed in 2018 at a minimum in Korea. But actually, there's no -- don't be surprised if there's some early signs in North America. And then 2020 onward, we expect it to grow. It's expected to be a very large market, and there's a lot of applications which are driving it. Smartphones, even though they are not growing their footprint in terms of bandwidth, is increasing, right. So maybe there's not that many new smartphones, but the refresh cycle is one which have yield bandwidth -- which require more bandwidth and significantly bigger load on the infrastructure and the applications of driving that. The other one is the Internet of Things both on the consumer and the industrial side. And that's expected to generate totally a new set of needs for infrastructure. So we think it's a big market. Again, we'll shed some more light on that in May from people who are more expert in the field.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I think despite Moshe saying Jon and I could have a lot to add, his answer was fairly comprehensive. In the near term, what we see is, as Moshe described, a firming up of recovery from where we had been in the low points, particularly in China, b
componenttext: Yes, and I think despite Moshe saying Jon and I could have a lot to add, his answer was fairly comprehensive. In the near term, what we see is, as Moshe described, a firming up of recovery from where we had been in the low points, particularly in China, backfills geographically around the world and a ramp in India, although we don't expect that to be of the same magnitude as China. And then finally, the 5G prototyping preproduction type of business is actually pretty good business for us this year.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. That's very useful. And then a quick follow-up question, what opportunity do you see in small cell? I mean, we've learned, obviously, that the price points were high and have -- cannot be led what people start with a ramp starting a few years
componenttext: Okay, great. That's very useful. And then a quick follow-up question, what opportunity do you see in small cell? I mean, we've learned, obviously, that the price points were high and have -- cannot be led what people start with a ramp starting a few years ago, but it looks like we're now starting to see signs in China, notably. Do you expect to participate? Or is that type of market naturally gravitating toward ASIC given the high volumes?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So there is -- that trend is continuing but certainly not as robust as people had indicated a number of years ago that it was going to be deployed. We are participating in small cells. It is still a market that we can be in if we're talking about urban ar
componenttext: So there is -- that trend is continuing but certainly not as robust as people had indicated a number of years ago that it was going to be deployed. We are participating in small cells. It is still a market that we can be in if we're talking about urban areas where the number of users and densification requirements. So not -- I would say not on the home or local kinds of things but in urban areas where they're trying to augment macro base stations. We are playing in those, particularly in the radios. So yes, but we don't see it as a big offset to the long-term macro station.

componenttext: First, I just want to thank Jon for all the help over the years, really appreciate it. Moshe, I know on an earlier question, you kind of addressed that the OpEx guidance for the fiscal year '17 is pretty back-half loaded. I guess, I just want some clarification. How dependent is that OpEx number in kind of hitting the revenue guidance number you gave? If, for some reason, revenue were to come a little bit short, would that OpEx number have some modulation in it? Or is a lot of that just kind of fixed OpEx based upon projects achieved that you are planning on doing in the back half of the fiscal year?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let's say there's a huge downturn, and we sort of -- we're rational people and we behave accordingly, right. So we generally realize that we have a responsibility here and we take it very seriously. So if that happens, we will act accordingly. We ar
componenttext: Well, let's say there's a huge downturn, and we sort of -- we're rational people and we behave accordingly, right. So we generally realize that we have a responsibility here and we take it very seriously. So if that happens, we will act accordingly. We are not planning -- Lorenzo's guidance for the year is 4% to 8%, and we are not sort of planning on some huge surge to justify this. We're planning on a gradual growth during the year. We think that's very reasonable given our strong design win situation and the fact that we do see them moving into production now at a greater rate on the newer nodes. So I'm not discounting that things happen and, if they do, we will act accordingly.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful, Moshe. And then, my guess is you'll address this in a lot more detail at the Analyst Day, and I'm not a huge fan of looking at seasonality because there's so much variance around seasonality. But if I just pivot seasonally off your June gu
componenttext: That's helpful, Moshe. And then, my guess is you'll address this in a lot more detail at the Analyst Day, and I'm not a huge fan of looking at seasonality because there's so much variance around seasonality. But if I just pivot seasonally off your June guidance, I'm getting fiscal revenue year growth in '17 that's more flattish versus kind of the 6% midpoint guidance you gave. I'm just kind of curious, can you give us some broad strokes as to what end markets or what product portfolios you think are going to start driving sort of better than seasonal growth as you go throughout the year?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me take that because I've actually looked at the issue of seasonality. I think the complexity of our business and the multi-market nature of our business makes seasonality a tough model to apply because it's more -- we're more prone to be following
componenttext: So let me take that because I've actually looked at the issue of seasonality. I think the complexity of our business and the multi-market nature of our business makes seasonality a tough model to apply because it's more -- we're more prone to be following longer-term growth or decline trends than we are necessarily seasonal behaviors of, like say, retail. And I know you acknowledged that up front, John, but I think what you were really saying in this market environment, it is the continued growth of our new products, which you can view as not being terribly impacted by seasonality and the expansion into new markets which also are not impacted by seasonality, that are driving our overall growth for the year. And those would be the continued ramp of new products in our wired business, like I -- and I made in my commentary, there's relative firmness in wireless, expansion in the data center, continued growth in the expansion opportunity we've developed in automotive. Those are the things that are going to drive us. And like I said, I don't see that kind of expansion impacted significantly by seasonality.

componenttextpreview: This is Chris Hemmelgarn on for Blayne. I just had a longer-term question about the direction of the auto business and the architectures there. I mean, the systems today are kind of a hodge podge of ASICs and FPGAs, each controlling different functions. A
componenttext: This is Chris Hemmelgarn on for Blayne. I just had a longer-term question about the direction of the auto business and the architectures there. I mean, the systems today are kind of a hodge podge of ASICs and FPGAs, each controlling different functions. And you've seen some players lay out a vision that involved more of a centralized control as the market matured. You clearly have long-term engagements with customers. I guess, what is the interest you're seeing? Are you still seeing them desiring discrete chips to drive each of these functions? Or are you seeing interest in more of a centralized controller?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we'll give some more bits here, but again this is an emerging set of applications. And there's various ways of skinning the cat. We do think that it won't all end up with one centralized monster processor regardless. Now there may be more done centrall
componenttext: So we'll give some more bits here, but again this is an emerging set of applications. And there's various ways of skinning the cat. We do think that it won't all end up with one centralized monster processor regardless. Now there may be more done centrally or there may be less done centrally, but it won't all be done centrally for a whole host of reasons. In order to enable this distribution, one of the biggest issues is, of course, the issue of security. And that's where our product -- because the security can be built in our products and embedded in hardware as opposed to software, which can more easily be hacked [indiscernible] that we -- we believe that we have a strong potential advantage as that turns out to be the case, right. But I think this is going to evolve over 10, 15 years, right. And this is a long-term transition. And regardless, I don't think that even at the very end, it will all be in 1 place. I think there will be lots of reasons for it to distributed over. But for sure, for the next 2 generations of products, we don't see anything other than distributed solution.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the whole issue with latency -- and you can't wait for a decision to be made by a process unit to get information to the driver at essentially real-time speeds. And that's where we excel. And there'll be many of those applications that are so
componenttext: Yes, I think the whole issue with latency -- and you can't wait for a decision to be made by a process unit to get information to the driver at essentially real-time speeds. And that's where we excel. And there'll be many of those applications that are so critical to getting that information there. You cannot stand any sort of a latency kind of an issue. And that's where we're finding huge interest even in our more advanced products from customers.

componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Ian, and I will be your conference operator. headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Lorenzo Flores, CFO, who will provide a financial and business review of the June quarter, and then we'll open the call for questions. During the quarter, we reclassified our product cat
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Lorenzo Flores, CFO, who will provide a financial and business review of the June quarter, and then we'll open the call for questions. During the quarter, we reclassified our product categories to be consistent with how these categories are analyzed and reviewed internally. Specifically, we are we're grouping the products manufactured at the 28-, 20- and 16-nanometer nodes into category named advance products, while all other product will be included in the category entitled core products. This representation is consistent with what was presented as our recent Analyst Meeting. For comparative purposes, we have provided supplemental information on our website at www.investor.xilinx.com that presents results based on previous classifications. 
Let me remind everyone that during our conference call today, we may make projections or other forward-looking statements regarding future events or the future financial performance of the company. We wish to caution you that such statements are predictions based on information that is currently available and that actual results may differ materially. We refer you to the documents the company files with the SEC, including our 10-Ks, 10-Qs and 8-Ks. These documents contain and identify important risk factors that could cause the actual results to differ materially from those contained in our projections or forward-looking statements.
This conference call is open to all and is being webcast live. It can be accessed from our Xilinx's Investor Relations website. Let me now turn the call over to Lorenzo.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rick. In the June quarter, Xilinx's sales were $575 million, up 1% sequentially and up 5% on a year-over-year basis. Advanced products increased 10% sequentially and 60% year-over-year with 28-nanometer and 20-nanometer products each reaching r
componenttext:
Thank you, Rick. In the June quarter, Xilinx's sales were $575 million, up 1% sequentially and up 5% on a year-over-year basis. Advanced products increased 10% sequentially and 60% year-over-year with 28-nanometer and 20-nanometer products each reaching record sales and 16-nanometer beginning it's revenue ramp. 
As expected, core products declined on a sequential and year-over-year basis. Communications increased 4% sequentially, with growth from both wired and wireless. Communications has stayed a modest but consistent recovery since bottoming in the June quarter a year ago and is up 22% on a year-over-year basis. 
Industrial and A&D was down slightly, with strength and test measurement and emulation not quite offsetting expected declines in industrial and aerospace and defense. 
Broadcast consumer and automotive was flat on a sequential basis, slightly better than anticipated due to stronger orders from Zynq driven ADAS applications. Both automotive and test and measurements reach record levels for the company in the June quarter. 
Gross margin in Q1 was 70.7%, higher than guided due to the mix of customers and products in addition to increased manufacturing efficiencies. We continue to aggressively optimize gross margin across our product portfolio. 
Operating expense at $220 million was in line with our guidance. Operating income for the quarter was $186 million or 32.4%. Other income and expense was an expense of $5 million as guided. 
The tax rate was 10% for the quarter, better than guided. This included the impact of the early adoption of an accounting standard related to the treatment of stock-based compensation. Our net income for Q1 was $163 million or $0.61 a share. This included a positive $0.02 a share impact associated with the accounting standard I just referenced. 
Operating cash flow was $339 million, driven primarily by strong profitability and a significant reduction in accounts receivable. Diluted shares were $266 million, including $10.5 million from the convertible. 
During the quarter, we repurchased 2.2 million shares for $100 million and we paid $84 million in dividends. 
Some key points on the balance sheet. We ended the quarter with $3.7 billion in gross cash and $2.1 billion net cash after our debt. Inventory was $195 million, up $17 million from the prior quarter and down $27 million from the same quarter a year ago. We continue to manage our inventory by balancing levels against expect the demand and potential upside from customers. 
Accounts receivable declined $90 million to $217 million, reflecting ordering patterns during the quarter. 
Now turning to our September quarter guidance. We expect revenue to be approximately flat. We entered the quarter with backlog that is down sequentially, but we have forecasted demand from key customers tat is not currently reflected in our backlog. As a result, we expect turns in the quarter to be approximately 54%. We expect advanced products to continue to grow with 28-nanometer sales increasing to a new record, 20-nanometer exceeding $40 million and our 16-nanometer UltraScale+ family demonstrating material growth. 
With respect to end markets, communications and data center is expected to decline after 4 consecutive quarters of growth. An increase in wired business will not conclude the offset a decrease in wireless sales. 
Industrial and A&D is expected to grow, driven primarily by strength in test measurement and immolation, along with growth in aerospace and defense and ISM. 
Broadcast consumer and -- broadcast automotive and consumer will be flat sequentially. 
Our gross margin will be approximately 70% and our operating expense will be approximately $230 million, including $1 million of amortization. The increase in operating expense is in line with the investments in accelerating our leadership position as we discussed at our Analyst Day. 
Other income and expense will be an expense of $4 million, and our tax rate is expected to be 14%. Share count is expected to be $266 million. 
Finally, at our Analyst Day in May, we discussed our expectations for 4% to 8% growth in revenue for FY '17, along with gross margins in 68% to 70% range, and the accelerated investments I just mentioned. As and our first quarter, we believe we are on track on all of these elements. 
Let me now turn the call over to Moshe.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, [indiscernible] with the financial results for the first quarter. We delivered revenue growth which was above the midpoint of our guidance and profitability was very strong. Our overall revenue growth was driven by sales of our advanced product
componenttext:
Thank you, [indiscernible] with the financial results for the first quarter. We delivered revenue growth which was above the midpoint of our guidance and profitability was very strong. Our overall revenue growth was driven by sales of our advanced products, which increased 60% year-over-year and reached a new quarterly record. Overall, this demonstrated the strength of our diversified multi-market portfolio, with 5 of our [indiscernible]  Markets growing in the quarter. 
Gross margin reached 70.7% resulting in an operating margin of 32.4%, the highest level in the year. We generated a record level of cash in the quarter, continue to demonstrate a commitment to shareholder return through both dividend and share repurchase. Our exceptional execution on the 28-, 20- and 16-nanometer nodes has now delivered 3 consecutive generations of unquestionable technology leadership. This is a testament to the success of our engineering and operations team, working in concert with our world-class industry-leading foundry partner, TSMC. 
The June quarter, for the third quarter in a row, our overall 28-nanometer sales delivered a new record. The overall 28-nanometer sales growth benefited from broad sales contribution from communications, industrial, automotive, tests and measurements and consumers. In addition, our Zynq product family, a significant element of our market expansion efforts, reached a new sales record in the June quarter. Overall, 28-nanometer sales, including our Zynq offering are expected to grow again in the September quarter. 
20-nanometer revenue again reached a record level at sales in the quarter significantly exceeded our $30 million forecast. UltraScale, the industry's only high-end 20-nanometer product offering, continues to grow at a very significant grade, as do sales from our Kintex UltraScale product family. We expect to ship over $40 million of 20-nanometer product in the September quarter. This accelerated 20-nanometer ramp continues to exceed our original expectations. 
At the 16-nanometer node, we have delivered all 3 UltraScale+ products family ahead of schedule. We are already shipping 6 units of product so well over 100 customers, and getting excellent feedback, in particular, with regards to its production level quality, further extending our industry lead to well over a year. 
Consequently, we are accelerating our 16-nanometer tapeouts schedules and broadening our offering at this node. This broad 16-nanometer product offering is being designed into applications in all of our major end markets and is enabling more platform-based designs than any previous generation. 
This advanced products are building significant momentum, enabled by 4 multi market industry growth drivers: Cloud computing, embedded vision, industrial IoT and 5G wireless. In cloud computing, we are in production with 3 of the largest type of scale data center customers, with 2 more in extensive trials. Additionally, we led the formation of the very broad CCIX consortium for the single the role of bringing a high performance, open acceleration framework to data centers. We're winning in fast-growing embedded vision applications, across numerous markets, including industrial, aerospace and defense automotive, broadcast and consumer. In particular, our ADAS penetration in automotive will reach 85 models this year. 
With regards industrial IoT, we have seen continued success with both Zynq and Zynq UltraScale+ family, securing platform design wins with the largest Tier 1 players. 
Lastly, in 5G wireless, we have 90% market share in pre-5G proof of concept deployments and 5G prototyping. We have attained an unprecedented position of strength, opportunity and momentum, this is driven by our exceptional execution, leadership product and customer adoption in the form of multi market drivers, which will fuel long-term revenue growth. We are committed to maintaining this leadership, while delivering 30%-plus operating margin in the long-term and continuing a strong commitment to shareholder return. 
Now I'll turn the call back to the operator for Q&A.

componenttext: So, Zynq. Just give me a second. Let me start with end markets for Zynq. The Zynq end markets, I think, the showcase end market for Zynq is really automotive ADAS applications. headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: Moshe, you talked about the CCIX at the Analyst Day, you mentioned again today. Can you sort of frame the current impact or expected impact of this? Are there products that are relevant to this consortium? Is there any revenue or customer at risk,/ any details would be helpful.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So this is a market, which, today, is dominated by Intel's very strong position on the server space. It's market which is fast emerging, it's expected to be a very large market going forward and the expectation is it will get split between additiona
componenttext: Okay. So this is a market, which, today, is dominated by Intel's very strong position on the server space. It's market which is fast emerging, it's expected to be a very large market going forward and the expectation is it will get split between additional players as competitive products are available from these players. Now these come from a variety of architectures. They can come from x86 solutions, they can come from power-based solutions and then they can come from the numerous players who are committed to the architecture. Those additional ones are still to emerge at the performance level, which will enable them to penetrate the market. CCIX is basically an opportunity, which now has been identified by all of these other players as the need to have a common interface standard that can integrate and support the -- from our perspective, we did, at the Analyst Meeting, talk about one product which conceptually will targets this market, which will be implemented in the 16-nanometer. And then we'll have traditional all-programmable devices at 16- and also a whole host of solutions at 7-nanometer that address thes markets. For us, we believe this has the potential of being several  hundred million dollars in the 2020 timeframe. In order to get to that, going to -- it was really essential to have this multi-partner opportunity, open multi-partner opportunity, in order to enable us to participate broadly in it. And so at this point in time, our revenue in data center does not yet comprehend this opportunity. It's more in traditional storage and networking data center applications. Over the next few years, we expect our business to grow to that. So that's about as much information I can give at this point in time. I hope it helps.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. If I can get the follow up. In server acceleration in the data center, there's discussion FPGA being helpful here, but also GPU. And I'm wondering if you view that as a stable competitive environment or if the dynamics there are changing?
componenttext: That's helpful. If I can get the follow up. In server acceleration in the data center, there's discussion FPGA being helpful here, but also GPU. And I'm wondering if you view that as a stable competitive environment or if the dynamics there are changing?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as I said, this is an emerging opportunity. And as such, the historic position is clearly led by Intel, and that's driven off their server and high-performance strength. In [indiscernible] definitely identified several years ago, this is an opportunity
componenttext: So as I said, this is an emerging opportunity. And as such, the historic position is clearly led by Intel, and that's driven off their server and high-performance strength. In [indiscernible] definitely identified several years ago, this is an opportunity, and they have invested heavily, and we believe that there is a host of applications, which was served well by a GPU solution. But that is a subset and not a particularly dominant subset of the future applications that's going to use this. And so we do expect this market, which is a large market and will grow rapidly over the next few years to be serviced by numerous solutions from numerous players. GPUs definitely will be one. But they have a whole host of applications where, due to power and a whole host of other issues, they don't provide an optimum solution and programmable logic, actually can provide much higher fulfillment for what the dollar, the most -- the best solution in that regard, and that's why we're talking to all 7 major hyperscale players and a few other players, too, and we believe that our solution will have a value for a whole host of these new applications. Having said that, we expect a the GPUs will continue to do well in this market.

componenttext: Just a clarification on the yearly guidance, they are sticking with the guidance provided the Analyst Day. On the gross margin, could it be 70% for the next couple of quarters? componenttext: So I'll start backwards. On OpEx, that guidance is essentially true. You can see, plus or minus, a couple of million dollars. But in aggregate, the expense growth is R&D. On gross margin, I'm not going to go into specific guidance for the second half. The 68% to 70% range for the year that we provided by the Analyst Day conference, a few different scenarios about how the actual revenue product and customer mix would come out. And so, I think we're comfortable leaving that range.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: And our next question is from the line of Ross Seymore.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question from the end markets side, I think, in your communications and data center side. Other than that 45% of revenues, can you remind us the split between wireless and wireline? And to the extent the wireless side is falling off, how do you vie
componenttext: Just a question from the end markets side, I think, in your communications and data center side. Other than that 45% of revenues, can you remind us the split between wireless and wireline? And to the extent the wireless side is falling off, how do you view where we are in the wireless market? Obviously, a year ago, you had a huge inventory drawdown, and then you've grown nicely since then. Is that inventory be fill back to normalize level and will then ship with the demand from here forward? And if so, what are your views on that?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if you look at communications and you break it down between wired and wireless, what happens is they tend to have different characteristics. Wireless tends to be more choppy, wired tends to be more gradual in terms of its growth. What we've seen is on
componenttext: So if you look at communications and you break it down between wired and wireless, what happens is they tend to have different characteristics. Wireless tends to be more choppy, wired tends to be more gradual in terms of its growth. What we've seen is on the wired side, basically driven by very strong technology portfolio. That business has been growing now consistently and, in particular, it's being driven by 28- and 20-nanometer shipments. On the wireless side, it is volatile. It had its [indiscernible] point in the June quarter of last year. And since then, it has recovered, it's grown by about 40% since that low point. It hasn't gotten back to its peak, and we don't necessarily expect it to get back to its peak. Its peak was about 2x higher than its low point. But it's hovering just about in the middle, and we expect it to continue to go up and down, but more around this new number, right, as opposed to the low point, and it will be based on deployments during the past quarter. China was steady, India was up, EMEA was weak, and North America was steady, it tends to change from quarter-to-quarter as the deployments geographically spreads around the world. But we do expect communications generally to continue to grow. And if you can neutralize the wireless volatility or sort of flatten it, we do see that the communications market overall, including data center, to be a long-term growth driver for us. Next question, please?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from the line of Vivek Arya.
componenttext: And our next question is from the line of Vivek Arya.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Moshe, thanks for the color around the wireless business. I have one follow-up to that. If you look at your content in the base station today, how does it compare to what you have a year before or the year before that? I understand the volatility in deplo
componenttext: Moshe, thanks for the color around the wireless business. I have one follow-up to that. If you look at your content in the base station today, how does it compare to what you have a year before or the year before that? I understand the volatility in deployments. But over a longer period time when I look at the low growth in this communications business, for not just yourself, but your competitors as well, has there been a unit issue? or has there been a content issue? But, yes, unit has been volatile, but is it possible that content has not grown at the same pace? And any color around that would be very useful.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So from generation to generation, the level of integration is much higher and the power reduction requirements are becoming more and more significant. And as such, we're seeing a higher level of integration, and our customers are moving to the highe
componenttext: Okay. So from generation to generation, the level of integration is much higher and the power reduction requirements are becoming more and more significant. And as such, we're seeing a higher level of integration, and our customers are moving to the higher end of our product offering. It's still -- it's not the high end, it's not Virtex products, but it's Kintex and Zynq products. And generally speaking, the percentage of the dollar content, which is implemented in programmable logic, be it Zynq or be it a nonprogrammable solution has grown up from generation to generation. What we're seeing -- and so if you look at the numbers, on average, 4G was higher than 3G. Best we can tell, 5G is an incredibly sophisticated requirement with -- and as we're being used in the vast majority of the early deployments, these are not going to be the massive deployments, those are still 3 or 4 years ahead of us. But we're sort of seeing the level of complexity is very high. And then unquestionably, the level of integration is high, and I would say, generally speaking, the average price what we realize has gone up with a  significantly higher level of optionality. The volatility is due to markets happening at different rates, in particular, China is very difficult to predict. But I wouldn't say that, overall, we've seen the dollar content shrink at all. It's gone the other way at this point per unit.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: And our next question is from the line of Tristan Gerra.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you elaborate a little bit on the operational efficiencies and mix? I know you're not providing a [indiscernible] guidance beyond this current quarter. But if you could explain a little bit what's happening in terms of operational efficiencies and w
componenttext: Could you elaborate a little bit on the operational efficiencies and mix? I know you're not providing a [indiscernible] guidance beyond this current quarter. But if you could explain a little bit what's happening in terms of operational efficiencies and whether there's a lasting effect that we can expect beyond this coming quarter?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Tristan, as you know, gross margin has direct price, direct costs and manufacturing overhead type of components that drive it. And we have a portfolio of customers, a portfolio of end markets and the customers all take -- in those end markets, the
componenttext: Right. Tristan, as you know, gross margin has direct price, direct costs and manufacturing overhead type of components that drive it. And we have a portfolio of customers, a portfolio of end markets and the customers all take -- in those end markets, the portfolio of different products. So what we see across the board is a continued drive toward manufacturing side efficiencies, getting our products at lower cost over time. We see continued price pressure from our customers across the board in larger customers, obviously a certain more price pressure, and we try to balance that and continue to get the broad savings to manifest themselves in our overall gross margin. On the overhead side, that will swing from time to time with the different factors than what we're doing from the inventory strategy. But in general, we're approaching manufacturing efficiencies there very, very aggressively as well. So as it's common in the semiconductor industry, cost continue to go down, but price pressure continues to increase and we, again, try to match that through the broad portfolio that we have.

And just to sort of summarize, because Lorenzo gave you all of the data without answering the question, we think the 68% to 70% will continue to be in the foreseeable. 
[Audio Gap] 
Embedded in your guidance, what are the -- how are these end markets behaving versus what you would normally expect if there was any [indiscernible] normal in the semi industry, that would be helpful. if you could provide us with some extra additional color on the other major end markets.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, we break it down into each market overall, and we're very pleased that we hit above the midpoint. But if you look at the growth overall, it was not huge, it was driven by 5 of the 8 markets. I think, we highlighted which those were in terms of the p
componenttext: Okay, we break it down into each market overall, and we're very pleased that we hit above the midpoint. But if you look at the growth overall, it was not huge, it was driven by 5 of the 8 markets. I think, we highlighted which those were in terms of the past product. And it's wired and wireless were up, automotive was up, consumer was up and test, yes, test was up quite significantly. Going forward, we're looking at flat, right? So there's probably going to be some up and some down, and I cannot, at this point in time, but as you look at the second half of the year, if I had to guess, we do expect communications to continue to grow slightly. We expect to be flat. We expect automotive to be up significantly, driven by the large number of design wins we have and we had expect I assume also to get back into the growth mode. So that's the best forecast we could can give your for the second half based on what we know now. And just for the upcoming quarter, I think, Lorenzo gave some of our prognostication there. Next question, please?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, Moshe, I think you referred to contribute in about 8% of revenues right now. Look surprised. I thought they would be higher, might be in double digits. Now is this contribution volatility or has been pretty much in the kind of the high-single digits o
componenttext: So, Moshe, I think you referred to contribute in about 8% of revenues right now. Look surprised. I thought they would be higher, might be in double digits. Now is this contribution volatility or has been pretty much in the kind of the high-single digits over the last couple of quarters?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, Anil, I think we were quite clear in the past. You sort of -- if you look at our entire offering, there's several generation that are now contributing. The first generation where there was a, I think, product line was the 28-nanometer, and that's prov
componenttext: So, Anil, I think we were quite clear in the past. You sort of -- if you look at our entire offering, there's several generation that are now contributing. The first generation where there was a, I think, product line was the 28-nanometer, and that's providing nearly all of that number. It's driven by 3 markets as Lorenzo mentioned, wireless, automotive and industrial markets. What those 3 wireless has gone into production or automotive is going into production, it should grow very rapidly, and the industrial market tends to move quite a bit slower. So that is ahead of us. What you will see is as the 28-nanometer grows, then the next growth sector, which is driven by the Zynq product line, will be a 16-nanometer, where we have a lot of design wins. You could assume that, that will follow a similar pattern to what we've seen at 28-. And this will drive our market expansion, it will just be delayed by 3 or 4 years, vis-Ã -vis what you saw at the 28-nanometer in terms of its significance. And that's the nature of the businesses we're in. They move at a slower rate. So as it's a new product line with the new role and the customer systems, it has now starting to be significant, but in the same way, the 28-nanometer took several years to get to where it is now. Zynq, which is a subset of that and was late with the last part of the product offering we rolled out is now starting to hit its stride market-by-market. And the next growth in 28- is going to be in automotive than by industrial, we actually see a lot of aerospace and defense growing going forward, and then we'll start seeing the 16-nanometer version. What I'd like for it to be faster? I would. But reality is that, that's the nature of the business we're in. Hope that answered your question.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Moshe, I kind of want to go back to the gross margins and given how high your gross margins are, it's a little silly to nit pick. But when I at that quarter just reported, you would've thought that both by end markets and geo that mix would've provided ac
componenttext: Moshe, I kind of want to go back to the gross margins and given how high your gross margins are, it's a little silly to nit pick. But when I at that quarter just reported, you would've thought that both by end markets and geo that mix would've provided actual headwinds to gross margin. You guys actually put out pretty good numbers. And I understand of a long-term target that you talked about at 68% to 70%. I'm just kind of curious as to why that is the long-term target, you feel like that's the gross margin level needed to drive year growth aspirations? I'm just kind of argument given the value you bring to customers, why shouldn't gross margins migrate up to that sort of low to mid-70s range permanently?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're right, it's a balance between growth and profitability, and we think we are striking in the right point here. We believe that we can, over time, generate more gross margin dollars if we stay at this level and not aspire to higher levels, that's the
componenttext: You're right, it's a balance between growth and profitability, and we think we are striking in the right point here. We believe that we can, over time, generate more gross margin dollars if we stay at this level and not aspire to higher levels, that's the trade-off that we are striving for at this point in time, and there's very few examples of that are sustainable at higher levels that can provide growth and one of the things that we want to do is to deliver the 6% growth on average over the next few years. And so that's what we are targeting at this point in time.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you're major competitor was acquired a while ago. So I wondering if you can maybe go some perspective on has anything changed over there hasn't been about as you would've expected anything different going on across the way?
componenttext: So you're major competitor was acquired a while ago. So I wondering if you can maybe go some perspective on has anything changed over there hasn't been about as you would've expected anything different going on across the way?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we are definitely focused on our execution. What we are seeing is we seem to be very far ahead. We were far ahead on 28-, definitely very far ahead in 20- and we appear to clearly have this one-plus year advantage on 16- versus their offering. We ar
componenttext: Well, we are definitely focused on our execution. What we are seeing is we seem to be very far ahead. We were far ahead on 28-, definitely very far ahead in 20- and we appear to clearly have this one-plus year advantage on 16- versus their offering. We are pursuing this with gusto. I think, that by the end of the year, it will be clear how Intel will decide to maximize their return on the $17 billion investment. But at this point in time, I would say that the -- as I check with our sales force, they appear to be winning based on the very strong technology portfolio, both on the silicon and the software and IP that we have. And at that is a multi-year investments we have made, which has come to fruition now. And I believe that most of the success we're seeing now is a result of that as opposed to anything else. I do believe the jury is still out with regards to how Intel will pursue the market long-term. There are various options that they have from which we make more sense to them than the others. But when you look at the consumer base, we're seeing consumer base becoming more and more interested as this [indiscernible] consolidation in the semiconductor industry, which everyone, including ourself, commented on numerous times. The customers are recognizing that they need to align with companies who are around and are committed to perpetuating their model. And that, I believe, has benefited as over the past year. And it's becoming clear and clear that we are committed to this business and be committed to technology leadership. And I think that's the other thing, which may be has changed in the competitive environment is actually, the customer's approaches quite different, and that's not only due to Intel, but it's due to other things that has happened in the industry, which are highlighting that there are fewer and fewer players who are going to be around the advanced nodes and [indiscernible] that it can and it will do that and our increased investments is another proof point that we're going to be there for them. Any more questions?

componenttext: I just wanted to follow up back on that Moshe. Obviously, you can see the timing of your products, and it does appear that you have a lead. I guess, when you look at the results, you still get them from your competitor, they're growing a little faster year-over-year, and obviously it's hard you had to get a little broader period here. Just kind curious, at this point 28- and 20- should be contributing outperformance. So I was just curious to your perspective as to why that hasn't shown up yet and when do you think you should be able to see some outperformance from this [indiscernible]

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Blayne, the numbers, the competitive numbers are very sparse. There's one number, there's no breakdown, there's lots of things that can be done, there is no understanding if it's new nodes or old nodes, right? And all I can say is we knew we've grown o
componenttext: So Blayne, the numbers, the competitive numbers are very sparse. There's one number, there's no breakdown, there's lots of things that can be done, there is no understanding if it's new nodes or old nodes, right? And all I can say is we knew we've grown our advanced products 60% year-over-year, that's 28-, 20- and 16-. That's -- And that's what is happening. The old nodes are now contracting in the contraction. There contracting at a slower level than they had been in the past, so what we think of the headwinds from that is going to be slower. And what we're seeing is massive growth of our new technology and massive set of design wins and very close alignment from the customer. So I don't -- I think all of the data, which is available, is such that indicate that Zynq continues to do extremely well. And I think it's -- if there's a huge breakdown, we could -- more detailed breakdown, we could tell, right? But in fact, this is great in terms of technology leadership and in terms -- and it's great in terms of revenue growth that these new nodes, and that's what matters for us. So that's -- it's going to be more and more difficult to do meaningful comparison going forward. But we're very comfortable with our position, we're very comfortable with the absolute results we're delivering and we very comfortable that our market share on new nodes, now for 3 nodes in a row, is substantially, and that is substantially above the natural market share in the past. The analysis of that and what the outcome is, is pretty clear.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Lorenzo Flores, CFO, who will provide a financial and business review of the June quarter, and then we'll open the call for questions. During the quarter, we reclassified our product c
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Lorenzo Flores, CFO, who will provide a financial and business review of the June quarter, and then we'll open the call for questions. 
During the quarter, we reclassified our product categories to be consistent with how these categories are analyzed and reviewed internally. Specifically, we are grouping the products manufactured at the 28-, 20- and 16-nanometer nodes into a category named advanced products, while all other products will be included in a category entitled core products. This representation is consistent with what was presented at our recent Analyst Meeting. For comparative purposes, we have provided supplemental information on our website at www.investor.xilinx.com that presents results based on previous classifications. 
Let me remind everyone that during our conference call today, we may make projections or other forward-looking statements regarding future events or the future financial performance of the company. We wish to caution you that such statements are predictions based on information that is currently available, and actual results may differ materially. We refer you to documents the company files with the SEC, including our 10-Ks, 10-Qs and 8-Ks. These documents contain and identify important risk factors that could cause the actual results to differ materially from those contained in our projections or forward-looking statements.
This conference call is open to all and is being webcast live. It can be accessed from our Xilinx Investor Relations website. Let me now turn the call over to Lorenzo.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rick. In the June quarter, Xilinx sales were $575 million, up 1% sequentially and up 5% on a year-over-year basis. Advanced products increased 10% sequentially and 60% year-over-year, with 28-nanometer and 20-nanometer products each reaching re
componenttext:
Thank you, Rick. In the June quarter, Xilinx sales were $575 million, up 1% sequentially and up 5% on a year-over-year basis. Advanced products increased 10% sequentially and 60% year-over-year, with 28-nanometer and 20-nanometer products each reaching record sales and 16-nanometer beginning it's revenue ramp. 
As expected, core products declined on a sequential and year-over-year basis. Communications increased 4% sequentially, with growth from both wired and wireless. Communications has stayed a modest but consistent recovery since bottoming in the June quarter a year ago and is up 22% on a year-over-year basis. 
Industrial and A&D was down slightly, with strength in test measurement and emulation not quite offsetting expected declines in industrial and aerospace and defense. 
Broadcast, consumer and automotive was flat on a sequential basis, slightly better than anticipated due to stronger orders from Zynq-driven ADAS applications. Both automotive and test and measurement reached record levels for the company in the June quarter. 
Gross margin in Q1 was 70.7%, higher than guided due to the mix of customers and products in addition to increased manufacturing efficiencies. We continue to aggressively optimize gross margin across our product portfolio. 
Operating expense at $220 million was in line with our guidance. Operating income for the quarter was $186 million or 32.4%. Other income and expense was an expense of $5 million as guided. 
The tax rate was 10% for the quarter, better than guided. This included the impact of the early adoption of an accounting standard related to the treatment of stock-based compensation. Our net income for Q1 was $163 million or $0.61 a share. This included a positive $0.02 a share impact associated with the accounting standard I just referenced. 
Operating cash flow was $339 million, driven primarily by strong profitability and a significant reduction in accounts receivable. Diluted shares were $266 million, including $10.5 million from the convertible. 
During the quarter, we repurchased 2.2 million shares for $100 million, and we paid $84 million in dividends. 
Some key points on the balance sheet. We ended the quarter with $3.7 billion in gross cash and $2.1 billion net cash after our debt. Inventory was $195 million, up $17 million from the prior quarter and down $27 million from the same quarter a year ago. We continued to manage our inventory by balancing levels against expected demand and potential upsides from customers. 
Accounts receivable declined $90 million to $217 million, reflecting ordering patterns during the quarter. 
Now turning to our September quarter guidance. We expect revenue to be approximately flat. We entered the quarter with backlog that is down sequentially, but we have forecasted demand from key customers that is not currently reflected in our backlog. As a result, we expect turns for the quarter to be approximately 54%. We expect advanced products to continue to grow, with 28-nanometer sales increasing to a new record, 20-nanometer exceeding $40 million and our 16-nanometer UltraScale+ family demonstrating material growth. 
With respect to end markets, communications and data center is expected to decline after 4 consecutive quarters of growth. An increase in wired business will not completely offset a decrease in wireless sales. Industrial and A&D is expected to grow, driven primarily by strength in test measurement and emulation, along with growth in aerospace and defense and ISM. Broadcast, consumer and -- broadcast, automotive and consumer will be flat sequentially. 
Our gross margin will be approximately 70%, and our operating expense will be approximately $230 million, including $1 million of amortization. The increase in operating expense is in line with the investment in accelerating our leadership position as we discussed at our Analyst Day. 
Other income and expense will be an expense of $4 million, and our tax rate is expected to be 14%. Share count is expected to be $266 million. 
Finally, at our Analyst Day in May, we discussed our expectations for 4% to 8% growth in revenue for FY '17, along with gross margins in the 68% to 70% range and the accelerated investment I just mentioned. As we end our first quarter, we believe we are on track on all of these elements. 
Let me now turn the call over to Moshe.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lorenzo. [indiscernible] with the financial results of the first quarter. We delivered revenue growth which was above the midpoint of our guidance, and profitability was very strong. Our overall revenue growth was driven by sales of our advance
componenttext:
Thank you, Lorenzo. [indiscernible] with the financial results of the first quarter. We delivered revenue growth which was above the midpoint of our guidance, and profitability was very strong. Our overall revenue growth was driven by sales of our advanced products, which increased 60% year-over-year and reached a new quarterly record. Overall, this demonstrated the strength of our diversified multi-market portfolio, with 5 of our 8 end markets growing in the quarter. 
Gross margin reached 70.7% resulting in an operating margin of 32.4%, the highest level in a year. We generated a record level of cash in the quarter, continued to demonstrate a commitment to shareholder return through both dividend and share repurchase. Our exceptional execution on the 28-, 20- and 16-nanometer nodes has now delivered 3 consecutive generations of unquestionable technology leadership. This is a testament to the success of our engineering and operations teams working in concert with our world-class, industry-leading foundry partner, TSMC. 
The June quarter, for the third quarter in a row, our overall 28-nanometer sales delivered a new record. The overall 28-nanometer sales growth benefited from broad sales contribution from communications, industrial, automotive, test and measurement and consumer. In addition, our Zynq product family, a significant element of our market expansion efforts, reached a new sales record in the June quarter. Overall, 28-nanometer sales, including our Zynq offering, are expected to grow again in the September quarter. 
20-nanometer revenue, again, reached a record level as sales in the quarter significantly exceeded our $30 million forecast. Virtex UltraScale, the industry's only high-end 20-nanometer product offering, continues to grow at a very significant rate, as do sales from our Kintex UltraScale product family. We expect to ship over $40 million of 20-nanometer product in the September quarter. This accelerated 20-nanometer ramp continues to exceed our original expectations. 
At the 16-nanometer node, we have delivered all 3 UltraScale+ product families ahead of schedule. We are already shipping 6 unique products to well over 100 customers and getting excellent feedback, in particular, with regards to its production level quality, further extending our industry lead to well over a year. Consequently, we are accelerating our 16-nanometer tapeouts schedules and broadening our offering at this node. This broad 16-nanometer product offering is being designed into applications in all of our major end markets and is enabling more platform-based designs than any previous generation. 
These advanced products are building significant momentum, enabled by 4 multi-market industry growth drivers: cloud computing, embedded vision, industrial IoT and 5G wireless. 
In cloud computing, we are in production with 3 of the largest hyperscale data center customers, with 2 more in extensive trials. Additionally, we led the formation of the very broad CCIX consortium with the singular role of bringing a high-performance, open acceleration framework to data centers. We're winning in fast-growing embedded vision applications across numerous markets, including industrial, aerospace and defense, automotive, broadcast and consumer. In particular, our ADAS penetration in automotive will reach 85 models this year. 
With regards to industrial IoT, we're seeing continued success with both Zynq and Zynq UltraScale+ families, securing platform design wins with the largest Tier 1 players. 
Lastly, in 5G wireless, we have 90% market share in pre-5G proof-of-concept deployments and 5G prototyping. We have attained an unprecedented position of strength, opportunity and momentum. This is driven by our exceptional execution, leadership product and customer adoption in the 4 multi-market drivers, which will fuel long-term revenue growth. We are committed to maintaining this leadership while delivering 30%-plus operating margin in the long term and continuing a strong commitment to shareholder return. 
Now I'll turn the call back to the operator for Q&A.
