componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Ian Ing.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Intel last week talked about being on track to ship Stratix 10 to customers some samples this year. Obviously, you already shipped last year. Any thoughts in terms of what the potential share split is, given the timing of product in customer's hands --
componenttext: So Intel last week talked about being on track to ship Stratix 10 to customers some samples this year. Obviously, you already shipped last year. Any thoughts in terms of what the potential share split is, given the timing of product in customer's hands -- perhaps some boundaries around the share splits?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We can say that being more than a year ahead is tremendous benefit. Having the broadest product offering is a tremendous benefit. Having production level material faster than we've ever achieved before is a tremendous benefit. And that's why we're investi
componenttext: We can say that being more than a year ahead is tremendous benefit. Having the broadest product offering is a tremendous benefit. Having production level material faster than we've ever achieved before is a tremendous benefit. And that's why we're investing to exploit the leadership we have. So we have no idea how it will turn out, but this is the strongest position we've ever had over the past 3 nodes.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from the line of David Wong.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: What were your total revenues from Zynq in the quarter? And what are currently the biggest end markets for Zynq?
componenttext: What were your total revenues from Zynq in the quarter? And what are currently the biggest end markets for Zynq?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Zynq, give me a second. Well, let me start with the end markets for Zynq. The Zynq end markets, I think the showcase end market for Zynq is really automotive ADAS applications. The product is strong in wireless as well in many different applications an
componenttext: So Zynq, give me a second. Well, let me start with the end markets for Zynq. The Zynq end markets, I think the showcase end market for Zynq is really automotive ADAS applications. The product is strong in wireless as well in many different applications and is also leading the industrial IoT platform wins that we have. We think it's a little bit in the, what we call it, as a percent of our total revenue, 8% or so of our total revenue in Zynq and continues to grow strongly quarter-on-quarter and year-on-year.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from the line of William Stein.
componenttext: And our next question is from the line of William Stein.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Moshe, you talked about the CCIX at the Analyst Day, and you mentioned it again today. Can you sort of frame the current impact or expected impact of this? Are there products that are relevant to this consortium? Is there any revenue or customer interest?
componenttext: Moshe, you talked about the CCIX at the Analyst Day, and you mentioned it again today. Can you sort of frame the current impact or expected impact of this? Are there products that are relevant to this consortium? Is there any revenue or customer interest? Any details would be helpful.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So this is a market, which, today, is dominated by Intel's very strong position on the server space. It's a market which is fast emerging. It's expected to be a very large market going forward, and the expectation is it will get split between additi
componenttext: Okay. So this is a market, which, today, is dominated by Intel's very strong position on the server space. It's a market which is fast emerging. It's expected to be a very large market going forward, and the expectation is it will get split between additional players as competitive products are available from these players. Now these come from a variety of architectures. They can come from x86 solutions. They can come from power-based solutions, and then they can come from the numerous players who are committed to the ARM architecture. Those additional ones are still to emerge at a performance level, which will enable them to penetrate the market. CCIX is basically an opportunity, which now has been identified by all of these other players as the need to have a common interface standard that all can integrate and support. The -- from our perspective, we did, at the Analyst Meeting, talk about one product, at least conceptually, which targets this market, which will be implemented in 16-nanometer. And then we'll have our traditional All-Programmable Devices at 16- and also a whole host of solutions at 7-nanometer that address the markets. For us, we believe this has the potential of being several hundred million dollars in the 2020 time frame. In order to get to that point, it was really essential to have this multi-partner opportunity -- open multi-partner opportunity in order to enable us to participate broadly in it. And so at this point in time, our revenue in data center does not yet comprehend this opportunity. It's more in traditional storage and networking data center applications. Over the next few years, we expect our business to grow to reflect that. So that's about as much information as I can give at this point in time. I hope it helps.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. If I can get a follow-up, in server acceleration in the data center, there's discussion not only of FPGA being helpful here but also GPU, and I'm wondering if you view that as a stable competitive environment or if the dynamics there are c
componenttext: That's helpful. If I can get a follow-up, in server acceleration in the data center, there's discussion not only of FPGA being helpful here but also GPU, and I'm wondering if you view that as a stable competitive environment or if the dynamics there are changing.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as I said, this is an emerging opportunity. And as such, the historic position is clearly led by Intel, and that's driven off their server and high-performance strength. NVIDIA definitely identified several years ago that this is an opportunity, and th
componenttext: So as I said, this is an emerging opportunity. And as such, the historic position is clearly led by Intel, and that's driven off their server and high-performance strength. NVIDIA definitely identified several years ago that this is an opportunity, and they have invested heavily. And we believe that there is a host of applications which are served well by a GPU solution, but that is a subset and not a particularly dominant subset of the future applications that will use this. And so we do expect this market, which is a large market and will grow rapidly over the next few years, to be serviced by numerous solutions from numerous players. GPUs definitely will be one, but they have a whole host of applications where, due to power and a whole host of other issues, they don't provide an optimum solution. And programmable logic, actually, can provide much higher performance per -- watt per dollar, the most -- the best solution in that regard. And that's why we're talking to all 7 major hyperscale players and a few other players, too. And we believe that our solution will have value for a whole host of these new applications. Having said that, we expect that GPUs will continue to do well in this market, too.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from the line of Chris Danely.
componenttext: And our next question is from the line of Chris Danely.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a clarification on the yearly guidance, so you're sticking with the guidance provided at the Analyst Day. On the gross margin, could it be 70% for the next couple of quarters? And then on the OpEx, are you still saying that SG&A is going to be flat a
componenttext: Just a clarification on the yearly guidance, so you're sticking with the guidance provided at the Analyst Day. On the gross margin, could it be 70% for the next couple of quarters? And then on the OpEx, are you still saying that SG&A is going to be flat and that the 7% to 9% growth is all R&D?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll start backwards. On OpEx, the -- that guidance is essentially true. We can see, plus or minus, a couple of million dollars. But in aggregate, the expense growth is R&D. On gross margin, I'm not going to go into specific guidance for the second hal
componenttext: So I'll start backwards. On OpEx, the -- that guidance is essentially true. We can see, plus or minus, a couple of million dollars. But in aggregate, the expense growth is R&D. On gross margin, I'm not going to go into specific guidance for the second half. The 68% to 70% range for the year that we provided at the Analyst Day conference of a few different scenarios about how the actual revenue product and customer mix would come out, and so I think we're comfortable leaving that range.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from the line of Ross Seymore.
componenttext: And our next question is from the line of Ross Seymore.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question from the end market side, I think in your communications and data center side. How did that 44% of revenues -- can you remind us the split between wireless and wireline? And to the extent the wireless side is falling off, how do you view w
componenttext: Just a question from the end market side, I think in your communications and data center side. How did that 44% of revenues -- can you remind us the split between wireless and wireline? And to the extent the wireless side is falling off, how do you view where we are in the wireless market? Obviously, a year ago, you had a huge inventory drawdown and then you've grown nicely since then. Is that inventory refill back to a normalized level? And will we ship with demand from here forward? And if so, what are your views on demand?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if you look at communications and you break it down between wired and wireless, what happens is they tend to have different characteristics. Wireless tends to be more choppy. Wired tends to be more gradual in terms of its growth. What we've seen is on
componenttext: So if you look at communications and you break it down between wired and wireless, what happens is they tend to have different characteristics. Wireless tends to be more choppy. Wired tends to be more gradual in terms of its growth. What we've seen is on the wired side, basically driven by very strong technology portfolio. That business has been growing now consistently and, in particular, it's being driven by 28- and 20-nanometer shipments. On the wireless side, it is volatile. It had its ebb, its lowest point in the June quarter of last year. And since then, it has recovered. It's grown by about 40% since that low point. It hasn't gotten back to its peak, and we don't necessarily expect it to get back to its peak. Its peak was about 2x higher than its low point, but it's hovering just about in the middle. And we expect it to continue to go up and down but more around this new number, right, as opposed to the low point, and it will be based on deployments. During the past quarter, China was steady, India was up, EMEA was weak, North America was steady. It sort of tends to change from quarter-to-quarter as the deployments are -- geographically spreads around the world, but we do expect communications generally to continue to grow. And if you can neutralize the wireless volatility or sort of flatten it out, we do see that the communications market overall, including data center, to be a long-term growth driver for us. Next question, please.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from the line of Vivek Arya.
componenttext: And our next question is from the line of Vivek Arya.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Moshe, thanks for the color around the wireless business. I had one follow-up to that. If you look at your content in a basestation today, how does it compare to what you had the year before or the year before that? I understand the volatility in deployme
componenttext: Moshe, thanks for the color around the wireless business. I had one follow-up to that. If you look at your content in a basestation today, how does it compare to what you had the year before or the year before that? I understand the volatility in deployments. But over a longer period of time when I look at the low growth in this communications business, for not just yourself but for your competitor as well, has it been a unit issue? Or has it been a content issue? But yes, unit had been volatile, but is it possible that content has not grown at the same pace? And any color around that would be very useful.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So from generation to generation, the level of integration is much higher, and the power-reduction requirements are becoming more and more significant. And as such, we're seeing a higher level of integration, and our customers are moving to the high
componenttext: Okay. So from generation to generation, the level of integration is much higher, and the power-reduction requirements are becoming more and more significant. And as such, we're seeing a higher level of integration, and our customers are moving to the higher end of a product offering. It's still -- it's not the high end. It's not Virtex products, but it's Kintex and Zynq products. And generally speaking, the percentage of the dollar content, which is implemented in programmable logic, be it Zynq or be it a all-programmable solution, has gone up from generation to generation. What we're seeing -- and so if you look at the numbers, on average, 4G was higher than 3G. Best we can tell, 5G is an incredibly sophisticated requirement with -- and as we're being used in a vast majority of the early deployments, these are not going to be the massive deployments, those are still 3 or 4 years ahead of us, but we're sort of seeing the level of complexity is very high. And then unquestionably, the level of integration is high. And I would say, generally speaking, the average price that we realize has gone up with a significantly higher level of functionality. The volatility is due to markets happening at different rates, in particular, China is very difficult to predict. And -- but I wouldn't say that, overall, we've seen the dollar content shrink at all. We've -- it's gone the other way at this point per unit.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from the line of Tristan Gerra.
componenttext: And our next question is from the line of Tristan Gerra.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you elaborate a little bit on the operational efficiencies and mix? I know you're not providing a gross margin guidance beyond this current quarter, but if you could explain a little bit what's happening in terms of operational efficiencies and whet
componenttext: Could you elaborate a little bit on the operational efficiencies and mix? I know you're not providing a gross margin guidance beyond this current quarter, but if you could explain a little bit what's happening in terms of operational efficiencies and whether there's a lasting effect that we can expect beyond this coming quarter.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So Tristan, as you know, the gross margin has direct price, direct costs and manufacturing overhead type of components that drive it. And we have a portfolio of customers, a portfolio of end markets, and the customers all take a -- take, in those e
componenttext: Right. So Tristan, as you know, the gross margin has direct price, direct costs and manufacturing overhead type of components that drive it. And we have a portfolio of customers, a portfolio of end markets, and the customers all take a -- take, in those end markets, a portfolio of different products. So what we see across the board is a continued drive toward manufacturing side efficiencies, getting our products at lower cost over time. We see continued price pressure from our customers across the board; in larger customers, obviously assert more price pressure. And we just -- we try to balance that and continue to get the broad savings to manifest themselves in our overall gross margin. On the overhead side, that will swing from time to time with different factors and what we're doing with inventory strategy. But in general, we're approaching manufacturing efficiencies there very, very aggressively as well. So the -- as it's common in the semiconductor industry, costs continue to go down, but price pressure continues to increase. And we, again, try to manage that through the broad portfolio that we have.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to sort of summarize, because Lorenzo gave you all of the data without answering the question, we think the 68% to 70% will continue to be in the foreseeable future where we are. Could we, from time to time, as we are now just rise above that? Ye
componenttext: And just to sort of summarize, because Lorenzo gave you all of the data without answering the question, we think the 68% to 70% will continue to be in the foreseeable future where we are. Could we, from time to time, as we are now just rise above that? Yes, but that is neither our target nor do we think that it's a sustainable goal going forward.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from the line of Ambrish Srivastava.
componenttext: And our next question is from the line of Ambrish Srivastava.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've talked about communications. I was wondering if you could talk about the other end markets. And specifically, embedded in your guidance, what are the -- how are these end markets behaving versus what you would normally expect, if there is any such t
componenttext: We've talked about communications. I was wondering if you could talk about the other end markets. And specifically, embedded in your guidance, what are the -- how are these end markets behaving versus what you would normally expect, if there is any such thing as normal in the semi industry. That would be helpful if you could provide us with some extra additional color on the other major end markets.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So Ambrish, we break it down into 8 markets overall, and we're very pleased that we hit above the midpoint. But if you look at the growth overall, it was not huge. It was driven by 5 of the 8 markets. I think we highlighted which those were in terms
componenttext: Okay. So Ambrish, we break it down into 8 markets overall, and we're very pleased that we hit above the midpoint. But if you look at the growth overall, it was not huge. It was driven by 5 of the 8 markets. I think we highlighted which those were in terms of the past product. And it's wired and wireless were up, automotive was up, consumer was up and test, yes, test was up quite significantly. Going forward, we're looking at flat, right? So there's probably going to be some up and some down, and I cannot at this point in time. But as you look into the second half of the year, if I had to guess, we do expect communications to continue to grow slightly. We expect A&D to be flat. We expect automotive to be up significantly, driven by the large number of design wins we have. And we expect ISM also to get back into a growth mode. So that's the best forecast we can give your for the second half based on what we know now. And just for the upcoming quarter, I think Lorenzo gave some of our prognostication there. Next question, please.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question is from the line of Anil Doradla.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question is from the line of Anil Doradla.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Moshe, I think you referred to Zynq contributing about 8% of revenues right now. A little surprised. I thought they would be higher, might be in double digits. Now is this contribution volatile, or it's been pretty much in the kind of the high single d
componenttext: So Moshe, I think you referred to Zynq contributing about 8% of revenues right now. A little surprised. I thought they would be higher, might be in double digits. Now is this contribution volatile, or it's been pretty much in the kind of the high single digits over the last couple of quarters?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Anil, I think we were quite clear in the past. You sort of -- if you look at our entire offering, there's several generations that are now contributing. The first generation where there was a Zynq product line was the 28-nanometer, and that's providing
componenttext: So Anil, I think we were quite clear in the past. You sort of -- if you look at our entire offering, there's several generations that are now contributing. The first generation where there was a Zynq product line was the 28-nanometer, and that's providing nearly all of that number. It's driven by 3 markets as Lorenzo mentioned: wireless, automotive and industrial market. Of those 3, wireless has gone into production. Automotive is going into production and should grow very rapidly. And the industrial market tends to move quite a bit slower. So that is ahead of us. What you will see is as the 28-nanometer grows, then the next growth vector, which is driven by the Zynq product line, will be a 16-nanometer where we have a lot of design wins. You could assume that, that will follow a similar pattern to what we've seen at 28. So -- and this will drive our market expansion. It will just be delayed by 3 or 4 years vis-Ã -vis what you saw at the 28-nanometer in terms of its significance. And that's the nature of the businesses we're in. They move at a slower rate. So as it's a new product line with a new role in the customer systems, it has now starting to be significant. But in the same way, the 28-nanometer took several years to get to where it is now. Zynq, which is a subset of that and was late with the last part of the product offering we rolled out, is now starting to hit its stride market by market. And the next growth in 28 is going to be in automotive, then by industrial. We actually see a lot of aerospace and defense growing going forward, and then we'll start seeing the 16-nanometer version. Would I like for it to be faster? I would. But reality is that's the nature of the business we're in. Hope that answered your question.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is Romit Shah.
componenttext: Our next question is Romit Shah.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Krysten Sciacca in for Romit. So my question is more on the automotive side. Even though we've had some strong results from the automotive [indiscernible] so far this earnings season. I think we're still seeing some concern about declining vehicle
componenttext: This is Krysten Sciacca in for Romit. So my question is more on the automotive side. Even though we've had some strong results from the automotive [indiscernible] so far this earnings season. I think we're still seeing some concern about declining vehicle unit starts [ph]. Are you seeing any weakening in our auto unit demand in the coming quarters? Or do you think demand is going to hold steady?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the -- we are expanding both the footprint we have in terms of the models that includes Xilinx-based ADAS systems, and those -- as well as the depth continuing to move from premium to mid-tier to lower tier in terms of the offerings. So the unit growth
componenttext: So the -- we are expanding both the footprint we have in terms of the models that includes Xilinx-based ADAS systems, and those -- as well as the depth continuing to move from premium to mid-tier to lower tier in terms of the offerings. So the unit growth is going to be less of an impact to us than overall penetration and expansion. That, as Moshe said earlier, will show us a significant growth in the automotive business for us through the year.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of John Pitzer.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of John Pitzer.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Moshe, I kind of want to go back to the gross margins. And given how high your gross margins are, it's a little silly to nitpick. But when I look at that quarter just reported, you would've thought that both by end market and geo, that mix would've provid
componenttext: Moshe, I kind of want to go back to the gross margins. And given how high your gross margins are, it's a little silly to nitpick. But when I look at that quarter just reported, you would've thought that both by end market and geo, that mix would've provided actual headwinds to gross margin. You guys actually put up really good numbers. And I understand the long-term target that you talked about of 68% to 70%. I'm just kind of curious as to why that is the long-term target. Do you feel like that's the gross margin level needed to drive your growth aspirations? I'm just kind of arguing. Given the value you bring to customers, why shouldn't gross margins migrate up to that sort of low to mid-70s range permanently?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're right. It's a balance between growth and profitability, and we think we are striking the right point here with -- we believe that we can, over time, generate more gross margin dollars if we stay at this level and not aspire to higher levels. And th
componenttext: You're right. It's a balance between growth and profitability, and we think we are striking the right point here with -- we believe that we can, over time, generate more gross margin dollars if we stay at this level and not aspire to higher levels. And that's the trade-off that we are striving for at this point in time, and there's very few examples that are sustainable at higher levels that can provide growth. And one of the things we want to do is to deliver the 6% growth on average over the next few years, and so that's what we are targeting at this point in time.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from the line of Ian Ing with a follow-up.
componenttext: And our next question is from the line of Ian Ing with a follow-up.

componenttext: Apologize if this was asked, but turns higher in September because, like key customers are giving you forecast instead of firm orders. Did you talk more about the applications there? And what gives you confidence those forecast will become orders actually?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I won't talk about the specific customers or applications, but we have done extensive work in identifying the additional orders that we expect come in this quarter to hit our revenue guidance. And we have confidence that we -- those will come in.
componenttext: So I won't talk about the specific customers or applications, but we have done extensive work in identifying the additional orders that we expect come in this quarter to hit our revenue guidance. And we have confidence that we -- those will come in.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question is another follow-up from Chris Danely.
componenttext: And our next question is another follow-up from Chris Danely.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So your major competitor was acquired a while ago. I was just wondering if you can maybe give us some perspective on -- has anything changed over there? Has it been about as you would've expected? Anything different going on across the way?
componenttext: So your major competitor was acquired a while ago. I was just wondering if you can maybe give us some perspective on -- has anything changed over there? Has it been about as you would've expected? Anything different going on across the way?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we are definitely focused on our execution. What we are seeing is we seem to be very far ahead. We were far ahead on 28, definitely very far ahead on 20, and we appear to clearly have this 1-plus-year advantage on 16 versus their offering. We are pu
componenttext: Well, we are definitely focused on our execution. What we are seeing is we seem to be very far ahead. We were far ahead on 28, definitely very far ahead on 20, and we appear to clearly have this 1-plus-year advantage on 16 versus their offering. We are pursuing this with gusto. I think that by the end of the year, it will be clear how Intel will decide to maximize their return on the $17 billion investment. And -- but at this point in time, I would say that the -- as I check with our sales force, they appear to be winning based on the very strong technology portfolio, both on the silicon and the software and the IP that we have. And that is a multi-year investment we have made, which has come to fruition now. And I believe that most of the success we're seeing now is a result of that as opposed to anything else. I do believe the jury is still out with regards to how Intel will pursue the market long term. There are various options they have, some of which may make more sense to them than the others. But when you look at the customer base, we're seeing the customer base becoming more and more interested as there's massive consolidation in the semiconductor industry, which everyone, including yourself, have commented on numerous times. The customers are recognizing that they need to align with companies who are around and are committed to perpetuating their model. And that, I believe, has benefited us over the past year. And it's become clearer and clearer that we're committed to this business, and we're committed to technology leadership. And I think that's the other thing, which maybe has changed in the competitive environment, is actually the customer's approach is quite different. And that's not only due to Intel, but it's due to other things that have happened in the industry, which are highlighting that there are fewer and fewer players who are going to be around the advanced nodes. And Xilinx has demonstrated that it can and will do that, and our increased investment is another proof point that we're going to be there for them. Any more questions?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: I just wanted to follow up back on that Moshe. Obviously, you can see the timing of your products, and it does appear that you have a lead. I guess, when you look at the results and you still get them from your competitor, they're growing a little faster year-over-year. And obviously, it's hard. You have to look at a broader period here. I'm just kind curious, at this point, 28 and 20 should be contributing some outperformance. So you're in the weeds. They're just kind of curious to your perspective as to why that hasn't shown up yet. And when do you think you should be able to see some outperformance from this year again?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Blayne, the numbers -- the competitive numbers are very sparse. There's one number. There's no breakdown. There's lots of things that can be done. There is no understanding if it's new nodes or old nodes, right? And I can -- all I can say is we knew we
componenttext: So Blayne, the numbers -- the competitive numbers are very sparse. There's one number. There's no breakdown. There's lots of things that can be done. There is no understanding if it's new nodes or old nodes, right? And I can -- all I can say is we knew we've grown our advanced products 60% year-over-year. That's 28, 20 and 16. That's -- so -- and that's what is happening. The old nodes are now contracting in the contraction phase. They're contracting at a slower level than they have -- had been in the past. So we think that the headwinds from that is going to be slower, and what we're seeing is massive growth of our new technology and massive sets of design wins and very close alignment from the customer. So I don't -- I think all of the data, which is available, is such that indicate that Xilinx continues to do extremely well. And I think it's -- if there was a huge breakdown, we could -- more detailed breakdown, we could tell, right? But in fact, this is great in terms of technology leadership and in terms -- and it's great in terms of revenue growth of these new nodes, and that's what matters for us. So that's -- it's going to be more and more difficult to do meaningful comparison going forward, but we're very comfortable with our position. We're very comfortable with the absolute results we're delivering, and we're very comfortable that our market share on new nodes, now for 3 nodes in a row, is substantially, and that is substantially above the natural market share in the past. The analysis of that and what the outcome is, is pretty clear.

componenttext:
Good afternoon. My name is Marianna [ph], and I will be your conference operator today. I would like to welcome everyone to the Xilinx Second Quarter Fiscal Year 2017 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Rick Muscha. Thank you.
Mr. Muscha, you may begin your conference.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Lorenzo Flores, CFO. We'll provide a financial and business review of the September quarter, and then we'll open the call for questions.Let me remind everyone that during our conferenc
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Lorenzo Flores, CFO. We'll provide a financial and business review of the September quarter, and then we'll open the call for questions.
Let me remind everyone that during our conference call today, we may make projections or other forward-looking statements regarding future events or the future financial performance of the company.
We wish to caution you that such statements are predictions based on information that is currently available and that actual results may differ materially.
We refer you to the documents the company files with the SEC, including our 10-Ks, 10-Qs and 8-Ks. These documents contain and identify important risk factors that could cause the actual results to differ materially from those contained in our projections or forward-looking statements.
This conference call is open to all and is being webcast live. It can be accessed from our Xilinx Investor Relations website.
Let me now turn the call over to Lorenzo.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rick. In the September quarter, Xilinx sales were $579 million, up 1% sequentially and up 10% on a year-over-year basis. Sales for the first 6 months of the fiscal year were up 7% versus the same period of the prior year. Our Advanced Products
componenttext:
Thank you, Rick. In the September quarter, Xilinx sales were $579 million, up 1% sequentially and up 10% on a year-over-year basis. Sales for the first 6 months of the fiscal year were up 7% versus the same period of the prior year. Our Advanced Products increased 10% sequentially and 61% year-over-year with 28-nanometer, 20-nanometer and 16-nanometer sales all reaching new records. Sales from our 16-nanometer UltraScale+ family were significant and exceeded our expectations.
Our sales in the September quarter demonstrated the resilience of our multi-market model. Growth in industrial and A&D and broadcast consumer and automotive [ph] categories more than offset the expected decline in communications.
The industrial on A&D category stood out with strength in test, measurement and emulation as well as aerospace and defense. [ph] 
In fact, sales from test measurement and emulation [ph] reached a record during the quarter. 
Broadcast, consumer and automotive was up slightly, better than expected, due primarily to strength from AVB.
Gross margin in Q2 was 69.6%, lower than guided due to the impact of a licensing agreement with Rambus. Moving forward, the impact of this agreement is expected to be immaterial to our gross margin.
Operating expense was $227 million, lower than guided due to lower compensation expenses.
Operating income for the quarter was $177 million or 30.5%.
Other income and expense was an expense of $1 million, lower than guided due primarily to an investment distribution.
The tax rate for the quarter was 7%, which included the previously disclosed benefit of $9 million or $0.03 per diluted share related to the closure of the audits of fiscal years 2012 through 2014 and a $0.02 per diluted share benefit related to other discrete tax items.
Our net income for Q2 was $164 million or $0.61 per share. Operating cash flow was $184 million. Diluted shares were $270 million, including $14.8 million from the convertible, higher than guided due to the impact of our higher share price. We repurchased 1.9 million shares for $100 million, and we paid $84 million in dividends. 
Now some key points on the balance sheet. We ended the quarter with $3.7 billion in gross cash and $2.1 billion in net cash after our debt. Inventory was $197 million, approximately flat with the prior quarter and down $16 million from the same quarter a year ago.
As I turn to our guidance, I would like to refresh the key points of the annual guidance from our Analyst Day in May. At the Analyst Day, we forecasted our revenue growth to be between 4% and 8%, our gross margin to be between 60% [ph] and 70% and our operating expense to be between $930 million and $950 million.
Our performance for the first 2 fiscal quarters, our guidance for Q3 and our expectations for Q4 indicate that we remain centered in the range of the guidance provided at our Analyst Meeting.
In the December quarter, we are expecting sales to be flat sequentially. Our backlog is slightly down heading into the quarter. We expect Advanced Products will continue to grow, and we are expecting communications [ph] to increase with both -- with growth in both wireless and wired.
Industrial and A&D is expected to decline as test and measurement comes off of 2 consecutive record quarters. Broadcast, consumer and automotive [ph] is expected to be approximately flat sequentially.
Our gross margin will be approximately 69%. For operating expense, we continue to invest in accelerating our leadership position as discussed at our Analyst Day. We expect to see operating expense increase to approximately $245 million with a significant portion of the increase coming from tape-out expenses.
Our operating expense outlook includes $1 million of amortization.
Other income and expense will be an expense of $2 million and will likely approximate this level again in Q4. Finally, our tax rate is expected to be 14%.
Now I'd like to say a few words on our capital allocation strategy. We are confident in our long-term growth strategy and expect to continue to generate healthy cash flows. Note our operating cash flow year-to-date exceeds $500 million. 
Our capital allocation priorities remain the same. Invest in our business that capitalize on our leadership position and return capital to our shareholders with a commitment to an increasing dividend over time and through share repurchases.
With respect to share repurchases, as we previously announced in May of this year, the Xilinx Board of Directors increased the repurchase authorization by $1 billion. Our plan is to take a more deliberate approach on share repurchases with the intention of exhausting the $1 billion authorization over the next several quarters.
Let me now turn the call over to Moshe.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lorenzo. I'm very pleased with the financial results in the second quarter. We delivered our fourth consecutive quarter of revenue growth resulting in operating profit in excess of 30% for the third consecutive quarter.Our overall revenue gro
componenttext:
Thank you, Lorenzo. I'm very pleased with the financial results in the second quarter. We delivered our fourth consecutive quarter of revenue growth resulting in operating profit in excess of 30% for the third consecutive quarter.
Our overall revenue growth was, as in the previous quarter, driven by our Advanced Products. These increased again by over 60% year-over-year, delivering yet another significant quarterly record and now accounts for 46% of our total sales. 
Overall, 5 of our 8 end markets grew in the quarter, demonstrating the robustness of our diversified multi-market portfolio.
Our unparalleled execution on the 28-, 20- and 16-nanometer nodes has now delivered three consecutive generations of very significant technology leadership.
Our world-class partnership with TSMC, a foundry technology [ph] and market leader, has been key to this success. In the September quarter, for the fourth consecutive quarter, 28-nanometer sales delivered a new record. 28-nanometer sales growth was enabled by our Zynq product line, which is a significant component of our market expansion efforts. Zynq product sales increased 25% sequentially driven by automotive, wireless, industrial and consumer applications. 20-nanometer revenue again reached a record level, very significantly exceeding our $40 million target.
Sales were driven by strong contributions from our test and measurement, wired and wireless [ph] markets. We expect to ship over $50 million of 20-nanometer products in the December quarter.
16-nanometer sales grew significantly in the September quarter, similarly exceeding our forecast while shipping to a broad base of end markets, including automotive, data center and communications. [ph] 
At our Analyst Day in May, we discussed a strategic increase in our R&D investment in fiscal year 2017 to both solidify our leadership position and expand our product portfolio.
We recently highlighted two significant accomplishments that demonstrate the early fruits [ph] from that investment decision. 
First and foremost, we reached ahead of schedule the critical production milestone with our 16-nanometer UltraScale+ portfolio, further expanding our product product sleeve [ph] to well beyond the year. We're already shipping 9 unique revenue generating products to approaching 200 active customers.
As per Lorenzo's earlier comments, we expect to deliver multiple production tape-outs in the current quarter to solidify this lead. In addition, we announced the expansion of our cost optimized Spartan, Altix and Zynq 28-nanometer product family, targeting a wide range of applications including embedded vision and industrial IoT.
We recently made two announcements illustrating our significant momentum in cloud computing, another of our key emerging market expansion opportunities.
Baidu has adopted Xilinx to accelerate machine learning applications in the data center and to leverage our platform in their initiatives to develop commercially viable autonomous cars.
In addition, the CCIX technology consortium, formed [ph] to bring a high-performance open acceleration framework to data centers, tripled its membership, as [ph] released the specification to consortium members.
We're uniquely positioned to capitalize on our excellent execution and innovative and game-changing products to both accelerate share gains and drive market expansion. We remain committed to maintaining and extending our leadership while delivering to our long-term operating margin target of 30%-plus, [ph] and per Lorenzo's earlier comments, underlying our commitment to returning cash to shareholders.
Let me now turn the call back to the operator for Q&A.

I hate talking about seasonality because there's so much variance around seasonality. But given the guide for the December quarter, that kind of implies the March quarter up about 6% versus seasonal of 3% [ph]. I wonder if you guys can just talk about if there's anything specific you're seeing maybe around the up 35 [ph] revenue stream or any other sort of new product revenue stream that gives you confidence as you look out that far that you have that kind of above seasonal growth?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So thanks, John. Obviously, as we close this quarter and we go into Q4, we'll be providing you with more specifics. But I think right now, what -- we will tell you that underneath our view of Q4 -- of our fiscal Q4 is a view that communications will
componenttext: Yes. So thanks, John. Obviously, as we close this quarter and we go into Q4, we'll be providing you with more specifics. But I think right now, what -- we will tell you that underneath our view of Q4 -- of our fiscal Q4 is a view that communications will be firming and we will see growth in the industrial and A&D [ph] category as well as the consumer automotive and broadcast [ph] category. Some for the reasons you're alluding to, but there's more out [ph] there than that.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then as my followup, guys, Moshe, the Baidu announcement was a nice announcement around acceleration. I wonder if you can help us understand kind of the opportunity there. Are you sitting next to Intel processors? And how do we think about the acceler
componenttext: And then as my followup, guys, Moshe, the Baidu announcement was a nice announcement around acceleration. I wonder if you can help us understand kind of the opportunity there. Are you sitting next to Intel processors? And how do we think about the acceleration sort of a growth developing in the near term because our thought process was that was perhaps going to be more a 2018, 2019 event relative to the Analyst Day you guys had earlier in the year. Seems like you're getting some of that earlier. Do you expect to see sort of additional follow-on here or is this going to be still something you expected to mature in the next couple of years instead of the next couple of quarters?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, it's next couple of years. It's not the next couple of quarters. We believe that this has the potential of being $200 million to $300 million by 2020, and it will have to grow to that number. It's not going to happen overnight and it won't happen ov
componenttext: John, it's next couple of years. It's not the next couple of quarters. We believe that this has the potential of being $200 million to $300 million by 2020, and it will have to grow to that number. It's not going to happen overnight and it won't happen over the next 6 months. It's going to take more than 6 months just for these devices to go into volume production. So this is a -- as most of our businesses, this grows a little faster, but it still will take time and will take several years until it gets to the several hundreds of millions of dollars. So the -- let's put it this way, this will not generate the Q4 upswing that you asked about earlier.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from Ambrish Srivastava with BMO.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So I think we've had questions over the past few months after we announced the board's authorization of an additional $1 billion in May about what our plans are. And I think in the past, we've characterized our approach to share repurchases as oppor
componenttext: Sure. So I think we've had questions over the past few months after we announced the board's authorization of an additional $1 billion in May about what our plans are. And I think in the past, we've characterized our approach to share repurchases as opportunistic, which is fairly ambiguous. What we're trying to communicate is we are -- we have the intent to utilize the authorization over, and I chose the word several -- next several quarters deliberately to indicate a rather more defined time span of when we're going to utilize the authorization.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my quick follow-up, Moshe. On the nodes, 16-nanometer. Where is the difference in this node versus what you've seen in the past? And Intel just announced their product and they said that they would be shipping for revenue. So just help us u
componenttext: Okay. And then my quick follow-up, Moshe. On the nodes, 16-nanometer. Where is the difference in this node versus what you've seen in the past? And Intel just announced their product and they said that they would be shipping for revenue. So just help us understand kind of where you are in terms of being, I think, over a year ahead versus them and then what kind of opportunities does it open for you. And if we just going back to the last node, it's clear at least to us that it opens up like a 65-35 kind of market share. So any help on the opportunity you're seeing versus the last node will be great.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Ambrish. So we taped [ph] it out in June of 2015. It came back in September of 2015. It was in such pristine condition that at that point in time, we were able to demonstrate devices working and achieving the specs, which for silicon [ph] immediatel
componenttext: Sure, Ambrish. So we taped [ph] it out in June of 2015. It came back in September of 2015. It was in such pristine condition that at that point in time, we were able to demonstrate devices working and achieving the specs, which for silicon [ph] immediately in the first day is as good as it gets and probably better than nearly everyone else. And we sampled the parts to our customers and we have been shipping them to numerous customers in a whole host of applications. And the feedback we're getting is between the software, the silicon and IP, [ph] customers have never seen from anyone, anything up to this level of functionality. And as a result, what we have done is we now have 9 products that are shipping and we're moving into production, and part of the bump that is happening this quarter, the current quarter we're in, in terms of R&D and the quarter after that will be a whole slew of tape-outs, [ph] which indicate that we're going to move into production at an early point. So in terms of sampling, we believe we are clearly a year ahead in terms of the maturity of the product. And from what we're hearing from our customers, we're much more than that. And that's the position we're in. It's a very enviable position and that's why we're increasing our investment to exploit it. Hopefully, that answers your question.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from William Stein with SunTrust.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Moshe, on the automotive side, can you remind us what's driving that growth today? And then turning to this autonomous driving agreement with Baidu, is that expected to drive Xilinx units in the vehicles? So for scoring or inference? Or is it more on the
componenttext: Moshe, on the automotive side, can you remind us what's driving that growth today? And then turning to this autonomous driving agreement with Baidu, is that expected to drive Xilinx units in the vehicles? So for scoring or inference? Or is it more on the deep learning side, not so much on the client side?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So our automotive business historically was more on the entertainment side. And I think product offering was defined specifically to address track [ph] resistance, and that is a huge step towards delivering autonomous vehicles. What is happening now
componenttext: Okay. So our automotive business historically was more on the entertainment side. And I think product offering was defined specifically to address track [ph] resistance, and that is a huge step towards delivering autonomous vehicles. What is happening now is the part that is growing is the advanced driver [ph] resistance and we actually shared that we expect to have 85 models in production in this year, and we remain on target for delivering those 85 models. If you noticed, I had mentioned that quite a bit of our early revenue on 16-nanometer was in automotive, and that comes from the second generation of our Zynq product, which is MPSoC. It's so more powerful element. Now in parallel to that, being in a [ph] position for this market, we are working on the next generation, which is the 7-nanometer product. And there, we expect that as the world moves to -- from driver systems [ph] to autonomous driving, we expect it to move in phases, there's question marks with regards to how quickly it will happen. There's a whole host of barriers regards to safety, security and legislation that will modulate and throttle that growth. And so we believe that a lot of the work is being done now and there's been a lot of early deployment. And what we're seeing is that, that market is expanding beyond the traditional suppliers between -- beyond the Tier 1 providers to those suppliers and there's a whole host of new players who are entering the market in addition and are deploying technologies, which they have developed for their data center applications. And so we expect this to continue to unfold, to be honest, over the next 10 years. We don't think it's going to -- all happen tomorrow. We do think there's going to be a lot of proof of concepts and very limited deployments over the next year or 2. But we think that the massive volume will actually come in the 7-nanometer in the 2020 and beyond time frame, and there will be a lot of different approaches. We believe that our technology and our solutions will be relevant to most, if not all of those targets, right? And there's quite a bit of fragmentation. There's a lot of different approaches there. But our technology fundamentally should be very viable to address all of those. And our early position with ADAS gives us good understanding, a good relationship to -- with the providers to address that market.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Vivek Arya with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Vivek Arya with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Moshe, this is sort of a longer-term question. The promise of FPGAs [ph] has been that there's a very long life to current generation and legacy products, and then you layer on growth from next generation. So certainly, your next generation is growing at
componenttext: Moshe, this is sort of a longer-term question. The promise of FPGAs [ph] has been that there's a very long life to current generation and legacy products, and then you layer on growth from next generation. So certainly, your next generation is growing at a very phenomenal phase. But when I look at your legacy or core products, they are declining at a mid-teens base or so. Is that different from what you have observed in the past, i.e., that the core products are declining faster than they had in the past or am I not looking at this the right way?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, you're looking at it right, and those numbers are difficult to argue with. I would say that first quarter effect is, are you winning, are you not winning at a certain node? And to be honest, the decline in the old product is because there's two signif
componenttext: No, you're looking at it right, and those numbers are difficult to argue with. I would say that first quarter effect is, are you winning, are you not winning at a certain node? And to be honest, the decline in the old product is because there's two significant generations where we did not do well, right? And if you look at the 40-nanometer, at the high end, we were late where the product had some issues. And prior to that, there's also a generation which had its challenges. And so as a result, that is now declining at a fast rate. The good news is now we have 3 nodes in a row that we've had great execution and significant market share. And because it takes a long time, and you're absolutely right in that, it takes time for that to compensate for the old nodes. The good news is once you get to 50%, right, and we're very close to that 50%, then you have a bigger, much stronger tailwind and the headwind is diminishing. And so what you should see is the percentage, which has the tailwind, is growing now at a faster rate and will soon reach magnitude that it can compensate and actually more than compensate for the product, which are not growing. And so your analysis is correct, but I think you need to take that first order [ph] impact is, did you have a good node or not have a good node. If you have 3 good nodes in succession and they are recent nodes, then once that gets to 50% of the revenue, that should more than compensate for the shrinkage of the old portion.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just as a quick follow-up. When I look at the growth rate that Intel has given for Altera, I understand that they're not giving too many details, but they're saying it's about similar to what you're targeting, which is about 6%, right, or
componenttext: Got it. And then just as a quick follow-up. When I look at the growth rate that Intel has given for Altera, I understand that they're not giving too many details, but they're saying it's about similar to what you're targeting, which is about 6%, right, or so. So is it that it is too early for us to see your share gains at some of these new nodes? Because if you have been gaining so much share at 28 and then 16 and at 20 nanometers, why isn't Xilinx growing faster than the the growth rate that Intel has mentioned around Altera?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's very difficult for me to answer that question. It's even more difficult for me to answer it as they're part of a very large company with a lot of things going on. And so what I would say is we believe in the 6%. We need to deliver the 6%. If the
componenttext: Yes, it's very difficult for me to answer that question. It's even more difficult for me to answer it as they're part of a very large company with a lot of things going on. And so what I would say is we believe in the 6%. We need to deliver the 6%. If they deliver 6% or higher, good for them. We need to deliver the 6%. All of the published numbers with regards to new nodes show that Xilinx's share at 28 is well over 60% and 20 is significantly higher than that. And obviously, at 16 and 14, right, we're -- in terms of shipments for revenue, we have all of the shipments for revenue at this point and we have over a year lead. So I think we're in a good position, and that position has strengthened over the past 3 generations. And we now believe that, that is at the route [ph] of enabling us to deliver 6% growth. And the comparisons are going to be more difficult in the future.

componenttext: So last time, [ph] I got tangled up in the Zynq and the auto. So auto, again, the dynamic in auto is we're seeing the decline in the older line business, which is infotainment and the growth in the ADAS part of the market, which is driven by Zynq. In aggregate, the automotive business for us is around 7% or 8% of our overall business. We think that will grow over time as the ADAS growth rate outpaces the decline in the infotainment part of business.

componenttextpreview: What we know and what we see, [ph] in terms of the end markets, are the customers we have, have been doing relatively well with -- I don't think I would call it strength, I will call it stabilization in the China market and growth in India, both contribut
componenttext: What we know and what we see, [ph] in terms of the end markets, are the customers we have, have been doing relatively well with -- I don't think I would call it strength, I will call it stabilization in the China market and growth in India, both contributing to our year-over-year growth. Now we had -- we've said this before, we had a relatively poor year last year in wireless. In, again, aggregate though, this year, we expect that the overall segment to grow little less than 10%. But what we're seeing right now through the year is not unexpected for us, which is there'll [ph] be up and down throughout the year a few million dollars a quarter, but again, getting to a place where we show year-over-year growth. So it's going to be a few million dollars of cycling in and out each quarter. We are down last quarter from Q1. We expect to be up in the third quarter from the second quarter. So that's not unexpected from what we had looked at for the year in wireless.

componenttext: Okay, great. And just a question here. Obviously, it's a period of elevated 16-nanometer investments. A lot of new parts in each of the families. Just trying to understand, I mean, how confident are you are that each part that's being defined can generate some pretty good ROI? Is each of these parts sort of addressing a specific application at the top customer and [indiscernible] want to parts now in terms of resources?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the parts are -- if you look at the entire family, there's lots of family members. And what we try to do is to make sure that the mix of resources addresses the different needs of each of the market. If we had perfect planning and vision of what the
componenttext: Yes, the parts are -- if you look at the entire family, there's lots of family members. And what we try to do is to make sure that the mix of resources addresses the different needs of each of the market. If we had perfect planning and vision of what the customers really would need as opposed to what they tell us they need, then they tell us they are doing great. Based on our experience, you look back and then you find out that some have overachieved and some have underachieved. But we do try to target the different requirements and sometimes we get it more right than wrong. But it's not the perfect science and it's not necessarily because our ability to predict is impaired. It's -- the customers' needs tends to change. And what we find is they end up requiring different mix and higher performance, et cetera. And so that's the beauty of our business and that we have this whole range of product. So if we miss it on one, we can typically get it on the larger one, albeit sometime it comes at a margin cost to address the specific market requirement.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

componenttext: [indiscernible] calling for Joe. I wanted to follow up in the industrial and A&D segment. Can you just talk about what kind of visibility do you have in that segment? And more importantly, how should we think about the long-term growth trajectory for the different buckets in that segment?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So it's -- this is a really mixed category for us with -- in light of that elements of what's you're after. In certain cases, we are very, very large customers and large and more public deals, like the [indiscernible] A&D, we have fairly good visibi
componenttext: Okay. So it's -- this is a really mixed category for us with -- in light of that elements of what's you're after. In certain cases, we are very, very large customers and large and more public deals, like the [indiscernible] A&D, we have fairly good visibility up until the actual letting of the purchase orders on when you can see the business. But in general, we can map those over time. Test and measurement, to a large degree, we have some customer concentration, we know we're doing extremely well there based on our leadership products. It's just unmatched, there's no competition for the capability we bring there. And so we have relatively good visibility to the program. What we actually can be positively surprised by in that area is the success of our customers as their platforms win in the market. Industrial. Industrial is a lot of customers for us. And so what we are typically doing is looking at a few for specific opportunities at customers and then looking at an aggregate -- aggregation on the broader customer base and seeing what we believe there. So each of these actually has relatively strong growth prospects, not defined by the markets they serve. Industrial, as we said before, driven by the an industrial Internet of Things and platform adoption will be broad-based and grow at the nature of that business is more slowly over time. A&D has actually been a relative bright spot for us. We continue to win broadly in design outside of the joint strike fighter and the joint strike fighter follow-on technology insertions. And so we're seeing a lot of a broader program strength there. And test, measurement and emulation, what you'll see is that our leading products will gain share and grow relatively rapidly and then we'll be filled in by other elements of that category, like semiconductor test business as that broadens out our footprint. So it's going to -- it's a very complex category for us to provide one answer to. Hopefully, I gave some color.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's really helpful. For the followup, I want to talk about 5G. You talked about 5G built starting in 2018 time frame. Can you provide an update there in terms of what are you hearing from carriers come in terms of road map? And more importantly, what d
componenttext: That's really helpful. For the followup, I want to talk about 5G. You talked about 5G built starting in 2018 time frame. Can you provide an update there in terms of what are you hearing from carriers come in terms of road map? And more importantly, what does that mean for you in terms of content opportunity?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So 5G, the market has changed quite a bit. And up to a couple of years ago, it looked like it was going to get pushed out. And definitely, the standard is not quite stable and isn't complete yet. So there's quite a bit of work that still needs to be done
componenttext: So 5G, the market has changed quite a bit. And up to a couple of years ago, it looked like it was going to get pushed out. And definitely, the standard is not quite stable and isn't complete yet. So there's quite a bit of work that still needs to be done and to come up with the standard. But what we have seen over the past 2 years is that all of the major players have shifted to a desire to be first and have significant market share. And we're seeing them all raise. And we believe that our 16-nanometer portfolio and our 20-nanometer portfolio is being used in close to 100% of the early prototypes, which are being used to demonstrate the technology. What we do expect is that the method deployment will start in 2020 onward and that the initial deployments between now and 2020 are happening, and they will -- there's various flavors, 4.5, 4.9, there's a whole host of numbers, which are being thrown around pre-5G [ph], 5G [ph] prototypes, but we're in a good position for all of those that we can tell technology position. But what we do believe that the massive deployment will be 2020 and onward with the combination of programmable devices, and then to some of the companies, they will definitely, over time, design ASIC to address that market as it stabilizes and as the standards become clearer and the market requirements become clear. Hopefully, that helps.

But you're right, that can be lumpy. In wireless, again, I'll go back to the answer I said earlier. We actually -- visibility into our customers demand on us and their view on what they need to build-out in particularly in China and in India on 4G and then the pre-5G business that Moshe referenced just a second ago internationally, North America included. That's what we see.

componenttext: So the way to answer that is of the $3.7 billion of gross cash, about 2/3 of it is -- categorizes permanently reinvested offshore, but about 1/3 of the total has been deemed tax covered, I guess, if you will, for the United States. And the mix of it as we we generated over time, it's a little dynamic, okay?

componenttext: Yes. Well, so there's 2/3 of it offshore, but 2/3 of the total are -- so half of that 2/3, so 1/3 of the total, we have basically provided tax provision for domestic purposes. So we could utilize that without having a U.S. tax book consequence. So when impact [indiscernible]. Yes.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from John Vinh with Pacific Crest.
componenttext: Your next question comes from John Vinh with Pacific Crest.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: As we look at 4G, it appears that we're in the kind of latter stages of kind of the rollout year in China. I think mostly operators in China are forecasting 4G CapEx down over the next several years. And obviously in mature markets, it's probably rolled o
componenttext: As we look at 4G, it appears that we're in the kind of latter stages of kind of the rollout year in China. I think mostly operators in China are forecasting 4G CapEx down over the next several years. And obviously in mature markets, it's probably rolled out. So as we look forward to 5G, which likely is going to roll out in a few years in 2018, do you think you'll be able to continue to grow your comp revenues over the next few [ph] years or are there other offsets to that?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, 4G indeed has peaked and is no longer growing, and -- but there are still deployments that are happening on 4G. Even in China, there are deployments as waves of 4G deployments and are still growing through those. And whenever there's a wave and you
componenttext: Well, 4G indeed has peaked and is no longer growing, and -- but there are still deployments that are happening on 4G. Even in China, there are deployments as waves of 4G deployments and are still growing through those. And whenever there's a wave and you see some growth on the -- India now we're seeing small markets, but we're seeing -- we've been fortunate to get the right design wins and those are being deployed in major way in India. The -- our expectation is that there's a level of densification, which is happening even in 4G part of which we are benefiting from, and then we're already benefiting from the 5G early deployment, but that tends to be not huge volumes, but nonetheless, it's nice revenue for us. So we expect -- the takeaway on wireless is we expect it to continue to be choppy. What we are seeing is on wired communications that now is growing at a nice rate, and that's where our technology lead -- and that tends to be less volatile market anyway, and that's where the technology leadership, in particular, initially in 20 and now even in 16 is helping grow our business. So we do expect communications overall to grow. I don't expect it to grow as a percentage of our business, generally speaking, over the next few years. And it's been fluctuating between 40% to 45%, and I don't expect it to grow beyond the 45%, neither do I expect it to shrink below the 40%. And that's sort of the general element. And from time to time, when there will be massive deployment cycles on wireless, it could sort of push it up, but on average, we don't expect that to change.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

componenttext: Got it. And my followup question, [indiscernible] of the it seems to be more of a measure [indiscernible] this time around versus phase 1, which was a little bit more lumpy. headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we have a little bit better visibility. I think we said before, we're repeating that for all of the elements of the second cycle or the cycle we're on now from the technology insertions, we've won all of the designs available to us. So that's how we ge
componenttext: So we have a little bit better visibility. I think we said before, we're repeating that for all of the elements of the second cycle or the cycle we're on now from the technology insertions, we've won all of the designs available to us. So that's how we get this visibility. We do expect it, and I'm the us right after the aggregate number, we'll get it back to you. But this is going to be -- our view is it's going to be spread over let's call it 10 years in terms of the buying patterns and the buildout. And again, we'll see actually business from the new technologies and we'll also see some of the business from the older technologies in the form of spare replacements and things like that. So our visibility, John, is based on the design wins we have and the discussions we've had with the government primes because they need to tell us when they're going to want them and expect the business to us. So -- but it is not concentrated, right? That is a different from what we saw in the last phase.

componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then with regard to using FPGAs as accelerators. In the last call, you talked about the fact that there'll be certain that workloads where FPGAs would work well versus GPUs. I was hoping you could go little bit more detail about workflow
componenttext: Okay, great. And then with regard to using FPGAs as accelerators. In the last call, you talked about the fact that there'll be certain that workloads where FPGAs would work well versus GPUs. I was hoping you could go little bit more detail about workflow to see guys are good at and where you're not good and has that changed over time as you've got an interview, hey, we're going to better with initially thought.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's a first emerging market with a lot of excitement and a lot of invention just happening there. The -- and there's a lot of ways of skimming the cat. You can do it through just using a lot of processors. The issue there the -- a lot of the applic
componenttext: Well, it's a first emerging market with a lot of excitement and a lot of invention just happening there. The -- and there's a lot of ways of skimming the cat. You can do it through just using a lot of processors. The issue there the -- a lot of the applications tend to be extremely parallel. And then if you try to do it through processors, you can only achieve so much, right, and what typically kill a few is the power there. There's a certain class of applications, which require tremendous amount of floating point, and that's clearly the area where GPUs have the edge and in video, in particular, has targeted this market for several years and has established a very good position and I believe are shipping hundreds of millions of dollars. What is clear is that for a whole host of applications, the parallelism inside the FPGAs and in particular the fact that it's dynamically reconfigurable, in other words, if you can change the way the programmable logic believes to adapt to the payloads and what the customer is doing provide a significant advantage. And what we're doing is we are focusing on enabling that target market and those sorts of applications to use programmable logic. The key to enabling them to achieve that is actually to abstract the design because these -- if you look at the several [ph] large players, they're not renounced happening having a lot of software engineers and system engineers, but no -- but very small number of FPGA designers. So at this point, the biggest issue is not in the architecture of the programmable logic. It's actually in enabling the abstraction so the target users can expand, and that's what we're focusing on. And as we have a whole range of products, which are called FDX product, system design products, which are targeted to pull that, and we believe that those are the key to enabling us to unlocking the potential of the programmable logic. And over the next 2 to 3 years, we're going to make tremendous drives to address that and to broaden that the set of customers. At this point, we need to do it one by one and it's based more on the skill sets that our customers have, which are limited.

componenttext: Okay. And then kind of the higher-level question, there's obviously some very topical scenes in terms of growth in automotive, artificial intelligence, HPC. And at a high level, can you just give us a refresher on your views on why you think FPGAs are better position for any type of parallel processing application relative to GPU architecture and in terms of growth outlook for the next few [ph] years and what you think is most promising under FPGA front?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
